editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: To the Family of God over the whole Earth; but more e≈øpecially to them of the Hou≈øhold of Faith in the Commonwealth of England.
div.p:
ALL who hold the Chri≈øtian Faith, do beleeve that as the world had a beginning, and was a created ≈øub≈øtance; ≈øo it ≈øhall peri≈øh and come to an end (or be changed;) we ≈øeem not only to be on the la≈øt foot of time in this our Generation, but having ≈øtood 1650. years upon it, we have many thoughts of heart-longings for the glorious appearing of the Son of God; Many expect him vi≈øibly to raign here on Earth in per≈øon, and that he ≈øhall be glorified even where he was crucified: Others look for a Kingdome of Righteou≈øne≈øs, a wonderful light of Truth to be manife≈øted, glorious out-breaking glymp≈øes and appearances of the infinite wi≈ødom, the brightne≈øs and evidence of which ≈øhall ≈øcatter all tho≈øe clouds, and di≈øpell all tho≈øe Exhalations which have mi≈ø-led us in the walkings of Chri≈øtianity, the fal≈øe Prophets, Clouds without rain, and Fires without heat, which have appeared among≈øt us: A people in this Nation hath had as great te≈øtimonies of this as any people extant on the Earth. The Power of the Almighty hath vi≈øibly appeared here the≈øe many years, ≈øcattering of Truths, and revealing hard ≈øayings, and giving to under≈øtand things that were hid for many Generations, though according to the wi≈ødom of the Father he hath di≈øpen≈øed divers gifts, and that there is much of controver≈øie among us; yet if all be really for Chri≈øt, and the increa≈øe of his Kingdom, what matters it? Let but all this move and incourage each in his place faithfully to labour in the Vineyard of the Lord. The Ma≈øter is expected; how he will come, lets not wrangle about, nor with whom: Let's all high and low, as we profe≈øs to expect his coming, ≈øo prepare for it: A≈ø≈øuredly he will then come to us in his glory, or take us to his glory: Therefore all you that in ≈øincerity profe≈øs Chri≈øtianity, rowze up your ≈øelves, li≈øten to the call of the Lord; He hath call'd afar off in Germany, he hath call'd at home, both here and in England and Scotland: hear his voyce, prepare to meet the Lord your glory. Hitherto Chri≈øtians have been the ≈øhame of Chri≈øtianity, and Go≈øpellers the ≈øcandal of the Go≈øpel. There was a fatall and general Apo≈øtacy faln upon her who called her ≈øelf the Spou≈øe of Chri≈øt; ≈øhe as Aholah & Aholibah played the Harlot; and though ≈øhe here with us in England promi≈øed to return, yet ≈øhe kept her Darlings ≈øtill; if ≈øhe parted with the A≈ø≈øyrian
Adulterer, ≈øhe kept the Syrian; God will have no mixture with Idols: England hath long de≈øired a thorow Reformation: Let no man boggle at the work if another de≈øires more then as ≈øome of you did 20. or 30. years ≈øince: why may not God have revealed this to him, and clo≈øed thine eyes now, as well as he revealed his will formerly to thee, and ≈øhut the eyes of others. Heretofore God put mean men only upon the work, here and there one; now he hath put many and great men upon the work; and what ever ≈øpurs they have; yet Chri≈øtian, if they drive on Gods de≈øign, lay thy hand on thy mouth, and only admire how God brings things to pa≈øs what he intends.

Some men are ≈øo rational, they can ≈øee nothing of providence; rea≈øon devours Religion, and they are afraid le≈øt they ≈øhould happily find, or be found of God in a way they expected not; they wholly tru≈øt to rea≈øon, and will ≈øee and feel, or they will not beleeve.

Others are meerly ≈øen≈øual, and in the muddine≈øs of their temper follow ≈øen≈øe only, becau≈øe rea≈øon is ≈øo various; as many opinions as men even in things not above us; This is the main ba≈øis of Athei≈øme; ≈øhun this Scylla and that Charybdis, and under≈øtand, All Gods wayes are not only prudential, but providential, and God a≈ø≈øuredly ≈øpeaks both ways: He that improves providence to Lu≈øt, Error, and Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion again≈øt the evident revealed will of God, is like him that becau≈øe he hears of Election, ≈øins at liberty, which is a mark of Rejection; He that in doubtful things in ≈øtreights for God, his glory, his Truth and Laws, the purity of Righteou≈øne≈øs, in ≈øimplicity eyes God with con≈øtant and fervent prayers, walking humbly and watchfully over him≈øelf, and all that partake with him, ≈øpying what leads and mi≈øleads, and ≈øearching all intere≈øts, ca≈øts all away all but that of the Lord and his Righteou≈øne≈øs: Surely he is like him that hearing of Election, and not knowing who it is, yet beleeving not only the truth of it, but ble≈ø≈øings appertaining to it, ≈øaith, I will ≈øeek if happily I may find, I will knock becau≈øe of the promi≈øe; and ≈øuch are a≈ø≈øured to enter life eternal.

Now all you that have in your eye the expectation of the glorious appearance of the Lord Chri≈øt in your ≈øeveral ≈øtations, Parliament, Princes and Nobles, Army, Judges, Officers, Magi≈øtrates, Rich men, Citizens, high and low, Rich and poor, one with another, de≈øpi≈øe not my weakne≈øs, inability, unworthine≈øs; eye not my life pa≈øt or pre≈øent, but look to what I ≈øay, and as you find it bearing the mark and character of fervent truth, accept it; if you doubt, labor ≈øatisfaction privately; if you ≈øpy an error, rebuke or inform me with Chri≈øtian wi≈ødom and ≈øobriety (my zeal for Gods cau≈øe, not ≈øelf-confidence, hath put me forth to the work) and I ≈øhall willingly learn, and ble≈øs-God that makes me know his will, yea though by my failings, ≈øo it may work to the encrea≈øe of his glory, and propagation of truth. Amen, So be it.

And fir≈øt give me leave to ≈øpeak a word to you that have at pre≈øent the Supremacy of Power, lay to heart the≈øe things: Fir≈øt, that you are in Gods ≈øtead; Next that there are many vows upon the Nation for Ju≈øtice and Righteou≈øne≈øs, again≈øt the then, and ≈øtill continued unchri≈øtian, uncivil, nay inhumane dealings of man with man, as man with God, &c. You ≈øtand in the eys of all, all your goings are marked, and all your failings graven to Record: Publick nece≈ø≈øities, your own con≈øciences and
peoples complaints, have plucked forth Declarations to men, as well as Covenants to God; the Obligations to men are ≈øtill the ≈øame, if the rea≈øon be the ≈øame: And for our Obligations wherein we lift up our hands to the mo≈øt high God; truly though the Covenant (as is ≈øaid) be out of date, that is the end of the Covenant for ≈øatisfaction to the King, to draw him to an union and conjunction with his great Councel, be di≈øobliged; yet the ≈øeeking of the ≈øetling of this Nation, the three Nations, all Nations, according to the Rule of Righteou≈øne≈øs in love, peace, and unity, yea the drawing of them to uniformity, both in Doctrine and Di≈øcipline according to the Word of God (that is, by the evidence of truth and the manife≈øtation of the Spirit) is ≈øtill the duty of all Chri≈øtians; for this had been a duty, had the Covenant never have been; it was before it, and mu≈øt remain after.

The pre≈øent Age is in the learned part very acute, at lea≈øt to cen≈øure all per≈øons, and then a≈ø≈øuredly the actions of Enemies. You have many who foment jealou≈øies from the ≈øuppo≈øed Errings and delays, ≈øome to one end, ≈øome to another, but all of beleeving the old experimented Rule of the de≈øtructivene≈øs of popular Government from the variety and incon≈øtancy, the dilatorine≈øs and ambiguou≈øne≈øs of their proceedings, and un≈øatisfiedne≈øs of ≈øo many ≈øelfi≈øh Intere≈øts as are among them; this is to bring in the Government of a King again; Indeed multitude of occa≈øions makes your proceedings ≈ølow-paced. In≈øtead of particular Acts which are un≈øatisfactory, ≈øettle a compleat body of Government; you have means of ≈øupplying all indigencies; for if you improve your power to evident publick good, who will oppo≈øe? The Royali≈øt and all among the Parliament party agree in many ju≈øt things, yet uneffected: Ju≈øtice is the pre≈øervation as foundation of the Throne. If you will raign ≈øafely, walk not in any of the wayes of them that fell before you; the pre≈øident of their puni≈øhment, as their error is too nigh at hand: Let no intere≈øt deterr you from your Rule: Con≈øerve indeed the real Liberties of the people, free us from all tho≈øe Legerdemains, the ≈øleights of Oppre≈ø≈øion and Tyranny: What was unju≈øt gain in the King, let not the State demand there; depend upon, & follow providence as far as you will, and be as remi≈øs and ≈øo called merciful as you plea≈øe; but in things ju≈øt and evidently conducing to common good be ≈øevere and unalterable; this is righteous: In things difficult and doubtful, fir≈øt u≈øe rea≈øon and prudence, di≈øcover the intere≈øt oppo≈øing, and ≈øo proceed to afflict; this wil breed both fear and love: Alter a good and ju≈øt thing, though to a more ju≈øt, by degrees, and gently; for intere≈øts have here lawful pleas; but in evidently evil, it's the glory to make ≈øpeed: Connive not there for an hour. What is here driven at, is the ju≈øt Reformation of all our Laws, the Reduction of them to a Rule and ≈øtandard of Chri≈øtian Simplicity. You that are of the long Robe, both in and out of the hou≈øe, you who≈øe knowledge both divine and humane abounds, as your abilities in outward as inward excellencies, Judges, Councellors and Officers of all ≈øorts, look not at ancient Cu≈øtomes, but at the common Ju≈øtice of them; not how they re≈øtrain particular evils, but as they conduce to univer≈øal good. If you will not admit the oppo≈øition of inferiors, do nothing but carrying that evidence of rea≈øon, as may ≈øtop the mouths of fools, as well as ≈øatisfie wi≈øe men: Let Godline≈øs now in this light be
the pretious gain; its the Pearl of great price: Surely there are things called Law, admitted practically for Law, and tho≈øe oppo≈øed and complained of, which are ≈øo notoriou≈øly unju≈øt and irrational, ≈øo de≈øtructive to the Nation, as its the admiration of all men they are not amended; 'tis laid onely to the charge as (a matter of Intere≈øt) to be ob≈øtructors; ≈øee in the day the Lord oppo≈øing every evil thing; lay down Self, and God will ≈øtabli≈øh you. To you Princes and Nobles, I ≈øay, learn by Gods dealings with you, to ≈øee Thrones, and Scepters, Powers Civil and Military, Riches and Honors, Wi≈ødom and all, are the gifts of the Almighty Wi≈ødom: The Hand of Providence holds them forth, and di≈øpo≈øeth them as it plea≈øeth: You have been bad Stewardes, amend your wayes; God hath here and there taken all away, otherwhere a great part, mo≈øt have ≈øuffered: know God is able yet to take away the remainder: ≈øeek not therefore in pa≈ø≈øion to break out; what ever you do carry God along with you, and that not in thought but deed; a≈ø≈øuredly the judgement el≈øe will be more ≈ømart, and deeper in every change, lets ≈øee the Work of God upon your hearts: change Profe≈ø≈øion into Practi≈øe of Chri≈øtianity; idolize not the Form, but acting ≈øincerely Zeal, Holine≈øs, Au≈øterity of Life in the avoiding the very appearances of evil, but exemplary in Charity, and that not onely in giving much, but giving well; ordering the wayes not of your ≈øelves onely, but of your Families, ≈øo that the nobility of your ≈øouls in the excellence of graces may ≈øpeak you illu≈øtrious above ancient riches, the Vertues or Vices of your Progenitors. The ≈øame I may ≈øay to the Gentry, and men of great e≈øtate, City and Country; know God gives you much that you may do much for him; wherein is now your excellency? Titles! Alas they are but like Ab≈øoloms Pillar, ≈øerve but to eternize his faults and mi≈øerie. Good cloathes, large Retinue (as Revenew, if not larger) and they generally idle, and ≈øo nece≈ø≈øarily vicious; Coaches and hor≈øes, bountiful and luxurious fare, as much ≈øpent to feed and cloath ten, as well would ≈øatisfie each day one hundred: and for one hundred, as would plentifully maintain a thou≈øand: Is God honored in all this, or is the poor profited? you may think it; for thus did your fathers, and ≈øo did you; but where is the Rule? the charges of the Commonwealth, if but five ≈øhillings, are a burthen to you, who ≈øpend ten pound, nay a hundred pound, nay a thou≈øand pound in wa≈øte; and they that have nought, follow your example, thereby believing they gain credit.

I now ≈øhall ≈øpeak one word to the Army; You have followed Providence, make no Selfi≈øh Intere≈øt your Idol, le≈øt Providence for≈øake you; be a≈ø≈øured, others have many enemies; but for you, how few are your friends? there are great engagements upon you to God, who hath with ≈øuch a continued cour≈øe given ≈øucce≈øs to your undertakings: I am ≈øo far from incouraging to Mutinies as I condemn them; there are ju≈øt wayes; u≈øe them; I would draw all the world by the Clew of evident Rea≈øon and demon≈øtrative Ju≈øtice, much more Authorities; and when my rea≈øon could not prevail, I would at utmo≈øt lift up my voyce in prayer, with one hand and my heart, and hold my ≈øword in the other for my defence. All that I ≈øay, is, be Engli≈øh men ≈øtill, war us not into ≈ølavery whom you were made ≈øouldiers to redeem from bondage; but e≈øpecially you Officers, let not promotion cau≈øe you ≈øit ≈øtill becau≈øe at ca≈øe.

I cannot but give out one word of advice to the great and eminent City of this Nation; you were ≈øen≈øible of evils pa≈øt, pride made you fat and you kicked with the heel: Though the greatne≈øs of Trade be broken, repine not; break not out, there is more lo≈øt in a day then can be gotten in a year; vex not Strangers from your Potency, nor Citizens by your Power: Petition not again≈øt Will in≈øtead of Law in others, and u≈øe far more irregularity, and upon le≈øs ground your ≈øelves: you heretofore gained the whole trading of the Nation into your company; we are all Engli≈øh men, ≈øhew us your Charter of Priviledge among≈øt the immunities of common Subjects: will you admit that a particular Company in your City ≈øhould of the Grant of the King have a priviledge to the detriment of your general Charter? why ≈øhould you then to the dammages of the whole Nation? Agree therefore to ju≈øt things; give God the glory to part with quietly from the convictions of ju≈øt Rea≈øon, what you might happily hold, either by Law or Power from your Grants, if the Grant be now evil, though not originally ≈øo; for Rea≈øon making things lawful, and being the bounds of Supream Monarches in general, it cannot be excluded their particular Grants: I know this will grate hard upon ≈øome among you; but if Chri≈øtians, they will hear; it were better to be le≈øs rich, and le≈øs populous, ≈øo more hone≈øt and better regulated: you are at pre≈øent, yea after ≈øo long ≈øitting under the Sword of the Vengeance of the Lord, the ≈øinke of abominable open prevailing ≈øins: you that ≈øhould be the Head to the Body, and the Eye to the Head in the greatne≈øs of Ble≈ø≈øings, going before others, and being a Pattern, and Example to all the re≈øt as a Mother City, as you have been ≈øtiled in the Nation; you are not active for that glorious Regiment of divine Rea≈øon, which as Chri≈øtian, is held forth to us in the Old and New Te≈øtament of our Lord and Saviour, the Lord Chri≈øt Je≈øus: you labour not in what is e≈øtabli≈øhed by Law; then ≈øure it can be little expected that you ≈øhould endeavor the Settlement of more: it is a work of difficulty; the oppo≈øition of the world will be; but the world is overcome, and this gives hopes of Conque≈øt, when we fight an Enemy that hath been beaten; its the cour≈øe of the world to plead Pre≈øidents, and then the highe≈øt are the be≈øt: you are able, do the work; you have done much in ≈øettling a Magi≈øtracie in Chief; ≈øet to the de≈øign; this is of intere≈øt publike; but cea≈øe not here; fit them to the general end of Government as well as to the particular one of Opinion: Its the way of all Corporations; this may not be evil in Politicks; but there is a better in States, much more in Chri≈øtianity.

And from you I pa≈øs to all Cities and Corporations; You have evils every day which need remedy: you ≈øpy errors in your Charters, whereby you ≈øee you are no way able to act for publike benefit: endeavour the Settlement by due con≈øideration of ju≈øt laws: pre≈øent them, as is due, to the Supream Magi≈øtrate; let them ≈øettle the due priviledges, and ≈øo enable by a ≈øtanding Law the Rule of your Chri≈øtian Government in a ≈øocial frame: Emulation may be hereby a ≈øpur to excellency of Order, while the improving the ≈øame priviledges, more or le≈øs, will evidence the excellency of men, which particular honor is the Bellows
to blow up the ≈øpark of outward Vertue to a flame in a zealous or ambitious ≈øpirit.

And you rich men, and men of parts in all places, improve your Talents, hold forth the Light God imparts to you for the healing of this langui≈øhing Nation. The poor increa≈øe ≈øo va≈øtly, through continued and unrepaired lo≈ø≈øes at Sea, and from the deadne≈øs of trading at Land, that unle≈øs ≈øome cour≈øe be taken, all mu≈øt to wrack; be≈øides the mercile≈øne≈øs of Wretches, who ≈øell the poor for a pair of Shooes; ≈øome by forging Judgements, and making folks to compound; ≈øome under colour of Warrants, breaking open of hou≈øes, being Bayliffs, and that at midnight; and then by the Ju≈øtice, its ≈øaid Ju≈øtices of the Peace, let go with onely re≈øtoring the goods again, and this ≈øince acted in ≈øeveral places, they pa≈ø≈øing unpuni≈øhed: otherwhere, a Bailiff upon a Judgement of one hundred and eight pound, upon a debt of forty pound, out of the Common Pleas, (whereby ten pound ≈øixteen ≈øhillings is due to one Officer for one Fee as dammage clear out of their e≈øtate, who are not worth one farthing) comes and makes ≈øei≈øure of a whole Shop of goods, worth by e≈øtimation above two hundred pounds in Grocery, and other ≈ømall wares of Silk, Buttons, Lace, Ribbonds, Linnen, and Woollen cloath, &c. be≈øides all the Hou≈øhold≈øtuff, not leaving a bed to lie on, or ≈øtool to ≈øit on; and the≈øe are (by whole Sale as they ≈øay) without any Inventory, or due appri≈øal, carryed away, and yet no Judgement ≈øatisfied, that is, not fully; forty ≈øix pounds is all can be made out of the≈øe goods; Men con≈øtantly Arre≈øted onely to force them to compound; for ≈øtand out a Suit, they are undone, yet who becomes careful to give or crave relief in the≈øe matters? Thus the poor and mi≈øerable people are daily utterly undone from Forms of Law, and the priviledge is in the Form. O Engli≈øhmen! deceive not your ≈øelves and others with ≈øhadows: The≈øe (≈øo (more then) evident) errings, wandrings, failings, and unrea≈øonable, unju≈øt procedures of ≈øo called (and proud of (as ≈øtriving for the) name of be≈øt, pure≈øt, holie≈øt, &c.) Chri≈øtians, are the gaps and inlets to all tho≈øe ≈øtrange unheard of Opinions, tho≈øe Bla≈øphemous and unnatural be≈øtial actions, and audacious Printings, which there is ≈øuch a ≈øtir withal in the world: lay ought to their charge, they recriminate, and be≈øpatter fouly, and ≈øoyl hangs: For the letter of the Scripture, if Chri≈øtians plead that they are gone, it is as killing under the Go≈øpel as the Law; for the letter of Scripture, and the lives of Chri≈øtians, are as different as life and death, hell and heaven: This in contemplative heads, convinced of duty, works high, and a≈ø≈øuredly brings forth all tho≈øe Enthu≈øia≈øtick Rap≈øodies which ≈øo amaze the world; the≈øe urge them by degrees to greater heights of ≈øo called zeal for Gods Truth, and then after a Prophetick ≈øtrain, they utter things hard to be under≈øtood.

I cannot ≈øee any ground why any ≈øhould be led away after them, nor give any credit to their ≈øayings; No, I rather believe it to be the malice of the enemy, ≈øubtil to deceive; they generally drive at two things, Community, and Parity; the one again≈øt the Tyranny and Oppre≈ø≈øion, &c. of great men in power; the other again≈øt the covetize, ≈øelfi≈øhne≈øs, luxuriou≈øne≈øs, &c. of rich men.

Now the≈øe things, O you great and rich men, do mo≈øt a≈ø≈øuredly, as you rightly conceive, tend to mutiny, to nouri≈øh feuds and envyings betwixt the multitude and you. All that I ≈øay, is, remedy not the≈øe evils by wor≈øe; you know what Bea≈øt you have to deal with; its of ≈øuch ≈øtomack and force, that Prudence mu≈øt have the honour of the management; if you ≈øubdue, know its but by a part of the Bea≈øt (you mu≈øt admit the Allu≈øion) and what in the winding up hath been the i≈ø≈øue of the≈øe things, the Pretorians at Rome, the Mamelucks in Aegypt, and others now te≈øtifie.

Con≈øider therefore what you have to do; God hath ≈øet all the≈øe as ≈øigns and tokens to you; if you fall, the evil is of your ≈øelves, your improvidencies, lightne≈ø≈øes, and in≈øtabilities; your odd and incertain followings of providences, evidence your fears, tho≈øe your doubts, tho≈øe the error of your principle; all things work contrary. O that every intere≈øt now could lay it ≈øelf down at the foot of Je≈øus, and ≈øay, I part with all for thee, and then take up all it hath as from him, and of his gift, and be ready to part with it to morrow: Should we then live as we do now? How many would then give to the poor to day, le≈øt they ≈øhould have nothing to give to morrow? How would they then not delight in luxurious Apparel, Hou≈øhold≈øtuff, &c. wherein multititudes of riches lie dead and buried, le≈øt another ≈øhould enjoy them to morrow?

I know this to ≈øome melancholy ≈øpirit may give occa≈øion to think I aim at, or give too great footing to Community and Parity; for they ≈øhould in ≈øuch contemplations ca≈øt away all; but I ≈øpeak to the ≈øetled Chri≈øtian, who knows its lawful to u≈øe the world, but all in due order; and as its lawful to recreate, but ≈øpend more time in prayer, then in playing; ≈øo its lawful to rejoyce in (and to have that we may rejoyce in) outward ble≈ø≈øings, but glorifie God with a greater portion to the poor then thy ≈øuperfluity amounts to.

I intend a due and ju≈øt reproof to exce≈øs and prodigality; Keep not all hor≈øes and doggs, ≈øome poor, not all in cloathing thy ≈øelf, ≈øome to the naked, and thy ≈øelf with moderacy; and yet if thou do≈øt the≈øe things, thou merite≈øt not Heaven, but thou avoide≈øt the ≈øcandal of men.

Now that this is not done, is the fault of the Magi≈øtrate: O Watchman! its thy duty, but thou ≈øette≈øt up for favor and by-re≈øpect, lazie, idle, and ignorant, and ≈øome evil Watchmen; therefore the work is not done; and that thou mighe≈øt tru≈øt the≈øe, thou made≈øt thy Law to extend to each matter, or ≈øo intende≈øt: and this was for two rea≈øons, one that fools, or any might not err, for the Letter was their guide; the other, that they that would abu≈øe their power, might not; and by this, not having each week a new Law, as occa≈øion grew, Ju≈øtice and Government is lo≈øt; for act by the≈øe particular Laws who can, in one hundred thou≈øand things ju≈øtly requiring remedy? The poor are thus ≈øold for le≈øs then a pair of old ≈øhooes. If you would give a remedy to this, authorize ≈øome few, or many, who ≈øhall examine and determine all actions by, or again≈øt any per≈øon not worth an hundred pounds; for no Tryal
can be under twelve pound, and the eighth part of all a man hath indeed of the thing in controver≈øie to be ≈øpent in trial of whether my hor≈øe be mine or thine, my knife, nay the ≈øheath of that knife, is a woful thing in a Chri≈øtian Commonwealth: I ≈øhall not declaim again≈øt it, but onely ≈øay, its contrary to the wor≈øt of Heathens proceedings: I intend not to make the wound wider, while I de≈øire healing; the difficulty ≈øeems to be onely to per≈øwade men this is a wound: I have been as lenytive and gentle in opening this Orifice of the ulcer of the Law and its practi≈øe as may be: I acknowledge it my Profe≈ø≈øion, not my Practi≈øe; and I account this according to the Head Rule of Englands Law, rather the Practi≈øe then the Principle, the error of Cu≈øtom and intere≈øt from men, then of the Law; I hold forth nothing for Law which is treated of in the Laws of England, but according to the general rule of that Law, holding nothing contrary to the Law of God or ju≈øt rea≈øon to be its Rule; all which I am ready to all, or any particular, to manife≈øt when ever called thereto.

And now I come to ≈øpeak one word to the people; You are of many ≈øorts, and many intere≈øts you have; but as I find the wor≈øt and wickede≈øt, as educated, profe≈ø≈øing Chri≈øtianity, I advi≈øe you fir≈øt to labour as ≈øuch, to approve your ≈øelves: you have, its probable, been mo≈øt of you Baptized; the Covenant is indelible after once you have (I ≈øay not been Rebaptized, or Baptized with the Spirit) but owned that Covenant, in the name Bapti≈øm; you are a debtor to the Lord Chri≈øt of all the duties of the Go≈øpel.

This then, O poor Chri≈øtian, goes far; its the Magi≈øtrates duty to rule well; ≈øo 'tis thine to obey well: 'Tis the ≈øame with you as with the people in Chri≈øts time, when the great and powerful men ≈øpeak the Law, and hold forth duties of Righteou≈øne≈øs; do as they ≈øay, however they do; Its the Magi≈øtrates duty to hear and receive in a right way ju≈øt things from you; and by the implicite Rea≈øon of power onely to vote them unrea≈øonable and ≈øcandalous, is un≈øatisfactory; but if they do ≈øo, remain you in your integrity; break not out again≈øt them, untill the Lord ≈øhall open a way, he will do it in his due time; go on and ≈øatisfie thy ≈øoul in thy own righteou≈øne≈øs, I ≈øay ≈øo, Comfort thy ≈øelf in the mercy of thy God, who hath given thee to ≈øee others failings; and though thy condition be poor and needy, yet break not out: This I ≈øay of this great ≈øcarcity which hath faln upon us, wherein I believe many have peri≈øhed, yet the evil hath light on the rude, ≈øtubborn, di≈øordered poor, again≈øt whom mens bowels have been ≈øhut up; walk therefore according to the condition wherein God hath ≈øet you; exalt not your ≈øelves again≈øt great men, no nor again≈øt rich men, they will be too mighty for you; poor and proud is a high judgement, it brings mi≈øery with rejoycing. I know many of your ≈øouls die within you, when you ≈øee the wicked full, their eyes ≈øtare with fat; you wait upon God, and your children fami≈øh: yea many hence think God regardle≈øs, ≈øo unju≈øt at fir≈øt, at la≈øt deny him. Fools, know 'tis his Wi≈ødom, he puni≈øhes or tries, or both; he puni≈øhes the body in the want of temporals for breaches of duty to thy brother, neglecting the creature, or abu≈øing it, and
the Creator in it: He tries thee for his glory; was he unju≈øt in his dealings with Job? then note that poverty is no ≈øhame, Chri≈øt hath ≈øanctified it; no nor death, no not on the Cro≈øs, if as Chri≈øt the Captain of our ≈øalvation, thou bee≈øt made perfect through ≈øufferings; not ≈øo, if thou bla≈øpheme≈øt, &c.

And now one word to the Teachers of the people; Take heed to your ≈øelves, le≈øt while you preach to others, your ≈øelves become not ca≈øtawayes: Some of you call your ≈øelves ≈øtill the Clergy, I pray evidence by what ≈øpecial right or title: next you claim ≈øpecial Ordination; pray agree to what end; we are jealous of a many among you that would ingro≈øs all knowledge of the Go≈øpel by as gainful a Trade as others did and do the Law; Briefly thus, If you have an infallible Word, ≈øhew it; if but a humane, and that that be attainable meerly or more e≈øpecially by Learning, and that by di≈øqui≈øition knowledge ≈øhal encrea≈øe, then ≈øhew how parts and graces are di≈øtingui≈øhable, and whether you wil quench the ≈øpirit altogether, or allow it altogether, or what or how; tel me why a brother, a member of the congregation, by them approved, may not improve his Talent to the edifying of his Brethren, as well as a Batchelor of Art, or Ma≈øter before ordained as you call it, Common Place as you call it, and that often more ≈øorily then an hone≈øt Bibling brother that never came at the Colledges, though at the Schools of the Prophets.

I cannot di≈øallow Pa≈øtoral de≈øignation, and ≈øo in order from Pa≈øtoral or Teaching abilities; but to re≈øt in de≈øignation any more then in ordination is incongruous; I know this opens a gap to fears of maintenance, but I ≈øee none ju≈øtly; I pray God your ≈øtanding off open not wider ones. If you be not the chief, you are none; what is the cau≈øe of your conte≈øt? I profe≈øs, I am not prejudiced again≈øt any per≈øon; I have been inqui≈øitive into intendments, and I judge the tree by the Fruit; may not man do ≈øo? is it not con≈øonant to rea≈øon? When do you leave your Pari≈øhes generally but to get better, greater Livings? you have made the notions of the Religious a call from one people, and a≈ø≈øent of the other call but ≈øtales to your additional maintenance.

I agree maintenance nece≈ø≈øary, but I dare not boggle with the things of God; ≈øpeak right out, eight ≈øcore, be it ≈øo, is but ≈øufficient by the year to maintain any Family, and till I come at that, I will not hold me to any call; you dare not do it; abu≈øe not your ≈øelves, many ≈øee it; ≈øay not el≈øe you can have ≈øo much in another place. This is the beautiful Harlot; your hot and eager di≈øputes are the Alarms to our continued feuds (I cannot ≈øpeak this to all, for there are ≈øome who imitate as much as this Age will permit, the example of Chri≈øt their Ma≈øter; and what ever their opinions be in Politicks, they ≈øubmit to the Powers for con≈øcience ≈øake, and what ever they may think, they unrake not the coales of di≈ø≈øention, much le≈øs will they blow them to a flame;) here are all our griefs, here is one wound ≈øo long kept open, hereby is all obedience in all degrees lo≈øt and extinct, no re≈øpect of Magi≈øtrate in any degree; the truth is, the unfitne≈øs of ≈øome Magi≈øtrates, in not having abilities, and of others in misimproving them, and ≈øo of Mini≈øters, hath heightned by a ju≈øt judgement the evil of contempt on all ≈øides; the retaining, and ≈øo
eager ≈øeeking unwarrantable intere≈øts will make the Callings I fear ≈øuffer by bringing all into que≈øtion; my rea≈øon is, This hath been Gods way here now and before: As all things nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øalvation, are (through the goodne≈øs of God) plain and evident; ≈øo all things nece≈ø≈øary to righteous Government; what Magi≈øtrates ≈øtumble at, is the perver≈øne≈øs of people in pur≈øuing unju≈øt ends to or again≈øt their fellow-brother, but e≈øpecially in cutting ≈øhort or tying him up too ≈øtrictly in the requi≈øites of honour, order, and maintenance, and that for the Publick. The people ≈øtumble at the Magi≈øtrates evil u≈øing, and greatly abu≈øing his Tru≈øt and power to ≈øelf-intere≈øts, profe≈ø≈øing for the publick, but intending and vi≈øibly bettering ≈øelf. Its a received Rule, The di≈øea≈øe is more then half cured, if the true rea≈øon be known.

O you Magi≈øtrates and Law-givers, you have the fir≈øt part to act, be you righteous; evil and di≈øordered people are the manife≈øt tokens of a loo≈øe negligent Magi≈øtracy. Its evidently ea≈øie to ≈øettle a Nation more numerous, more di≈øordered from ignorance and will, then this is; in the time we are di≈øcour≈øing how far the Magi≈øtrates power extends in Religious things, or in a Politick con≈øideration what ≈øhall be done when the Nation is ≈øetled, before the ≈øettlement be made or agreed upon; let's not to avoid the evils of the wor≈øt of Levelling ≈øo called, give advantages to their de≈øigns or propo≈øals: Let's walk, ≈øo that we may by rea≈øon as well as power maintain our proceedings; before we undertake, lets re≈øolve to pro≈øecute or ≈øurcea≈øe upon evident and publick rea≈øon; the want of this hath di≈øobliged more then ever the Covenant or Engagement bound. And as I begun with you in Supream Power, Civil, or Military, or both, ≈øo give me leave to end; when you fir≈øt engaged, when fir≈øt you began this great work of Religion and Publick Liberty, how hot and ≈øpirituous were you, when great oppo≈øitions and many de≈øigns were on foot? how watchful, when you were running for the Goale and ≈øtriving for the Ma≈øtery, yea, as your ≈øelves ≈øaid, venturing for your own Lives and Liberties? how regardle≈øs of bare forms? how then could you look at publick good in the nighe≈øt ≈øafe≈øt way? you could then lay out your way be≈øides the common Road without the formality of ≈øuing out an Ad quod damnum; yea what ≈øtrength of rea≈øon could not untye, the Sword did cut: Thus are the burthens, ≈ønares and vexations of truly religious people gone as to the con≈øcience: Thus far you have been ≈øincere in your Obligations to God; be al≈øo as faithful in your Tru≈øts to the Nation. I would not have Judges taken away, root and branch; Judges are found in Holy Writ, yea ≈øuch in power and Authority as we de≈øire to have; we de≈øire Ju≈øtice ≈øhould flow like ≈øtreams, and Righteou≈øne≈øs like mighty waters; the want of this impoveri≈øhes the Nation; I am in ≈øuch place, that I ≈øee and know it, yea I beleeve, let it be rightly ≈øcanned, it will appear mo≈øt co≈øtly, more ruinous, and more en≈ølaving then two ≈øuch Armies; and as now practi≈øed, more intolerable then an univer≈øal Toleration ≈øo often charged upon you.

Now the Lord God of hearts lay what is written to all your hearts, and grant that you may go on as you have promi≈øed, namely, according to the great Tru≈øt that is upon you from the people, you proceed in procuring
common good, (which is the true and ultimate end of all ju≈øt Government) and by a right aim at that, direct all your actions, and not cea≈øe to improve your be≈øt judgements, and lay out your mo≈øt unwearied labours, notwith≈øtanding all di≈øcouragements, either from malice, envy, danger, or any other cau≈øe what≈øoever, to promote the ≈øame, ≈øo far, and ≈øo fa≈øt, as the ≈øubject matter will bear; and a≈ø≈øuredly the ble≈ø≈øings of Heaven will attend and follow you and your Councels; otherwi≈øe be a≈ø≈øured, when God hath made u≈øe of you for a while, the Lord will ca≈øt you away, as others before you, and your place ≈øhall no more be found: for the averting of which judgement, and ≈øetling this Nation and the Government of quiet and peace upon the foundation of Truth and Righteou≈øne≈øs, is the prayer of

closer.signed: Him that zealou≈øly and faithfully endeavours and prays for the peace and happine≈øs of the Commonwealth, CHARLS GEORGE COCK.

div.head: A SVRVEY Of the Hou≈øhold of God on Earth, &c.
div.p:
THe Lord God for his own glory, and the accompli≈øhment of his determinate Councels, made the world, and every living thing, whether Angels, or men, in heaven or in earth; which perfected, The Almighty wi≈ødome, though it could have otherwaies gloryfied it ≈øelf, thought fit among all the Creatures which his hands had made, to rai≈øe man to that pitch of honor, as to make him not only the object of his love, but in ≈øome ≈øort the Author of his honor, (who is the fountain it ≈øelf or original ≈øpring of honor and all other vertues and excellencies) and this he him≈øelf acknowledges, by ≈øeveral expre≈ø≈øions of his own, and Prophets, when men have yielded obedience to his Commandments, ≈øaying they honored him, or gave glory to him. Yea indeed it will be acknowledged of all ≈øorts of men, that the end of mans Creation was (as is the work of every Artificer) the glory and honor of the Creator, and maker; Therefore the ≈øame wi≈ødom that Created man, even while man was yet ≈øimple and pure, in the ab≈øolute height of his fir≈øt created perfection, put him under the obedience of a Law and Rule in word, to the keeping of which tho≈øe fir≈øt principles which we call the Laws of ≈øen≈øe, and rea≈øon, were but ≈øub≈øervient. But man kept not long that ≈øtation; but di≈øobeyed the law of his mo≈øt high Creator, by which error or fall its concluded and agreed, by all Chri≈øtians, that the whole nature of man was corrupted and tainted, and from being the ≈øons of God in pure creation, all mankind became the ≈øons of Adam by natural propagation; bearing in our bodies the ≈øting and marks of our fir≈øt ≈øin, in our daily and continued tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions, thru≈øt out from the pre≈øence of our God, and could dwell no longer in paradi≈øe. And now the Laws of ≈øen≈øe and rea≈øon were mans rule, God not holding that lively communion with man, which he did before, to pre≈øcribe him particular and po≈øitive Commands, or Laws; (at lea≈øt that we read of.) Yet the goodne≈øs of our Creator, tran≈øcendently appeared, in that while he breathes forth threatnings to his di≈øobedient ≈øervant, nay actually puni≈øhes him, in ejecting him the earthly Paradi≈øe, the Type of the heavenly Re≈øt, he opens a door of comfort, in ≈øo ≈øweet promi≈øes as he there annexed, of the hopes of a Saviour; under which Covenant he plea≈øed in all ages to take a ≈øpecial regard to ≈øome men, in and by whom the family and hou≈øhold of God was continued; and to the≈øe he ≈øeveral times, and by ≈øeveral manners revealed him≈øelf (whether by Dreams, Vi≈øions, Angels, or otherwi≈øe, is not ≈øo materiall to be here di≈øcu≈øt) and taught them the Laws and Ordinances of his hou≈øe, which Laws we ≈øee were not ≈øo contrary to the Law of pure Rea≈øon or the inherent law of nature, that they wrought divi≈øion, or ≈øeparation either among≈øt them≈øelves, or with others, or ≈øo per≈øpicuous to the eye of mans rea≈øon, that each wanderer ≈øaw the wi≈ødom of the Father, and immediately followed that rule and dictate of the divine Spirit; of which families or hou≈øholds it is conceived the Lord had ≈øeveral in divers Countries at the ≈øame time; but as being lea≈øt que≈øtionable,
mo≈øt proper to a Chri≈øtian, and ≈øo mo≈øt ≈øub≈øervient to our end, we ≈øhall only look at the direct line of ≈øcriptural genealogy, from Adam to Noah, and ≈øo to Abraham, of who≈øe po≈øterity in the twelve Patriarcks, was found the people of God, the holy ≈øeed, among whom were (in his due time) ≈øhewn the Oracles of God, the depth of wi≈ødom, both for the government of Gods people as men, or Saints, by the Lords annointed, and every inferior power under the civill Scepter: or by the royall Prei≈øthood or inferior Levite under the Divine declaration. How far Adams power extended, or how ab≈øolute it was, I ≈øhall not controvert, nor yet Noahs; but this we may ≈øee, that it was ≈øo paternal, that we read not of any cen≈øure that he gave to Cain upon his brothers murther; though we ≈øee God did; but how it was effected, whether only by the voice of con≈øcience, or otherwaies, is ≈øo difficult that we will not gue≈øs, but conclude, had the knowledge of it been material, either for Gods honor or our good, the holy and wi≈øe God would not have ≈øo ob≈øcured it; nor yet gives God a precept again≈øt murder, but gives it Noah after the Flood. That it was want of ab≈øolute power afterwards, that brought ≈øuch loo≈øne≈øs, and di≈øorders upon the world whereby ≈øin in the ≈øucce≈ø≈øions of generations, from Adam to Noah, was ≈øo multiplyed, the contrary ≈øeems evident, and that from the Tenor of Gods truth: For there were mighty men, who abu≈øed their power to wrong and inju≈øtice, therefore were they plagued; we may ≈øay plainly, they ≈øought and got power over each other, and de≈øtroyed the pure law of nature: For (though I am not again≈øt, nay I am for Government, as will well appear hereafter, yet) this I ≈øay, that the law of pure naturals ≈øets not one above another, which law ob≈øerved, there would be no need of Governors, for each one would be a law unto him≈øelf: But to return, the power thus obtained, they abu≈øed it to unju≈øt ends, Spoile, Robbery, Rapine, Lu≈øt, and ≈øuch like; for this came the wrath of God upon the≈øe children of di≈øobedience and violence; and the Flood wa≈øhed away them and their ≈øins together. Yet the Lord remembred Noah, for was he ju≈øt, from who≈øe po≈øterity de≈øcended all the pre≈øent Inhabitants of the earth; and although the fathers were, as Shem and Japhet, righteous in their generations; yet the ≈øons and progenie of the≈øe, forgat the laws of their fathers hou≈øe, and fell into the delu≈øions of Sathan, by the lu≈øts of their own hearts; And forgetting the Judgements of God upon the old world, they as well as the ≈øeed of Cham, fell into the ≈øins of the old world, and promoted them≈øelves over their brethren, not according to priority of birth, as mo≈øt congruous to rea≈øon, but by might and power, abu≈øing tho≈øe excellent qualifications of divine infu≈øion, again≈øt the law of the mo≈øt High, and then according to their factions, they by ≈øtrength got dominion, which loth to lo≈øe, they combined together again≈øt God him≈øelf; nay as ≈øure as the Lord liveth, the Poet truly expre≈ø≈øeth the heart of man, The≈øe Giants or Principes would if they could, have plucked God out of heaven; they fir≈øt brake his Laws, and then fought again≈øt him; but the Almighty now only ≈øcatters them to his glory; and they who before were bounded in a narrow compa≈øs, are now di≈øper≈øed through all regions, and it is concluded that the chief of them of one language, upon the confu≈øion of tongues was their Prince, but whether that were the mo≈øt Ancient, Strong, or Wi≈øe, we ≈øhall not need here di≈øpute; it is agreed there was a cheif, and that the mo≈øt ancient, by the general Law of rea≈øon, owned that place. Our evil hath grown from lenity; our remedy mu≈øt be at lea≈øt nece≈ø≈øary ≈øeverity; and if you be not guilty, you may u≈øe it freely; 'Tis offendors cry out ≈øo ≈øternly for mercy; you are now by true intere≈øt and obligation, to labour a well grounded peace to this; the occa≈øions of publique di≈øgu≈øt mu≈øt be fir≈øt taken away. You have ≈øeen the ≈øtanding out of the King again≈øt a few ju≈øt things made at la≈øt, that many that would have been granted, would not ≈øerve the turn: I profe≈øs, it is meer zeal to Ju≈øtice‚ñ™ hath produced this.

I have avoided bitterne≈øs to the utmo≈øt; My only hope, de≈øire and prayer is for the welfare of the Nation, and the e≈øtabli≈øhing of it upon the firm ba≈øis of mo≈øt undenyable verities; I ≈øhrink under the oppo≈øition Truth is like to find. If there be not a ≈øpeedy ≈øettlement, there mu≈øt be a di≈ø-≈øettlement; the people are prone to, as well as ≈øtirred up to di≈øobedience; did you command never ≈øo well, if Subjects ≈øhake off the yoak, or loo≈øe it but in what or as long as they plea≈øe, Empire mu≈øt down.

We are now as it were in the dregs of ≈øo called Populacy; the Kings attempted alteration, and alteration was ju≈øt, but ju≈øt things mu≈øt be done ju≈øtly; and as he ≈øuffered for ≈øeeking him≈øelf, ≈øo will others in their day (if the expected one come) mete out to you.

Learn the nature of the one Covenant made with Abraham, I≈øaac and Jacob, and ratified to us Chri≈øtians ≈øo di≈øtingui≈øhed from time, as of Faith and Works, that as much of Works is now requi≈øite under the Covenant ≈øo called of grace, as was before of Faith under the Covenant of works; contend not ≈øo much, whether Magi≈øtrate or Congregations be the Keeper of the fir≈øt Table, as both to give due glory to God, and educate the people faithfully in the knowledge and practice of the Doctrine of the Go≈øpel; and you chief in power, to ≈øee to govern them according to a Rule of Righteou≈øne≈øs, upon a ≈øure foundation in all places and callings, which according to the Talent God hath given me, I ≈øhall here hold forth to you, and that out of the ≈øo called Law of England, or u≈øually accepted Law Books of the ≈øame with the Word of God, and the approved examples of our mo≈øt free Progenitors, wherein that I name not the Authors, I have before laid down the rea≈øon; I ≈øhall only now hint, That its the duty of Magi≈øtrates not to regard the per≈øon of the man from whom the work comes; grant it but my mite, if it be pure Gold, put it into the Trea≈øury; I will give much light to ≈øome, and though others know much more, let them al≈øo improve their talent; make u≈øe of this till then.

div.head: To the Engli≈øh Reader.
div.p: WHoever thou art, of what ever Calling or condition, know, God calls thee by his Judgements to a ≈øerious con≈øideration of thy duty; thy duty is towards him, and tho≈øe to whom he hath given power over thee. They hold forth de≈øires of ≈øetling the State, and that both in Religious and Civil re≈øpects ≈øincerely. We all agree all out of order; that which naturally draws mo≈øt men, is pre≈øent benefit; this makes ≈øome crie out for the old Government, others one wholly new; others to ≈øettle their Condition, would patch and dawb, and joyn iron and clay together: I ask thus, Is the priviledge of an Engli≈øhman, and old Laws, and carnal Intere≈øts above that of Chri≈øtian, Chri≈øts, or Gods Laws, and the inheritance of Eternity? If ≈øo, to them ≈øay ≈øo, I am ≈øilent. To the Chri≈øtian Engli≈øhman I ≈øay, I have propounded a Model of Chri≈øtian Government, I ≈øay not perfect, nor according to that perfection which I do, as I conceive, comprehend; but ≈øuch as may be con≈øtituted to fit by degrees to a more pure ≈øettlement. I intend not all ≈øhould be as here ≈øet down; its but an E≈ø≈øay; I have gone as neer the Original Law of England after the Nation received Chri≈øt, as I could; This, if accepted, mu≈øt, as in all alterations, de≈øtroy many intere≈øts, and advantage others.

All that ≈øubmit in all things to the will of God, will not kick again≈øt him in his dealings; they will ≈øay, its the will of God, I ≈øubmit: How it ≈øhall be done, I leave to the great Councel of Parliament, be≈øeeching the Almighty to give them
wi≈ødom to govern the people rightly; we are a ≈øtubborn Nation naturally; where grace poli≈øhes, look for a≈ø≈øured help; where wi≈ødom ≈øettles, you will finde no re≈øi≈øtance. Go on Worthies, God is with you, and good men are not again≈øt you; chear their hearts; go on to ≈øettle; be not alwaies pulling down; its harder to build then de≈øtroy. I know many of you, then much more the people, will think ≈øome of the≈øe Tenets again≈øt priviledge; what, the Magi≈øtrate to ≈øuperadvi≈øe private actions? be not di≈øquieted either to think your care will be too great, or the Subjects Liberty ≈øtreightned: The oppo≈øition is only to evil men in evil things, and that when notorious; the onely thing you all fear, is Magi≈øtrates may abu≈øe their Tru≈øts. To all ≈øuch I ≈øay, the Law is ju≈øt ≈øtill; for the man, puni≈øh him.

I ≈øhall not enlarge but in one word to the Politick man; Sir, I have I confe≈øs not ≈øtuck ≈øo clo≈øe to the rules as many do, at lea≈øt of late; but you may ≈øee I offer things as I think they may be now received, to fit for better by degrees. To all I ≈øay, the intention of my undertaking was onely the peoples good, but e≈øpecially Gods glory, who knows all our hearts, and knows that I ≈øpeak truth, to who≈øe guidance I commend your Spirits.

div.head: AN ESSAY OF Chri≈øtian Government.
The fir≈øt Quaere, what is Monarchy and its Divi≈øions?
div.p: FIr≈øt, Monarchy in General, or ab≈øolute Monarchy, is the Government of one man according to his own Will, without any regulation. So whether he rules ju≈øtly, or inju≈øtly, hath ≈øeemed needle≈øs to quaere, ≈øuppo≈øing that the people having ≈øimply ≈øubmitted, what ever he doth is ju≈øt, though ju≈øt rea≈øon with ju≈øt men be his Rule.
But here is to be quaeried, whether ≈øuch ab≈øolute ≈øubjection binde the parties ≈øo ≈øubjecting them≈øelves to obedience in things unlawful and evidently de≈øtructive to publike good.

To this it is Summarily an≈øwered, that they them≈øelves are not bound; for as Nature doth nothing in vain, ≈øo neither communities of men, who act together by pure Naturals, that is, look at what they call good, therefore as for pre≈øervation of the whole, they agree to be ≈øubject, who were free; ≈øo for the ≈øame rea≈øon vi≈øible, they may rea≈ø≈øume that ≈øubjection into native freedom; and this the examples of all Ages, Nations, &c. manife≈øt to be the Law of pure Rea≈øon, whether their attemps were ≈øucce≈øsful or no.
But what if bound by an Oath?

To this I ≈øay, the Oath mu≈øt and can work no otherwi≈øe (intentionally) if free, then to the general end afore≈øaid, common ≈øafety, and that de≈øtroyed, they are loo≈øed; for the Law of Nature, and for Freedom ≈øake, all rea≈øon annexes, and mu≈øt annex ≈øuch a condition to every ≈øuch Oath.
But what if the Oath were enforced?

I ≈øay, it is ab≈øolutely and ≈øimply void; all Laws in all Nations in pecuniary contracts, the Minima hominis, damn enforced Oathes, then much more in main matters of liberty, though the intere≈øt of Princes and great men, under colourable ≈øhews and preten≈øions of peace, and quiet thereby, have cau≈øed great Wits, and great Pens to abandon Nations to the lu≈øts of particular men.

This cleared in the ab≈øolute Magi≈øtrate, it will be more then clear in the limited, that cautioned Freedom, how ever obtained, and by whom, ever mu≈øt be ob≈øerved; and though that the be≈øt ordet is a whole Repre≈øentative to act in enforcing and judging matters of ≈øo high concernment;

Yet the declarative act of breach of Tru≈øt pa≈øt by the major part, execution as with us may be ju≈øt; though ≈øome ≈øay not ju≈øtly done, (that is, in manner and form, I here admit of Form:) But ≈øome ≈øay, it had in the formal part ample ≈øatisfaction, according to the letter of the Law, and ≈øo was done ju≈øtly; for if a force were upon the hou≈øe, it was by the hou≈øe; and they not que≈øtionable, but either by the whole people, or a new Repre≈øentative; and this till recalled by a more lawful power, mu≈øt be ju≈øt; This was done by Parliament at We≈øtmin≈øter, the place, and a ≈øufficient number of per≈øons to make a Court in Law there was; and the Law gives no power to inferiors
to take notice of the jangles of equals, e≈øpecially in Supremacy of Power; this in Law, in Con≈øcience they mu≈øt look to them≈øelves, who did the Act; if unju≈øt, our con≈øcience is to look to the pre≈øervation of ju≈øt liberties which we have; and in a due way to gain tho≈øe which under pretence of Conque≈øt, pa≈øt, or pre≈øent, have been gained from us, and by time u≈øurped, which the≈øe men have promi≈øed who are our Repre≈øentatives, that is of the whole Kingdom; for their general and great Engagement is,
Fir≈øt, to do the Nation Right, next to ≈øerve the particular places faithfully for which they are cho≈øen, and to ≈øee they have no wrong;

Now of the≈øe Monarchies; ≈øome are Elective, ≈øome Hereditary; this alters not the Cau≈øe, but may make men more cautions, in ca≈øe of the Nation, who≈øe Kingdom is con≈øtituted by Hereditary ≈øucce≈ø≈øion.

div.head: 2. What is Ari≈øtocracie?

The next is where is the whole body thoo≈øe never ≈øo vile a wretch, he is fit for the place, a Tribune of the people, and his Yea, or No goes as far as Any's.

An other Democracie is ≈øetled in ≈øeveral choices, refining the gro≈ø≈øer pars by degrees, and by wi≈øe limitations, re≈øtraining the way of confu≈øed meetings, and yet giving ju≈øt freedoms, and to keep Ju≈øtice pure, limiting the Electors as well as the Elected, and that not onely by re≈øtraints of not ≈øuch e≈øtate, or no Vagabond, or that hath been ≈øuch, no Thief, no out-lawed per≈øon, no perjured per≈øon, no ≈øervant; but ≈øome have Chri≈øtianly added, ca≈øt out of the Church, a common Swearer, Lyer, Tavern-haunter, Prophaner of the Lords Day, a Game≈øter.

This yet being the work of the Supream Magi≈øtrate, the more warily ordered the State is in rea≈øon con≈øtituted, the more durable.

By this it is plain, that all ≈øubjection was admitted for protection; and that protection merits, and may require ≈øubjection, and ≈øubjection protection; that this power imployed again≈øt the end, is in Law (that is the radiance or glymp≈øe of Divine Rea≈øon in man) utterly void, and all of them intend but the ≈øame thing, namely publike good, although they ≈øeek it divers wayes.

div.head: 5. What form of Politie is be≈øt?
div.p: THis pa≈øt, I now come to to quaere, which of the≈øe forms of Politie is the be≈øt? Wherein I cannot be of opinion, that Ari≈øtotle onely out of affection to his Pupil, rai≈øed Monarchy to the top of Excellency; for why ≈øhould he not as well have ≈øet his King above the Laws? but this indeed he did not, re≈øting in a limited Monarchy, wherein the Law was the Kings boundary; and ≈øurely he knew no King limited but in Greece, ≈øpecially in Lacedemon, where I take it, he was ≈øubject to the Ephori, and by them to the Ax, and the Halter, &c.

I find the excellency of a Kingdom above a Commonwealth, rather by not having the
Evils of Ambition and quarrels for Supremacy, then the good of Common Ju≈øtice, Right Laws, and gallant Spirits, begotten and educated.

Tis agreed, a King is more ea≈øie to be corrupted, as is, and hath been ever manife≈øted in all ages; and though it was then preferred as more ea≈øie to reduce (for few would then ≈øtand again≈øt publick intere≈øts) yet now it being made the Idol of vain men, and the Chri≈øtian world wholly o're run with vanity, it is harde≈øt to be reclaimed; for things are evidenced to be ea≈øie or difficult, as intere≈øts are.

Yet Divine Providence hath here blown upon all intere≈øts, for they were corrupt: (Oh you that are in power, build not with ≈øuch hay and ≈øtubble ≈øtill, for ≈øurely your work is like to pa≈øs the fire.)

But a≈ø≈øuredly a Kingdom Hereditary, is far before any other Kingly Government, where the Nation is ≈ømall, bounds large, and ≈øpirits content; for Peace is mo≈øt durable in that Government. And that will give Riches, and the people ≈øhall have ea≈øe and plenty, and grow numerous, (for emulation the mother of di≈øcord, is re≈øtrained at lea≈øt.)
But then the land will be too ≈øcant, and that Nation mu≈øt fall upon others, or break within her ≈øelf, or tran≈ømit Colonies.
Now Democracie mu≈øt be in War abroad, or el≈øe ≈øhe breeds Feavers in her own bowels.
Yet Ari≈øtocracie and Oligarchy ≈øeems wor≈øe, as partaking in more ≈øelfi≈øh intere≈øts; but a≈ø≈øuredly in all, they are be≈øt or wor≈øt, as the men Ruling are.

div.head: 6. Whether the acque≈øts of Kings belong to the State in Ca≈øe of alteration of Government?
div.p: SEeing now alterations are incident to States, it may be ju≈øtly Quaeried, whether what is gotten by the Prowe≈øs of a King, or Marriages, come to the Supreme power Governing, or return back in ≈øuch Alterations, or the Heir Naturall to enjoy them?

The an≈øwer is ea≈øie; for all the≈øe things re≈øt in the King as King, as they were acquired, whether in an ab≈øolute or limited State, they go to his Succe≈ø≈øor Politick, not Natural, not in the ordinary cour≈øe of inheritance, but according to the Tran≈øition of the Crown, how great Jumps ≈øoever it take, and this per≈øon dies not; ≈øo that it is evident the ≈øupreme power hath all the acque≈øts, and rights, whether Warlike, or Civil, as by Marriage, Permutations, Emptions of State, or Mortgages Real, as Cautionary Towns.

So that this Change of Government hath not dive≈øted England of any Title to ought due to any former Kings as Kings of England; whether in Ireland, France, Ca≈øtile, Cicily, Cyprus, Hieru≈øalem, united Provinces, or el≈øe where.
