div.head: 7. Whether better to be Governed by Laws, or without?
div.p: HAving ≈øeen the Governors, let us ≈øee how they are to Govern. I take it that the ≈øame rea≈øons again≈øt Arbitrary Government in a King, will ≈øerve for a State; for grant a Choyce of the mo≈øt excellent men in knowledge, and Ju≈øtice:

Yet can we ≈øay they ≈øhall be alwaies ≈øuch, or tho≈øe that ≈øucceed them? therefore no doubt it is better to be Governed by good Laws, then good men, taking care that tho≈øe Laws be executed under ≈øevere puni≈øhments.

div.head: 8. Whether better to have general, or particular Laws?
div.p: I Now mu≈øt come to the hard task of all Polititians, That is, to ≈øet the Medium of power in Magi≈øtrates, wherein it is plain, that to tye a Magi≈øtrate (in any Government) ≈øupreme or inferior, yet admini≈øtring Ju≈øtice to the very ≈øtrict letter of the Law, is to have all the ≈øafety of the Commonwealth ≈øhipt in a Ve≈ø≈øel without ≈øails or oars; ≈ølip but the letter, and no Magi≈øtrate can meddle.

Therefore generals mu≈øt be the way, but limited they mu≈øt be, or el≈øe your venture is as much on the other ≈øide; for to give him no bound, or too much, is to put him into a ve≈ø≈øel overladen, and the ≈øail too full, which upon every gu≈øt is ready to ≈øink, or be o're turned, or run under water.

Now to pa≈øs this Scylla and Charybdis, is the hard work in the fir≈øt ≈øettlement: That the ≈øupreme Magi≈øtrate hath his due boundary, and after for him ≈øo to di≈øpence to inferior Magi≈øtrates, that the equal Temperament in every part may a≈ø≈øure the ≈øafety of the whole.

England, before the late fatal infu≈øions into King Charls his head, of the ab≈øolute power due to Princes Jure Divino, whereby they were rendred accountable only to God, boa≈øted again≈øt all other Nations of the happine≈øs of all the≈øe Governments, in a ≈øweet and admirable admixture of power; for they had the freedom of a Commonwealth, the opulency of Ari≈øtocracie, the glory of a King.
Yet he ≈øo bounded by the Laws, and ≈øo watched by the Emulators of his glory, the Nobles, and by the Con≈øervators of our Liberties, the Commons, that it was hard for him to break.

Yet break he did, and that ≈øo ≈øuddenly, that it was evident the ≈øettlement we gloried in, was but as we ≈øay, A la≈øt ga≈øp to the decaying ≈øtate of the Ba≈øtard William, ≈øo called, the Conqueror.
And now is the time for them to whom God gives the Honor of a Settlement, ≈øo to mould and temper Government, that it may be mo≈øt durable, which is the glory of a State.

Now to do this aright, after the A≈ø≈øurance that nothing be done, how politick or advantageous ≈øoever it ≈øeems, contrary to the light of Chri≈øtian Doctrine, I come to the difficulty above≈øaid, that is, What Power is to be committed to the Magi≈øtrate, whether Supreme or Inferior, re≈øpectively?

To which I an≈øwer generally, That the Magi≈øtrate, whoever he be that is intru≈øted, ought to have more power then its commonly requi≈øite he ≈øhould improve, that thereby by acts of Grace he may endear or ≈øuppre≈øs, as occa≈øion ≈øhall offer:

The Supreme thereby obliging all parties, as well inferior Magi≈øtrates, as other Subjects: the inferior Magi≈øtrate to engage the equals (in all but Magi≈øtracie) and all the vulgar, and that without puni≈øhment from above, or ≈øcorn below.

For it is evident there are ever ambitious or in≈øolent Spirits, who if the Magi≈øtrate be tyed too ≈øtreight, will draw him to the end of his line, and then dare him; I wi≈øh from my ≈øoul Magi≈øtrates were all wi≈øe and ju≈øt, fearing God, and hating Covetize; but in the choyce of the≈øe men for intere≈øts, it will not be ≈øo; therefore I meddle not to pre≈øcribe rules, as ≈øome do, for a man who prefers private intere≈øts, but him that onely and principally fixes him≈øelf, and his endeavors upon the advance of Publick and Common good; therefore to them I addre≈øs my ≈øelf, with this Caution;

That the great ruining danger, is, in times of Commotion to be over ≈øtrict, beyond late pre≈øidents, and Examples; for that blows the coals of Sedition, yea ≈øparks to a great flame e≈øpecially if publick ruins build private fortunes, ≈øo called, or partake with any ≈øelfi≈øh intere≈øt.

They therefore that are in Supream tru≈øts, and would ≈øettle, or continue their Governments quiet, mu≈øt them≈øelves in their places, and whom they impower re≈øpectively, with (not onely faithfulne≈øs and diligence, but al≈øo) wi≈ødom and di≈øcreet activity, moderate that power which may be lawful, much more that which is exorbitant, or but to be u≈øed again≈øt per≈øons exorbitant (that is, violent Rebellious (and that in acts) di≈øturbers of the Peace) for again≈øt ≈øuch, to ≈øpare one guilty, is to
venture the de≈øtruction of a thou≈øand of innocents; In evident ju≈øt things ≈øettle the power.

Now I come to the Rules of bounding the inferior Magi≈øtrate, wherein I conceive it is principally requi≈øite to add to the general Rules of Law, or head Laws, particular Officers, by which onely it is lawful to act in time of peace, or not imminent danger.

That to this Officer being ≈øworn, or tyed under a ≈øet penalty of faithfulne≈øs in his Office, the Magi≈øtrate ≈øend his Warrant, expre≈ø≈øing the cau≈øe of the Warrant, as now to Con≈øtables; and that this Warrant di≈øcharges the Officer, and then the complaint is and ought to be again≈øt the Magi≈øtrate.
For no rea≈øon one ≈øhould be puni≈øhed for executing his Office by command of his Superior.

Nor is it fit the Magi≈øtrate ≈øhould be too ≈øuddenly lyable to Que≈øtion; therefore it is requi≈øite to have ≈øome appointed near hand, to whom the Magi≈øtrate in Ordinary, and al≈øo the Subject may have recour≈øe, who knowing the Law, may ≈øpeedily determine; for otherwi≈øe the Judge or Magi≈øtrate is di≈øcouraged on the one ≈øide to act, and the Subject on the other ≈øide fears his liberty to be infringed, both which mu≈øt be provided again≈øt ≈øpeedily and certainly.

For it is a≈ø≈øuredly meet, That every one not acting Legi≈ølatively, but judicially upon Laws ≈øet, ≈øhould be under the juri≈ødiction and Cognizance of ≈øome one or more per≈øon or per≈øons, and to make returns to them of at lea≈øt all matters doubtful.
And again, That they that act Legi≈ølatively ≈øhould not act judicially, nor be the ≈øame per≈øons, (unle≈øs in ca≈øe of vi≈øible nece≈ø≈øity) lea≈øt otherwi≈øe Ju≈øtice fail.

As for example, if the Judges of the Common Bench, Common Pleas, and Chequer were Judges in Parliament, could we think the Parliament fit to determine their Errors; lets have the be≈øt Laws that could be, Laws would be but dead letters ≈øtill in them≈øelves.

div.head: 9. Whether the Laws ought to be according to the Judicial, or what? and whether a head rule, or not?
div.p: I Come now to that great and old (difference, or) difficulty, what is the boundary to humane Power, or Authority, or Dominion, call it what you will, it is the executive vertue in the Magi≈øtrate Supream, in dictating, or giving forth of Laws.
Now I in this ≈øhall wave treating of Law, in its variety of objects, and ≈øhortly give you this de≈øcription of it.
It is the Rule of well ordering Societies of men, or many Families of men living together; and aims e≈øpecially at pre≈øerving the poor and weak, again≈øt the rich and mighty, &c.
Now it is truth, that many Nations have divers Laws, yea, great variety, and all ju≈øt; and ≈øome Nations have a few Laws, and many unju≈øt; naturally, each one ≈øeeks particular good.

But as this grew obnoxious to particular per≈øons or families, they joyned together, and that under agreements, wherein there being ≈øtill particular re≈øpects according to the advantages and di≈øadvantages of the Covenanters, ≈øo were the Laws more or le≈øs unju≈øt; but ofttimes that which was ≈øeen unju≈øt after, was not di≈øcovered ≈øuch at the time of enacting.

Hence ≈øome have, to take away all wrangles, fallen upon a Community; ≈øome from Community, to Property, ≈øtill looking to avoid the pre≈øent evil; yea from hence indeed ≈øpring all the Commotions, and hurries of the world, which ≈øo Rent and ≈øhake people and Nations.

So that there was nothing ≈øo highly honored, as the enacting good Laws; I take it to be the Original, at lea≈øt one of the chief Originals of the Heroes, or Daemones, men Deified (≈øo God him≈øelf ≈øtiles Magi≈øtrates, becau≈øe of their Repre≈øentation of him among men) and all the≈øe Law-givers pretended at lea≈øt to receive them from the gods, or the friends of the gods.
For even to natural men it ≈øeemed ju≈øt, that what wi≈øe men had in≈øtit uted, wi≈øe men might alter.

Now if the≈øe Laws were onely ≈øome Prerogatives of the Princes, or Priviledges of great men, which men had ≈øought to u≈øher into the world with ≈øuch pomp, there might have been a ground for ob≈øtruction; but the≈øe which were the Laws of well living, the Laws tending to publick quiet, repo≈øe, riches, & honor, (cu≈øtom of living being equal to, if not above nature) were of nece≈ø≈øity thus brought in, onely by fear of the ≈øuppo≈øed Gods; yea, al≈øo the future Magi≈øtrate was by this (≈øuper≈øtition, call it ≈øo) onely kept in aw, not to break forth into exorbitant affections, or decline action, either not to make the Law like the knife of Delphos for all purpo≈øes, or el≈øe for no purpo≈øe.

So are men bya≈ø≈øed by private re≈øpects on the one hand, and loving ≈øupremacy of power on the other, that unle≈øs there be ≈øome over-awing decree, ≈øome ≈øetled boundary, beyond which we mu≈øt not pa≈øs, there is no ≈øafety.

Now if it be ≈øaid, this is indeed true in the cau≈øe of natural men, but not ≈øo to Chri≈øtians; Grace perfects nature: I agree, it is truth in ≈øome ≈øence, but not in every part; for it is rather true in the future, then any other Ten≈øe; for it works here in the fle≈øh not ≈øo inten≈øively, but more remi≈øly, yea, ≈øometimes the effectual work of grace ≈øeems dead; that this is true, the agreed failings of the Saints evidence.
Yea tho≈øe in whom the work of Grace was begun ≈øure enough; as witne≈øs Davids Pride, Murther, Adultery, &c. Samuels ≈øufferance of his ≈øons, Hezekiah, and all others before Chri≈øt.
Peter, the ≈øons of Zebedee, Paul, Barnabas and others, under the Go≈øpel.

So that it is plain we mu≈øt remember it to be truth in ≈øome ≈øort, which was objected again≈øt Ari≈øtotles councelling Alexander, (as was pretended) to u≈øe the Greeks as friends, and carry him≈øelf as their Guide and Conductor; but to u≈øe the Barbarians (meaning thereby all other Nations) as enemies, and carry him≈øelf towards them as Lord and Ma≈øter.
The rea≈øon of their objection was very acute; for ≈øay they, there are many Greeks wicked, and many vertuous Barbarians.
So that if any Quaere, whether Laws ≈øhould be diver≈øe in re≈øpect of divers ≈øorts of men, it is ≈øhortly an≈øwered, Laws are to re≈øtrain and puni≈øh onely evil, whether men or actions.

This being cleared, the next thing is to come to the more clo≈øe and plain re≈øolving of the que≈øtion, wherein I cannot urge antiquity; for I wave all Authors more then as illu≈øtrative, taking none as Authoritative; the ≈øuperintendency of the Expurgatorian Cla≈ø≈øis abroad in forreign Authors, and our Licentia, or Placet at home, making them ≈øpeak what they li≈øt, or as they li≈øt who are ma≈øters of the Pre≈øs; for if ≈øo done to ≈øome, why not to all? or who can tel to which? and indeed there is no nece≈ø≈øity of either ancient or modern te≈øtimony, the Almighty wi≈ødom having the ≈øame fountain of endowments, graces and abilities as in any age, and the ≈øame as plentifully poured out now upon us, however it is improved.

This premi≈øed, I then Quaere, what law is exi≈øtent among any or all the Nations of the world, like that which is called Mo≈øes Judicial, holding forth ≈øuch fit and apt puni≈øhments, as are there laid down, carrying with it ≈øuch a vi≈øible rea≈øon for it ≈øelf, agreeable to the Rule of Proportion?

I may ≈øay that the law of England did own this as its nece≈ø≈øary pattern (it is ≈øeldom denyed) but if any do oppo≈øe, or doubt, let them fir≈øt con≈øider, That no law in England was ≈øetled (generally at lea≈øt) until the Pope had come to an obliging power, and that agreed; ≈øure as he aped the Ceremonials, he did engage a conformity in Princes as far as might be to the Judicials.
I ≈øhall now ≈øee the onely or main objections again≈øt the Judicials, which may be reduced, I take it, to three chiefly.
Fir≈øt, they were given to the Jew.

Secondly, they are not, or cannot all be performed by us; for ≈øome were onely proper to the Jew, ≈øome no way fitting this Nation, for they were never received; and there is a nece≈ø≈øity of altering laws as vices encrea≈øe, and grow more Obnoxious; and al≈øo in regard the Judicials them≈øelves are not all ≈øo clear that it can be ≈øaid which are all the Judicials, by rea≈øon of mixtures of Ceremonials with them.

Thirdly, The Law of Chri≈øt is a Law of Love, not Revenge, to pray for enemies, do good to them that hate us, turn the other cheek to him ≈øtrikes one, and give the cloke to him takes the coat, and go two miles with him enforces thee to one.
God a≈ø≈øi≈øting, we will endeavor to clear the≈øe Heads; and then in con≈øideration of the particular Laws, an≈øwer ≈øome particular Objections, if any be ≈øeen needful.

Now as to the fir≈øt, That the≈øe things were immediatly directed by the Almighty wi≈ødom to the Jew, it is agreed; But what doth this hold forth? Sure onely this, That the Jew was bound by them, God having commanded them to that Nation, that God required not obedience from the other Nations to whom he had given no command, but that any other Nation might not u≈øe them, it proves not;

But rather that tho≈øe Laws, as far as holding forth a rule of Ju≈øtice to them which had no Rule, or a better, where defective, ought by the≈øe Nations to whom they were known, to be e≈øtabli≈øhed, is ≈øure out of controver≈øie, while Legi≈ølators have Ju≈øt and Good for their Rule. To the ≈øecond, That they cannot be all performed by us, Let us ≈øee the hindrances.

Fir≈øt, Some being ≈øuppo≈øed onely proper to the Jew, if we come to ≈øearch what tho≈øe be which we cannot perform, there appear here vi≈øibly but the Law concerning the Trials of Adultery, and Virginity; we allow the≈øe ought to be inquired into, and ≈øatisfaction given to the jealous ≈øpirit; but we pre≈øume the ≈øpecial Law binds not; That in ca≈øe of Virginity, being, though natural, yet as it were onely proper to that Nation, and that by ≈øome extraordinary power of Divinity, giving forth Te≈øtimony to his own Law.

The other ≈øimply extraordinary, in regard the ≈øame water wrought ≈øo contrary effects; ≈øo that the vertue was evidently not in the water: and if we ≈øhould ≈øearch the depth, the ≈øeeds, though conceived by of the Adulterer, could work no more then of a husband in the ordinary cour≈øe of Nature.
There is al≈øo ≈øome particular Laws of two wives, humbling of Handmaides, with ≈øome others.

The next ≈øort of Laws are ≈øuch as are ≈øaid hold no proportion with the natural condition of the people of this or other Chri≈øtian Nations; and therefore the Nations ≈øetled others, and never received them.

To this part I an≈øwer; That if it never received them, there was no trial, whether agreeable to the Nation or not. Next if tried, how doth this indi≈øpo≈øition in Nations generally to the receit of particular Laws appear? ≈øure it is not by way of Antipathy, ≈øo that the Nation fails, dies, or is removed upon receiving of them; truth is, we all agree, Nations may be altered by Laws, as the Romanes brought from natural ≈øavagene≈øs to a more moderate temper by Numa's Laws; and the Lacedemonians by tho≈øe of Lycurgus; and they may be heightned and deba≈øed in ≈øpirit, as well as moderated; but all this re≈øts not in the Law, but the executive part or power of it.

Now that force will naturalize Laws, it is plain; why then not Rea≈øon? It is evident, Laws are the reins of Rea≈øon over the bea≈øtial part of man; therefore now to the rea≈øonable man any ju≈øt Law is approveable; as to his obedience, he is a Law to him≈øelf, and happily gives far le≈øs liberty to his particular bea≈øt, his appetite, be it to, or in what it will, then it is fit the general Law ≈øhould hold forth; and this hath ju≈øt wi≈ødom in it; hereby are the good and wi≈øe di≈øtingui≈øhed from the vain and idle, even by the ≈øubjection of natural appetite: from whence it is hereby clear, that to govern a fierce Nation, the ≈øame Laws will not ≈øerve, as to govern a quiet peaceable one.

But now our Quaere mu≈øt be, whether there be not be a ju≈øt Law in the generality, agreeable to the light of Nature, ≈øet down in the Judicial heads of Law, which will agree to govern all Nations by; take two Laws for example, Murder and Theft.
The fir≈øt is the head-Law of mankinde towards his like, the prime end of Magi≈øtracy being to pre≈øerve life.

The next is goods; Now in this I finde no loo≈øe to the Magi≈øtrate, but life mu≈øt be for life; if murder, that is, lieing in waite, or as with us malice before hand; in this the Magi≈øtrate hath no liberty to ingratiate in refined Rea≈øon; it lies upon the Land, if not expiated with the blood of the offender, and ≈øo upon the City, and ≈øo upon the Army.
But the chief guilt ≈øurely lies upon the chief Magi≈øtrate, who is the prime in tru≈øt executive as to the fact; this ≈øure is, and ought to be death in all Nations.

The like head-Rule of common Ju≈øtice is in the Law of the man≈ølaier at unawares; and ≈øurely of this ≈øort there will be no doubt, nor of the expiation of incertain murder which ought to be ≈øetled rightly by an Oath of Inqui≈øition, &c.
But the great quaere will be concerning Theft, which is the matter mo≈øt, or with the mo≈øt to be con≈øidered, as a grould of controver≈øie.
For the mo≈øt of Chri≈øtian Nations have made it death, yet the Judicial maketh it death in no kinde, That puni≈øhing life with life, and goods with goods, &c. in the rule of proportionate Ju≈øtice.

Now this alteration is not without rea≈øon as things ≈øtand, that is, upon the received principles forementioned out of the ≈øeeming contrariety which Chri≈øtians have gathered out of the Law Judicial, and Apo≈øtolical.

For they have gathered, that Chri≈øts Kingdom being of brothers, there ≈øhould be no ≈øervants; that is, no ≈ølavi≈øh ≈øervitude, or bondmen, which was the i≈ø≈øue of not ≈øatisfying what was ≈øtollen with the Jew; and upon this pre≈øumption, they at la≈øt wholly abrogated, as to Theft, the mulcts of two, three, four, or ≈øeven-fold re≈øtored for his life, and took away his life; now this being onely practice, cannot determine the Controver≈øie.

Let us then ≈øee the Rea≈øons if any be, whereof the mo≈øt eminent is that of Magi≈øterial Intere≈øt, whereby he would wave a limitation, or rule in ordinary, and make him≈øelf ab≈øolute in every condition.

For Supremacy generally aims at ab≈øolute Power in all e≈øtates, Royal, or Republical, or mixt, though they maintain their intere≈øt diver≈øly, according to evident principles, upon which their foundation ≈øtands; this therefore is a Politick rule; but how warranted by Supremacy of Rea≈øon, upon the pure principle of common or univer≈øal good, or what Rule in the Word, mu≈øt be examined; in the written Word there is owned nothing as clear; for ≈øure then the controver≈øie with ≈øome one good Magi≈øtrate, or Commomwealth or other would be determined, and the intere≈øt of Righteou≈øne≈øs would cloud the intere≈øts of riches, honor, power, &c. This therefore failing, let us ≈øee the Rea≈øon; the fir≈øt part whereof is in nece≈ø≈øity of altering Laws, according to emergencies; to which it is an≈øwered, That Laws in inflicting ju≈øt penalties may be higher or lower according to emergency; and the rigorous, or exact execution may be ju≈øtly inforced; but the incompatibility or di≈øproportion of the Law of Death for Theft is, in that all the goods of a Prince are not of equal worth as goods, be they Hor≈øes, Kine, Gold; Silver, &c. to the head of a Slave, con≈øider him as man: nay, the Lord touches not mans liberty for goods meerly, if he had wherewith to re≈øtore; therefore this Rea≈øon will not avail.

But if we con≈øider the Quaere a little further, there will appear le≈øs rea≈øon yet; and that is, that even Chri≈øtians them≈øelves doubt not, but that would the Magi≈øtrate wave his advantages, both to him≈øelf, Clerks, Officers, &c. by the death of Felons, and ≈øtrictly ≈øee to the Execution but of re≈øtoring two or three fold, Theft would not be the one hundred part ≈øo frequent as now it is; for though generally it be truth, that pre≈øervation of life is the prime principle of Nature, and he will part with all to ≈øave that:

Yet the ≈øpirits of ≈øome men are ≈øuch, being not poli≈øhed by divine precept, that they ≈øcorn to live but as they have been educated; ≈øome will dye rather then labour, and ≈øo Thieve, or commit any villany.

Now it is by ≈øome thought the≈øe may be put to death, but the≈øe do not put the≈øe men to death for Theft, but not having to re≈øtore, they impri≈øon them to ≈øatisfie by labor, their wrongs; and if they break pri≈øon they dye for it; ≈øo that death is now inflicted upon them, not only by the equity of the Law Judicial, but univer≈øal rea≈øon cutting off this di≈øobedient ≈øon, rooting out this Moth of the Commonwealth; and there is ≈øure much of Ju≈øtice in this; for now with Chri≈øtians to pro≈øecute a Felon (as any other criminous per≈øon) will co≈øt a man in expence of time, and Fees, and other charges, as much as would have kept his Family a moneth, which added to his lo≈øs who would pro≈øecute, yet compound the Law forbids, but I intend ha≈øte.
The next rea≈øon is, the Judicials are ≈øo mixed with Ceremonials:

To which it is an≈øwered, that many are clear, u≈øe them; the other ≈øearch out how the mixture ≈øtands; for if there be a plain Law of di≈øtributive Ju≈øtice, a nece≈ø≈øary rule for the benefit of Societies, take that; and if there be no corrupt intere≈øt in it, ≈øure it will be accepted by wi≈øe men, though meer Politicians may baulk it, as well as enact it, as King Hen. the 8. did in ca≈øe of Marriages.
I am now come to the great head of all, namely that the Judicials were a Law of revenge, which now is proper to God, Chri≈øtians mu≈øt not fight, war, revenge, &c.

I could with ≈øome ≈øay I admire the wonderfull goodne≈øs, mercy, long-≈øufferance, patience, &c. of God, who willing to ≈øhew the Riches of his mercy, forbears the ve≈ø≈øels of wrath fitted for de≈øtruction.

Art thou a Chri≈øtian that objecte≈øt again≈øt the Judicials to elate another Magi≈øterial power then that of the Regiment of the Lord Chri≈øt? for though they were given by Mo≈øes, they were the Dictates of the prime verity: And where O man ha≈øt thou ≈øuch a pattern!
But thou wilt ≈øay, We are Chri≈øtians, and we have no need of Laws?

I an≈øwer with Paul, If thou bee≈øt the Law to thy ≈øelf, the Law puni≈øhes thee not; Rulers are ≈øet up for the puni≈øhment of evil doers: So ≈øaid the Lord to Cain in the fir≈øt two thou≈øand years; And ≈øo ≈øaith the Spirit to the world in the la≈øt two thou≈øand.

But ≈øay you, we acknowledge a Law to men, but not Chri≈øtians; Brethren, be not deceived; remember what Peter ≈øaith, The unlearned and un≈øtable wre≈øt the Scriptures to their own de≈øtruction; the place I pitch upon to clear up the Righteou≈øne≈øs of the Law even to Chri≈øtians, is that of the 1 Tim. 1. from the 8. to 14. There are multitudes of places hinting the ≈øame, I at pre≈øent know none more pregnant; for thence it is plain, that there were then many controver≈øies ≈øtirred by the Chri≈øtian Iews, or ≈øo pretending, concerning the ob≈øervance of the whole Mo≈øaical Law, whether Ceremonial or Judicial.
Paul had beaten down as much as in him lay, the Ceremonial, ≈øhewing it was but the ≈øhadow, the body was Chri≈øt.

Now concerning the Judicials particularly there is no que≈øtion, but from the following ver≈øes, and from other places it is plain what was intended; for in the 9. ver≈øe, he ≈øheweth wherefore the Law was made.
Fir≈øt Negatively, not for the Righteous, (the foundation of great errors while mi≈øapplied.)
Next Affirmatively, for the lawle≈øs and di≈øobedient, ungodly and ≈øinners, unholy and prophane; the≈øe are general.
Now he comes to particulars, Murderers, Man≈ølayers, Whoremongers, Buggerers, Men-≈øtealers, Lyers, Perjured per≈øons, and again≈øt all other things contrary to ≈øound Doctrine, &c.
There is an objection again≈øt this, viz. the≈øe things are Morall.

To which I an≈øwer, that if you take Morall for the Law of the ten Commandements, they are not literally there; if you intend Moral for what ever is contained virtually under the≈øe heads, the two generals whereof comprehend the whole duty of man to God, and to his brother, all mankind, then the whole Judicial at lea≈øt mu≈øt be therein comprized.
If you intend by Moral, what the light of perfect rea≈øon holds forth concerning ju≈øt and good, no man dare ≈øay the Judicials wanted the height of perfect Rea≈øon.
If you look at it as rectified by Evangelical Doctrine, then it is an≈øwered, that the primitive error is the cau≈øe of our now wandering.

Fir≈øt generally ≈øeeing the errors which have flowed by the Church to the Commonwealth, we confu≈øedly judge this to ri≈øe from the principle of the Judicials, and lay all the pride, covetize, and various intere≈øts of Princes Courts, Judges Fees, and unju≈øt and unnece≈ø≈øary dependancies, Nur≈øes of Heatheni≈øh and dete≈øtable wickedne≈øs, villany and en≈ønaring dependencies to life and liberty of common Societies as well as particular men upon the Judicial.
Next it is beleeved, that Chri≈øtians take the Judicials proper to them, as to the prototype of the Jew, which might be; but now a clearer light manife≈øts higher things, or is ≈øo pretended to.
The main particular and worthy con≈øideration is our formation of Chri≈øtian policy according to the Jewi≈øh Model; for we held all Baptized as Circumci≈øed to be Chri≈øtians.

Now of the≈øe, how excellent Chri≈øtians we have, the Gallows, Gaoles, Hou≈øes of Correction for puni≈øhment, and all places of vanity, ≈øuch as almo≈øt the Heathen would
blu≈øh at, Drinking, Dicing, Drabbing, &c. publickly known, manife≈øtly proclaim; and though no rents to the State, as at Rome, for the Stews; yet to the State≈ømen they enhance Farm Rents, &c. for ≈øurely, were there no advantageous intere≈øts, they would not again≈øt common profe≈ø≈øion be upon ≈øo weak rea≈øons as they are, tolerated, while winked at; yet what is done with the≈øe Chri≈øtians? lo they are puni≈øhed, are they not? Surely no, not one of ten, if one of a hundred; and this puni≈øhment is the ≈øacrificeing for ≈øin; and this pa≈øt, they are if it be but commutation, as clear Chri≈øtians as the be≈øt; and being now become more ≈øerviceable to corrupt intere≈øts, the≈øe ≈øpied out the lawful Liberties of better Chri≈øtians, which the Judicials not affording a whip for,

The Magi≈øtrate mu≈øt be loo≈øed from his re≈øtraint rather then not have an hone≈øt man puni≈øhed; this rai≈øed error upon error, and opened this loo≈øe to the Chri≈øtian to ≈øeek freedom from an unju≈øt Law; and to the Magi≈øtrate, to ≈øeek to puni≈øh at lu≈øt: But if you ≈øee through all the Apo≈øtles Writings, they only forbid the ≈øin; and for puni≈øhment, look at the Law in general, which ≈øurely they could not intend but of the Judicial.

Now for the Commands of Chri≈øt the Lord, and the Precepts of Love, Charity, Patience, forbearance, &c. they are certainly true, and to be ob≈øerved; and then the Quaere or Objection is, what need of Law? The An≈øwer to this is as evident as the other, That the pure≈øt Congregations, Churches, &c. have had, and ever will have evil men among them, not only hypocrites but open ≈øinners; The error of the Congregations not ejecting, or Magi≈øtrates not puni≈øhing, or not due regulating by puni≈øhment, rather ≈øhews the nece≈ø≈øity of Law, then the u≈øele≈øne≈øs of it.

Now grant that the whole Nation were purely Church-Members, of which no vi≈øible cau≈øe of ejecting or rejecting communion appeared; yet there would or might ari≈øe many debates, differences and controver≈øies, which would require a Magi≈øteriall Authority to determine, if but for difficulty; And ≈øurely the Congregations of Chri≈øtians never ≈øo little declining, could not avoid litigations and wranglings; and there being no word to extirpate the Civil Magi≈øtracie, it becomes not Chri≈øtians to wrangle, much le≈øs violently to oppo≈øe ≈øo approved, ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary an Ordance; That opinion that in the ≈øimplicity of the la≈øt Age, as in the beginning, the father of the Family ≈øhall be King and Prie≈øt, hath little warrant; that hath more, that each Saint ≈øhall be ≈øo; and yet in the mean time, as hitherto, ≈øubject to the powers; yea, the Heathen ones, for con≈øcience ≈øake, of the radiancy or glimp≈øe of the Divinity holden forth in them.

It is truth, pure Chri≈øtians will not be contentious, ≈øome meek ≈øpirits may and will obey the letter of Chri≈øt; and ≈øure they that do ≈øo in faith, ≈øhall not fare the wor≈øe for their exact obedience; but in the mean-time, this is no binding rule to us, except the words be ≈øo intended.

It is truth, the child of God ≈øeeks not his own, &c. he is wholly taken up with God, &c. ≈øhall the Magi≈øtrate therefore ≈øee evil again≈øt him go unpuni≈øhed? Again, love and not avengeing wrongs, and praying for enemies in the ≈øpiritual ≈øence, may ≈øtand with the puni≈øhing, afflicting, and bringing to judgement the body of the tran≈øgre≈ø≈øor in the literal; yea, God is thereby glorified; otherwi≈øe how can the peace of good men be pre≈øerved again≈øt the wicked, but miraculou≈øly? which we have no warrant to expect at pre≈øent, and what ≈øhall be hereafter, as the light manife≈øts it ≈øelf, the Lord grant we may walk in it, and al≈øo up to it; and that our Laws may be e≈øtabli≈øhed according to a rule of Righteou≈øne≈øs, even according to the wi≈ødom revealed by God him≈øelf; and that all emergent Laws may flow from the ≈øame fountain; for for every action contingent there is as is agreed no particular Law already ≈øetled, nor well can be, but the Chri≈øtian Magi≈øtrate ought to provide that not the lea≈øt wrong or tre≈øpa≈øs but be righted or puni≈øhed.

I mu≈øt yet remove one rub, and that is, the Judicials have been our mi≈øguider hitherto, therefore better any other Law then them; 'tis the ≈øame that was objected for u≈øing of formes, whether of prayer or otherwi≈øe which the Church of Rome u≈øed (and was partly ≈øpoken to before particularly) in that all our old errors having ≈øprung from that root that it is nece≈ø≈øary, yea, ≈øome ≈øay of nece≈ø≈øity, to wave that for our rule le≈øt we tread the ≈øame trace of error, that was before our ruine; and therefore better take our Laws from Turk or Per≈øian, or &c. then from the Judicials.

Now let us examine this, and all will appear vain; for fir≈øt it is denyed, that the
ob≈øerving the Judicials, yea though as binding as the prototype, was the error of Chri≈øtians, ≈øo as to bring ≈øo horrible a defection upon our Judicatories.
We maintain not (I de≈øire to be rightly under≈øtood) That this Nation profe≈ø≈øing Chri≈øtianity, is bound to the Mo≈øaicall Judicials in the command to the Jew.

But a≈ø≈øay to manife≈øt that tho≈øe Judicials were not our mi≈øguidance. The Decalogue or Ten Commandements we all agree (except in the ≈øet day of the Sabboth) to hold forth but even what Natures light determinately approves, whereby it is evident that ≈øin is the ≈øame to us as with them, which all the writings of the Apo≈øtles manife≈øt.
Now the ≈øin in the head Law being the ≈øame, what difference in the branches, either in re≈øpect of the ≈øeverall ≈øpecies of tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion, or manners of puni≈øhment.

That the Law pre≈øcribed in the Judicial for puni≈øhment, holds a due proportion, puni≈øhing life with life, goods with goods, &c. if ≈øo, then that the≈øe mediums or rules of due puni≈øhment ought much more to be ob≈øerved by the Chri≈øtian Magi≈øtrate under the Law of the Go≈øpel, the glad tydings of peace and mercy, then by the Jew, and not to outbound, unle≈øs after the utmo≈øt of execution the Law be found evidently defective, which I pre≈øume it never will be under prudent Magi≈øtrates.
Now to him that ≈øayes the ob≈øervation of the≈øe Laws was our ground of error;

I ≈øay in the Ceremonials of Mo≈øes it was; and that the receiving of the Judicials might open a gap to introduce that error the more facily, I will not deny; but that this mu≈øt either ca≈øt out the Judicial, or make us take the Rule (for this in any ju≈øt Law I pre≈øume mu≈øt be) from the hand of a Heathen rather then from the word of promi≈øe, is the fruit of ≈øtrong contemplative zeal; for the puni≈øhment, ≈øo it holds its due proportion, take it from the Turk if you will, or Per≈øian, it matters not.

The Turks puni≈øhment, ≈øo it be not Torture, may ≈øuit be≈øt the ≈øpirit or genius of the Nation; for to burn, hang, behead, or ≈øtone, all is but death; and this difference, had Ceremonies ≈øo called been lawfull to be enjoyned, might have ≈øtinted our controver≈øie of old between the then ≈øo called Prote≈øtants and Puritans for the receiving the ge≈øtures, ≈øet formes of Prayers, Ornaments and Formes of and in Church-Service ≈øo called.

And a≈ø≈øuredly it ever hath been one of the Devils gyns, to fright men from truth and right by mi≈øcarriages in the manner, &c. hence cometh the ≈øcandals of profe≈ø≈øion from the errors, if but of one or two hypocritical or mi≈ø-led profe≈ø≈øos; we may as well refu≈øe the Scriptures becau≈øe Heretiques u≈øe them; and that they lead to Judai≈øme is a great error; for ≈øurely Judai≈øing was intimated in no part of the Judicial Law, of which any que≈øtion can be.
For the exception in Fornication, things ≈øtrangled, and blood, the la≈øt two being meats, we are now freed from.

There is a holy jealou≈øie which is for God, and is commendable; and there is a pertinacy from intere≈øt, which is Idolatrous and wicked; the Lord open mens eyes, e≈øpecially tho≈øe in Authority, rightly to di≈øtingui≈øh that they be not found fighters again≈øt God.
Now who are to expound this Law, and ≈øettle it, and how far their power extends, is our next task.

div.head: 10. Who have the power to make Laws, and how far that power extends?
div.p: SOme may think, that the Judicials being laid down to be the fitte≈øt rules for Chri≈øtians, or any men to live by, That this Quaere is needle≈øs.
For what have we to do with Law-makers, of or among men, when God him≈øelf hath fitted the work to our hand?

But the≈øe men mu≈øt know, that time brings to light new inventions of ≈øin, Satan goes about in variety of ≈øhapes and deceives daily, and the≈øe offences many of them will be difficultly referred to the proper head of Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion; therefore it is requi≈øite that there be a ≈øuperintendency to oreview the≈øe errors and apply a remedy in time according to their rule, yet to puni≈øh life with life, goods with goods, &c.

Now the≈øe are various according to the either condition or con≈øtitution of the Nation, or both; the con≈øtitution according to ≈øetled Law and con≈øtantly received; the condition time of war or peace.

Now the time of war being only accidental, we are ≈øpecially to con≈øider acts done according to the ≈øetled con≈øtitution of the Nation, be it by Monarchy ab≈øolute, or limited, or Republique; Republiques of all or any ≈øort; and their boundary is common and publique good, and that either according to emergent nece≈ø≈øity, as in ca≈øe the elders of Gibeah had con≈øented to have all their eyes put out for National advantage; for in ≈øuch a ca≈øe the elders had turned evident Traytors to their tru≈øts, but to lo≈øe one or either eye. This will receive ≈øomewhat more ample ≈øatisfaction, if we con≈øider ≈øeriou≈øly

div.head: 11. What are the proper Rights of the ≈øupream Magi≈øtrate, ≈øo called, Prerogative.
div.p: NOw in the handling of this Que≈øtion it is fit a little to open what is Prerogative; now this ≈øimply taken, is the Priviledge or preheminence that one party hath, either above, or before another, and ≈øo is no more then to have that of right and duty, which others have by accident or by favor, as to have the mo≈øt honourable place, to be heard fir≈øt, and ≈øuch like.

But to take it in the proper latitude, it is the ≈øum of all tho≈øe powers, priviledges, Rights and Immunities nece≈ø≈øary to the Supream Power, whether per≈øon or per≈øons (according to the ≈øtrict rule) that thereby the people may be the better governed, according to the loo≈øe rule, that the people may be kept in ≈øubjection, and the glory of the King or Ruler exalted, and that as to ab≈øolute Power over both body and goods.
Now therefore to treat of Prerogative in ≈øuch a ≈øence, is vain; for Prerogative is ab≈øolute power; and what the Prince plea≈øeth is his Prerogative, and this was a≈ø≈øuredly aymed at here.

Now Prerogative, according to the ≈øtrict Rule, is of two ≈øorts, that is, more, or le≈øs ≈øtrict; as for example, ≈øome Prerogatives primarily u≈øurped, by time are agreed to, and after con≈øtituted, ≈øuch as our va≈ø≈øalage of Tenures, whether in Capite, or that by grand or petite Serj. E≈øcuage, Knights Service, Soccage, or Villenage; all which the e≈øtates of the Nation have looked upon, and not annulled, but regulated, and the Kings ≈øought to avoid tho≈øe Regulations.

Now the more ≈øtrict Rule of Prerogative, is, to give the dues nece≈ø≈øary, and that both for honour, and order, and ≈øafety, which both the other are but as handmaids to; for the etymologicall fautaries, I pa≈øs them, intending to hold out truth in her native ≈øimplicity, without the ammu≈øive garni≈øh of needle≈øs witty vanities.

This then agreed, what Prerogative is in general, from hence it may be collected, that what ever is nece≈ø≈øary, or rather of nece≈ø≈øity, to the well being of the whole, is to be in the Supream Power: Now this which is by ≈øome, and generally alledged as proper to Kings, yet mu≈øt be al≈øo in all Supream Magi≈øtrates, as Dukes, Earls, &c. yea though Va≈ø≈øals or Tributaries to other Princes, and mu≈øt be al≈øo in Republiques, or where the ≈øupremacy of power re≈øts in more then one per≈øon, whether Ari≈øtocratical, Oligargichal, or the pure Republique, viz. the Democratique State.

For the Prerogative is incident naturally to the Supremacy of power, and that of nece≈ø≈øity; for they are the Superintendents of the whole body, and are to have requi≈øites to that Office, as nece≈ø≈øarily as the father of a Family or any inferiour Magi≈øtrate under him ought to have, to govern in their bounds, precincts, limits and places; and therefore the Law of England ju≈øtly in the matter (however in the attribute, or that to admit compari≈øon with the Almighty, might or may offend ≈øome mens eares) by way of illu≈øtrative Analogy, gave a kind of ubiquity or omnipre≈øence to the King, and ≈øo to the ≈øupream Magi≈øtrate, as the fir≈øt part of his Prerogative, his diffu≈øed power (for common good ≈øo ordered) manife≈øting it ≈øelf in all Offices whereby the publick peace (≈øo called the Kings peace) was pre≈øerved, and was nece≈ø≈øary every where.
But as more nece≈ø≈øary, ≈øo more apparent in the Courts of Ju≈øtice, all of which were called the Kings Courts, and the Proce≈øs the Kings, &c.

Now we being ruled by Laws; for to avoid the inconveniencies afore-mentioned of pu≈øillage and folly, and alterations accidental to the be≈øt of men depraved, through the fall, make this ≈øupream power vertually to re≈øt in ≈øetled Laws, and by them they rule, and ≈øo neither death, folly, nor any kind of wrong, or injury, can by the e≈øtimation of Law be done or ≈øuffered by the ≈øupremacy of power, ≈øo that truly the Law ≈øaith, the King can do no wrong, that is, the Law by the ≈øupremacy of power, enables him not to do wrong; and to ≈øpeak out the whole truth, to men of the meane≈øt under≈øtanding; This law, and the right under≈øtanding and executing of it, is the highe≈øt Prerogative of any of Gods Vicegerents, in higher or lower ≈øphears, and is the agreed Rule of common good, as before-≈øaid.

Now our great error and delu≈øion of late was to give that to the per≈øon, which was due to the Office, and to ≈øubjugate the Office to the per≈øon, and not the per≈øon to the Office, which the Law would never admit; for the Law, that is the purity, yea, tan≈øcendencie of Rea≈øon, leaves the per≈øon of the Prince naked, in ca≈øe of Male Action, though it cen≈øures not in all male admini≈øtration, where it admits him po≈øitively to judge.

I ≈øhall give you an example to illu≈øtrate; for if the King enters a mans hou≈øe di≈øgui≈øed, and offers to vitiate his wife, daughter, &c. and be ≈ølain of the father, husband, &c. it is but as the death of an ordinary per≈øon; and truly by the principles of the ≈øetled Law be he known, it is no more.

I ≈øhall put but one Example more; A Traytor is by vertue of the Kings Writ, brought before the Judge, Arraigned, and Condemned; the King grants no pardon, (which I ≈øuppo≈øe he in ≈øuch Ca≈øes cannot generally, though it was done cu≈øtomarily) nor u≈øes no legal peaceably way, but by force per≈øonal ≈øets him≈øelf in Act by his Guard to take this Traytor out of the hands of that Ju≈øtice to which in his Politick capacity he hath Sentenced him; and the Sheriffs men defending the Law; and the Guard by the per≈øonal command of the King, ≈øeeking the overthrow of it, by taking away illegally the pri≈øoner; and they fighting about it, and the King running in, he is ≈ølain, it is no murder by the principles of the Law, which owns not the King in this Act of Tort and Force, and takes no notice of the death of that per≈øon as King, who in Law dies not; for the Law cannot now take notice of it, becau≈øe out of his Sphear; by this it is evident to what end the Magi≈øtrate is cloathed with ≈øo called Prerogative, namely the advance of publike intere≈øt.

Now, as in this ≈øort, it gives to the ≈øupream Magi≈øtrate the glory of the Courts of Ju≈øtice, and the di≈øpo≈øings of them, as one part of Prerogative; ≈øo knowing the honor of the Supream Power cannot be maintained but by ≈øome ≈øet way, as it ≈øeems the Ancients provided here, ≈øo much of all ≈øorts of provi≈øion, both for the Kings Family, as al≈øo for his Stable, at the ≈øo called Kings price exceedingly abu≈øed, be≈øides the ≈øo called ≈øetled revenues of the Crown, namely Crown lands, Fee-Farm Rents, &c. So it al≈øo provided for Emergencies, and that both for charges upon the ≈øea, and al≈øo for the land by Cu≈øtoms now ≈øo called, Fines, Forfeitures, (wrecks of the ≈øea how unju≈øtly ≈øoever) land de≈øerted of the ≈øea, lands of Ideots, Trea≈øure found, goods without owners, Tythes of lands out of Pari≈øhes, and the like: And upon the≈øe, or any other matter, if any debt did accrue, it was ≈øatisfied to the King, (that the Commonwealth might not lo≈øe) before any private per≈øon could be ≈øatisfied one penny, (the abu≈øe of this was grown intolerable, but I here treat of Settlements) and how long ≈øince it was
in the Kings ca≈øe it matters not; for no ≈ølipping of time could prejudice the Kings Title, as in ca≈øe of a common per≈øon, who was tied to ≈øue within ≈øuch a time, or the time might be pleaded in Bar as was ju≈øtly enacted.

Now the rea≈øon of this was ju≈øt and good, preferring publike and univer≈øal good before private and particular; yet this proved offen≈øive oft-times, becau≈øe it was made the in≈øtrument to ab≈øolute Inju≈øtice, while re≈øtitution was made to the King, to the evident de≈øtruction of a ≈øtranger, that is a third per≈øon whom the Law left remedile≈øs, yea though utterly undone, and begging from door to door.

It was al≈øo for the ≈øame rea≈øon con≈øtrued to be Law, that in all Grants made by the King, they ≈øhould be taken mo≈øt beneficially for him; and that they ≈øhould not erre to any other con≈øtruction then what was manife≈øted in the body of the Grant, that is, the plain letter mu≈øt be taken, and no implicite con≈øtruction of Law ≈øhall be taken advantage of, again≈øt the good of the Commonwealth, as again≈øt a particular party.

And la≈øtly, In ca≈øe of Grants it is void, if it appears that the King was deceived in his Grant; truth, the≈øe originally ju≈øt things, after the fatall wi≈ødom of the Law was politickly perfected, came to be made the My≈øtery of Iniquity; for it was ≈øaid, the Grants were made according to the≈øe received Rules for the Kings ≈øole benefit, whereby he that was once made the Kings Officer, was ever after ≈øcandalized for a Knave; and he that was once the Kings Farmor, Grantee, or Debitor, his e≈øtate was alwayes after e≈øteemed incombred.

Now this was more feared when it was granted to him by Judgement of the Judges, that he in Temporals might by a Clau≈øe of Non ob≈øtante, di≈øpence with any Statute Law; and that though the Statute ≈øaith ≈øuch di≈øpen≈øations ≈øhould be utterly void, as it was in the time of Henry the ≈øeventh; the beginning was in Edward the fourth, not ≈øo plain; Acts of Parliament bind not the King unle≈øs e≈øpecially named.

Now the≈øe unhinged all our Liberties; for by the one he was not bound except named; and by the ≈øecond he might di≈øpence how-ever named; therefore the≈øe, how ever u≈øed, I cannot reckon as legal Prerogative.

I now proceed with Prerogative called Ju≈øt; that is, That the King, or Supream Power for the benefit of the Commonwealth, have the e≈øtates of tho≈øe that die without heir; for no private or particular heir being, the publike is rightly preferred; ≈øo if they purcha≈øe who have no right, as Aliens; they have al≈øo given him tho≈øe Royal Mines of gold and ≈øilver, le≈øt ≈øuch things in Subjects ≈øhould rai≈øe them ≈øo high, as they ≈øhould be able by leavying Arms, to conte≈øt for the Supremacy, and attempt a Tyranny.

Now this, if agreed, as agreed, is mo≈øt ju≈øt; They gave him ≈øome honorary re≈øpects meerly; as for example; That the Lord ≈øhould not ≈øei≈øe his Villein in his pre≈øence; how ju≈øtly, may well be Quaeried.

For if ju≈øt to be done, why not more ju≈øt before him? To which may be added, That Amerciaments, Fines, &c. which had no exact literal Rule, as offences made by Statute puni≈øhable by the Ju≈øtices at Se≈ø≈øions with unlimited Fine or Amerciaments, were ≈øaid to be by vertue of his Prerogative as his Iu≈øtices, that is, they were to Fine at di≈øcretion, that is, according to the nature of the fact, re≈øpect had to the Law; that is, ≈øaving his Freehold, or not to the value of his Freehold; or ≈øo that he ≈øhould not for to pay that Fine be put to ≈øell his Freehold; all which are argued for, with much nicety, little Chri≈øtianity.

Now as for the benefit of the Commonwealth the Law put the King into po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of others (though by matter of Record) ≈øo it kept him in the State of the Commonwealth; for, for Lands Jure per≈øonae, or hereditary at Common Law, the rule of Law extends not to it, as I conceive; therefore the King cannot be di≈ø≈øei≈øed; and many other ≈øuch things, as the goods of Felons, murderers, &c. which is, or may be ju≈øt in murder in ≈øome ≈øort (but in no ca≈øe in Felony, but they ought to go to the per≈øon wronged) and in man≈ølaughter, and defence of a mans own per≈øon, there ought to be no right to the Checkquer, not in the Self-defence at all; and in the others it ought to go to the party; for if the Law in forceable ≈øtrikeing give dammage, and more in wounding, and more in Maihem, then mo≈øt in killing, where the life of the criminal is ≈øaved.

That of Deodands is in the Law; and I ≈øee no warrant for it, but the meer allu≈øive
equity of the Judicial: It is al≈øo ≈øaid to be a part of the Kings Prerogative to have ≈øpecial Iudges to try the right of his revenues as is the Checkquer; and the differences of his immediate Officers and ≈øervants, as the Steward and Mar≈øhal of his hou≈øe; and in≈øtead of Action again≈øt his per≈øon, The Law by the Ordinance of Edward the third, for honor ≈øake, framed it in nature of a Petition; but the Proce≈øs was as again≈øt an other per≈øon; and ≈øo if Iu≈øtice be upon that, it is ju≈øt, otherwi≈øe not; it will al≈øo admit no wager of Law again≈øt him, and which proved a great abu≈øe, and was unju≈øt; and is no way either honorary or nece≈ø≈øary; he did take men under pretence of being his debitors, into his protection to the overthrow of many particular per≈øons and univer≈øal detriment; thus was Derogative.
Again, Judgment was never final again≈øt him, but with a figmentitious advantagious eva≈øion of a ≈øaving his right; and this was al≈øo new and not nece≈ø≈øary.

I come to two main and principal ≈øteps to the eminency of Prerogative, alwayes afforded the Supream power; which are, fir≈øt, That the King hath by his publike tru≈øt, power to do what≈øoever there is no Law again≈øt; So that from hence hath ari≈øen the ob≈øtructions to Laws upon new Cau≈øes; namely, ≈øetling that in the Law which was before in the King; and ≈øo abridging the Royal Tenure: By vertue of this he created Corporations, and made Denizens.

The other was (from Gods appointment to Mo≈øes ≈øurely) to appoint places, ≈øo called, of Priviledge, like Cities of Refuge; but undoubtedly this was a civility betwixt the Kings and Popes, to rai≈øe a benefit to the King, by priviledging: That Charter had many Fees, and then the Pope made it by allowance a Sanctuary, and ≈øo ≈øecured by both powers; what can be doubted? that mu≈øt be ju≈øt where Mo≈øes and Aaron joyn; and the≈øe men, both Pope and Prince did well, they ≈øaved the life, but ≈øquei≈øed the pur≈øe; and none affoord ≈øuch milke more freely then Rogues and Whores, as all Hi≈øtories evidence.

This is the ≈øumm of all the Prerogative ≈øo called; that I in this ha≈øte remember, ju≈øt, or unju≈øt, that the Laws of England hold forth. The three main pillars upon which the Edifice of Prerogative ≈øtands, all the≈øe being but the Ornaments thereto, are the ab≈øolute power to make Laws, War and Peace, and rai≈øe moneys.

Except in ≈øome few ≈øcattered judgements, ari≈øing upon Emergencies, and are not indeed worthy the name of Prerogative, though in our Topical heads of Laws, they be ≈øo ranked, but rather priviledges or Royalties; many of which were obtained by Subjects; for what a Subject may enjoy I count not Prerogative; therefore not Copning of money, &c. nor Royal fi≈øhes, nor a hundred matters of the like nature; and wreck is generally dete≈øtable, and the Royalty of grandage abominable; but the generalty of them are ju≈øtly belonging to all men with the Supream Maje≈øty, e≈øpecially tho≈øe favors of errors in pleadings, &c.

Now this Legi≈ølative power was never in the King, nor no rea≈øon it ≈øhould; which alone ≈øhews the Kings in England never was ≈øince the e≈øtabli≈øhment of the three e≈øtates the Supream power; for the makeing of Laws was alwayes ≈øince in them, as the body Repre≈øentative of the Nation, and ≈øo the Lords and Commons were put as a Bar to invading Prerogative.

Next for war or peace, it was not in the Kings power; his Knights were bound according to their Tenures, but not otherwayes; and the ≈øpecial of them not performing their ≈øervice, were to be fined nowhere but in Parliament. The la≈øt of them which are the ≈øinews of the war, were always in the peoples hands, never denyed by any King, however ≈øubtilly obtruded upon, as by loans, privy Seals, &c. which were always declaimed again≈øt, and damned by Parliaments.

The≈øe were and are nece≈ø≈øary to the Supream Power, but never tru≈øted to Englands Kings, a ≈øure ≈øign the Supremacy was not in the King; he knew it nece≈ø≈øary to aggrandize his power, and for an ab≈øolute ≈øubjection of all intere≈øts to his, to claim that the≈øe were incident and appendixes to the Supremacy ab≈øolute, which he a≈øpired unto.

And though the Forts, Ships, Magazines, and appointing Judges, Governors, Captains, &c. were actually in his power; yet hereby it is plainly ≈øeen to what end, and how trayterous they were to the then true Engli≈øh Intere≈øts, who ≈øtuck to the King again≈øt the Parliament in this war; but that controver≈øie is be≈øides my task here.

Therefore I proceed, and ≈øay that it is nece≈ø≈øary ≈øtill, that the total and ab≈øolute Supremacy hath the≈øe powers, viz. of making or giving forth Laws, making Leagues
offen≈øive and defen≈øive, denouncing Wars, and e≈øtabli≈øhing Peace, and al≈øo to rai≈øe moneys.

Now this I know not denied by any publike and approved Judgement; but the≈øe men have their bounds, their limits al≈øo; for general, common and publike good, is their limit, their chain, and to ≈øee the end of this, it is fit next to ≈øee

div.head: 12. Who is Judge of publike good, and his Rule of Re≈øtraint? and whether it be fit to admit this ab≈øolutely in the Supream Power?
div.p: THe Kings formerly were not unskilled in the i≈ø≈øue of this my≈øtery, they boulted out what others will bake, who ever eats it.

Now it is plain, this al≈øo is required in the Supream Power; for it is impo≈ø≈øible to ≈øettle particular Laws, ≈øutable to each particular occa≈øion; for in the corrupt ≈øtate of man, as the Law is profitable or di≈øprofitable, ≈øo it is relli≈øhed; as for example, in an equal rate, the ju≈øt man likes the equality, and ≈øo doth the covetous; but he ≈øaith, no rate at all; and if an hone≈øt Mi≈øer can be, he approves equality, but he repines at the payment.

Now the boundary is evident publike good, and of this in the manife≈øt parts of it are all men Iudges; for though in tran≈øactions of the high affairs of State, the progre≈ø≈øion may not be fit to be made publike, yet the winding up as it is evident, ≈øo the rea≈øons of that i≈ø≈øue, may, as ≈øome conceive, fitly be accounted of, at lea≈øt to ≈øome ≈øpecially appointed, who are to be impowred to that particular end, as the Ephori or Spartan Court, who judged their Kings Actions, the Tribunes at Rome, and Democratie at Athens.

To this it is an≈øwered, That the condition of the Commonwealth, where the Rulers and Law givers are tran≈øient and per≈øonal, are naturally inclined to more equality in di≈øpen≈øations then Kings, who wholly labour to bring all to the power of their Succe≈ø≈øors, Princes like them; but the ≈øons of the other are like to be under government.

The other reply, that with all men pre≈øent intere≈øt works; and power pre≈øent may if not bound and limited, prove obnoxious, and for private re≈øpects, neglect publike profit in the Republike, as in the Monarchick State; for all are men; nay, experience hath manife≈øted, that many Senators have been corrupted, to the betraying their e≈øtates to the Empire of a Foreigner; never yet a King, but to a≈ø≈øure his Kingdom, and ≈øo he was not corrupted.

The other return that the≈øe accidents of the world do not at all conclude more then what was done; The ambition of mo≈øt Princes hath made them true to them≈øelves, and the Covetize of ≈øome Senators made them fal≈øe to their Country.

But the Que≈øtion here is onely of the ab≈øolute judgement of the Supream Power, and that is concluded po≈øitively to re≈øt there in all dubious matters mo≈øt unque≈øtionably; but for matters de≈øtructive to common good, or to common Ju≈øtice, or again≈øt Rea≈øon, they are allowed to be accountable.

Yet it is again replied the≈øe were the boundaries before to Kings, and are the boundaries to all Powers; all have generally broken in all ≈øorts of Governments; the examples of ≈øubmi≈ø≈øive accounting Supreams are rare; one was found in Rome, and one in Greece; and to finde two more in all the world is difficult; for who as the≈øe will be buried, and have their daughters married of the publike pur≈øe, when they have the Trea≈øures of a Nation in their di≈øpo≈øe, and may benefit them≈øelves much with little or no hindrance to the State? Pitty it is, the inju≈øtice of great men ≈øhould give ≈øuch cau≈øe of ≈øu≈øpition; and folly were it while men may, not to ≈øet a bound; and not to ≈øet it in the fir≈øt ≈øetlements, makes the propo≈øal for the future difficult, the e≈øtabli≈øhment dangerous: Therefore they propound, that the Law be e≈øtabli≈øhed as agreeable to the light of Nature, examples of other States, continued experience, and not again≈øt divine in≈øtitution.
The wi≈øe and ju≈øt man will ≈øubmit to that in him≈øelf which he holds requi≈øite to require from an other.

The Parliament of England allowed the King a Judgement of the nece≈ø≈øity, but not che ≈øole Judgement, but that was becau≈øe the Supremacy was not ab≈øolutely in him; and all held fit not to ve≈øt ab≈øolutely Supremacy anywhere but in Law; ≈øo that untill e≈øtabli≈øhed by Law, the matter is in que≈øtion.

And though the time pa≈øt when the Legi≈ølative power depended upon the Kings will and plea≈øure, by his calling or not calling Parliaments as he plea≈øed, there might be ≈øome difficulty to ≈øettle dubious matters; yet that Bar broken, where can a let be, unle≈øs we convert our mercy into a judgement?

Upon all this it is plain that there are many difficulties in the nature of Prerogative, whereby to under≈øtand it clearly and truly. All States, that is, the Supremacy of power, do labor naturally to advance the ≈øo called Prerogative.

And the people generally ayme as much at liberty, but Kings mo≈øt, and they more ≈øpecially where the Crowns go by way of ≈øucce≈ø≈øion; for the great part of per≈øonal Prerogative of a King dyes in a State, except the Supream power will continue it (but then it is requi≈øite in ≈øuch an alteration to ≈øettle ju≈øtly, and remedy fore-experienced and evidently fore≈øeen evils) therefore it is requi≈øite that the continued complaints of men, e≈øpecially again≈øt the Kings Butlers, the Clerks of the Pipe, Chequer, &c. in their fees be ≈øetled; for the paying and gaining of a Quietus upon a duty to the King, is almo≈øt as much in Fees as the Rent it ≈øelf. Now I come to ≈øee

div.head: 13. Whether the Supream power can grant the inferiour Prerogatives, ≈øuch as Wreck, Forfeitures of Felons, Royal Fi≈øhes, Trea≈øure, Trove, &c. and How?
div.p: NOw for this, it is plain, fir≈øt that the Kings have done it, and the≈øe honours were never denyed; for, for mo≈øt of them, generally the charge of obtaining, was as much to the Crown as the thing it ≈øelf; Therefore whereas they had Officers and Offices in every County, attended upon every Court, and ≈øome ≈øpecial Courts for Sea matters: The Kings did give the≈øe as rewards to their Nobles, and great men, within ≈øpecial Precincts, where in the primitive ≈øettlement of the Nation, their dwellings were, and ≈øo he was di≈øcharged of his Officers, and the due Courts were let down, and the Tryals were reduced all to his Court of Admiralty, which as in all ca≈øes, was, and is, a burthen intolerable to the Subject, and to all impoveri≈øhed per≈øons Ju≈øtice is by this turned into Gall and Vinegar, e≈øpecially to di≈øtre≈ø≈øed per≈øons by Sea; for the poor people all along the Coa≈øt, are like ≈øo many Harpyes; wreck or no wreck, all that comes to their net is fi≈øh; and thus to ≈øave a little charge, we are infinitely inhumane; but by this it is plain, all but the power of making Laws, war and peace, levying Moneys, and ≈øome ≈øay Royal Mines, are grantable by the Supream Power.
Provided that due means of Tryal of Right be pre≈øerved for the publique benefit; otherwayes not.

Some ≈øay, that this is generally true, that is, the Supream Magi≈øtrate hath power in all Laws meerly Civil; but in ca≈øes religious, or wherein properly the con≈øcience may, ≈øome ≈øay does ≈øcruple, the Magi≈øtrates power cea≈øes; therefore it is fit to look a little at that, and quaere,

div.head: 14. Whether the Magi≈øtrate be Keeper of both the Tables ≈øo called?
div.p: THey who make this controver≈øie, are not pre≈øently to be thought enemies to Magi≈øtrates, nor enviers of Mini≈øterial Dignity.

Some have admitted the Popes Primacy, who have denyed his Supremacy; others have given Princes all power; ≈øome a Negative, but not an Affirmative power in ≈øo called Eccle≈øia≈øticks or Church matters; others take away the Popes Primacy; for they take him away, equalizing all Pa≈øtors, and that that ≈øpeciall de≈øignation befits no earthly per≈øon; others bind up the Magi≈øtrates hands wholly; ≈øome by denying Magi≈øtracie; others by re≈øtraining him wholly to the name of Civils, not ≈øufficiently caring for (by a≈ø≈øured and preventive means) tho≈øe errors which have heretofore clouded the excellency of Magi≈øtracie by the pride of Churchmen.
For were inherent holine≈øs vi≈øibly and ≈øetledly, and ≈øo infallibly tyed to either of the≈øe, the Supremacy were determined; but while they are all men, they mu≈øt have their bounds and limits.

Yet in the Kingdomes of the world, the Prince mu≈øt bear ≈øway, and hath the preheminence; The Heathens in glory of the Prince annexed the Prie≈øtly Office to the Superior Power, not the Kings to the Prie≈øts; and under Gods Law, Mo≈øes was Aarons Prince or Father, Aaron Mo≈øes Prophet.
Next the Civil part of Judicature was ever, and now is clear and manife≈øt, except where intere≈øt or humour prevails, and let that humour alone, and it is ready to ≈øwarm into intere≈øt immediatly.
But this you will ≈øay determines the fir≈øt part of the Que≈øtion, but the latter is undetermined.

To that it is generally an≈øwered, that what power is nece≈ø≈øary for the pre≈øervation of the peace of the Nation or Government, is proper to the Supream Magi≈øtrate; but an obliging power, that is, that ≈øimple obedience is to be given to his determination of but dubious matters in points of either Doctrine or pure Church-Di≈øcipline, I beleeve never was nor will be yielded to him, in matters circum≈øtantially Religious; otherwi≈øe barely civil, was, as generally agreed, and will not now be denyed, as concerning the time of Congregating, the place, and other Circum≈øtantials for pre≈øervation of the peace of Church and Commonwealth; yea, if it were upon good rea≈øon, the number that were to congregate, provided there were enough to con≈øtitute a Congregation, might be ≈øet by the Supream Magi≈øtrate, and Chri≈øtians bound to obey; but this is only as keeper of the fir≈øt Table, not of the ≈øecond.

Now to clear this, it is to be known, that if it be taken to be the Keeper of the two Tables, ≈øo called, to promote by all lawful means the glory of God, as the good of men, as all good and ju≈øt Magi≈øtrates will and ought, yea if it be by preaching him≈øelf, or them≈øelves, and that either by word or Doctrine as good life, they and all Chri≈øtians are the keepers of both Tables, and he or they as ≈øupream in power, and ≈øo as more entru≈øted with means by God, to do mo≈øt for God, then he or they who have the ≈øupremacy, are by way of eminency the ≈øpecial keepers of them, but that they are de≈øigned more e≈øpecially to repre≈øent either the Kingly, Prie≈øtly, or Prophetical Office of the Lord Chri≈øt as head of his Church, without the manife≈øt tokens of more e≈øpecial Grace and divine Revelation, whereby to periodize the Controver≈øies of their own Subjects, holding forth to us under the ≈øame rule the will of God as the Prie≈øts under the Law, is not ea≈øily di≈øcerned, nor will I beleeve be ≈øtrenuou≈øly urged.

The ble≈ø≈øings which our Lord and Saviour held forth, were meerly tending to his ≈øpiritual Kingdome, and the propagating of it, and given out to the Apo≈øtles, and in them to all the Church, as mo≈øt ≈øutable to not onely rea≈øon generally, but the rea≈øon of that our King in his Tran≈øactions among≈øt them; of this enough at pre≈øent. I come now to the la≈øt Quaere of the Prerogative of Princes.

div.head: 14. Whether Male Admini≈øtration doth ip≈øo facto dethrone Princes, and give their Subjects power to depo≈øe them?
15. And whether Kings and other Supreams may be puni≈øhed, by whom, and how?
div.p: THis is a great & weighty controver≈øie; truly Magi≈øtrates that de≈øire to be flattered, ≈øtand off, you can hear nothing ≈øafely; for your ≈øafety is your danger; Now what we have ≈øaid before, tends much to the illu≈øtration of this point, that is, the due con≈øideration of the end for which Magi≈øtracie is ordained, (for by the Law of pure Naturals no one is above another) namely the pre≈øerving few again≈øt many, weak again≈øt ≈øtrong, and right again≈øt wrong, in Scripture phra≈øe to be a terror to the evil; and to that end not to wear the Sword in vain; ≈øo that while evils are or may be, Magi≈øtracie is nece≈ø≈øary to be.

Now generally the defects and failings of Governors in them≈øelves, are not ≈øimply and alone a cau≈øe of neglect of obedience to them, or the Laws by them; for evil men may be good Magi≈øtrates; but in ca≈øe the Magi≈øtrate ≈øeeks to overthrow
laws, and all Righteous Government, altering or cro≈ø≈øing wholly the end of his ordination; it is in this ca≈øe clear he is not a Magi≈øtrate, but he is a Tyrant, an u≈øurper, an Enemy to Ju≈øtice; but then it is beleeved by ≈øome, that the light or interpretation of this defection is in every man, and ≈øo each man judges, and may ju≈øtly withdraw obedience and oppo≈øe. This is gro≈øs ignorance; no then every unju≈øt man puni≈øhed, would be ready to rebell, and mi≈øcall his deficiency Revenge of injury to the publique.

The Pope by the evill management among Princes of this quarrel, brought the deci≈øion of all the≈øe controver≈øies to his Tribunal, and by the ≈øteps of ≈øeeming ju≈øtice, mounted the Chayre of Antichri≈øt; for he finding that the Ambition, Pride, Lu≈øt, Covetize of earthly gods, had rai≈øed up men again≈øt them, and that many halings and pullings were, between the Princes and Potentates of the earth and their Subjects, the one to have all the power in their own hands, the others to defend what they called ≈øometimes Priviledges, ≈øometimes ju≈øt Rights; one while the inheritance of their Ance≈øtors, as what they had contended for and delivered to them, ≈øealed with their blood; otherwhile their proper and natural birthright, as dues to the people, which no Power or U≈øurpation of a Prince could dive≈øt them of; he politickly holding forth the nece≈ø≈øity of an Umpire, got ab≈øolutely into the Chayr of preheminence, and depo≈øed Kings for plea≈øure, and Kings and Emperors and all for his profit.

Who would beleeve, that now after five thou≈øand years experience, the world ≈øhould not be able to unriddle this my≈øtery? the ≈øource of all our controver≈øies is the Judicials not rightly under≈øtood; for a≈ø≈øuredly, the Acts of their Kings is no rule for us or ours; we are to follow them no further then they follow the light, which God gives us all to walk by, that is, if you will look at their King, it mu≈øt be as bounded, not as imitating the Kings of the Nations, as not exalting him≈øelf over his brethren, not as taking away the excellent young men and beautiful Maidens to be his ≈øervants; and if ≈øo that he be under a Rule, then he is not to rule, not onely not evilly, but not ≈øo well as he pre≈øumes he might, unle≈øs it be made parcell of his Rule.
But if he breaks this Rule, who ≈øhall enforce?

Now in this ca≈øe it is plain, that a Prince, Ruler, or inferiour Magi≈øtrate, doing greater good then his Rule limits, is in an error, e≈øpecially if opportunity were of having that enacted into a Law; for men are men; and to do ≈øo, opens a door of jealou≈øie 'twixt him and his people.

Next it ≈øtands as a pre≈øident to his Succe≈ø≈øor; La≈øtly, it ab≈øolutely intimates either a neglect of the Law, or ≈øeeking freedom by degrees from it; but if this were evill or detrimental, what remedy?

To clear this, there mu≈øt be a difference taken betwixt things partly de≈øtructive to the end of well reigning, and wholly; for unle≈øs wholly de≈øtructive, threatning the whole community, there is no cau≈øe evident; but grant it ≈øo, we mu≈øt then ≈øee whether the Prince be an ab≈øolute Monarch or limited; If ab≈øolute, then it i ‚Ä¢ the greater difficulty; for there being no barr in ≈øuch ca≈øes, betwixt the Prince and lu≈øt, the deci≈øion of the difference mu≈øt be by the whole community, at lea≈øt the greater part; and if they break out, wo to the Commonwealth, &c. It is the difficulty to do ju≈øt things in ≈øuch extremities, not the inju≈øtice of the thing puts ≈øo many barrs in the way; and the evil truly is ≈øo great, that prudence hath totally waved a liberty of ≈øuch judgings, finding the dear rate Liberty is in ≈øuch ca≈øes purcha≈øed at.

But ≈øome Princes have by renewed Tyrannies, tru≈øting to their power, enforced the multitude to la≈øh out, and great men for ≈øafetie to head them; but when matters come to this pa≈øs, it is ≈øurely a judgement on both ≈øides.

Now all Chri≈øtian Princes held this, that they being all Typed out by the Judicials, they for≈øooth were ab≈øolute Princes, anoynted with holy Oyle, and ≈øo apply all the Texts of Davids not daring to ≈øtretch out his hand again≈øt Saul, his heart ≈ømiting for cutting off the lap of his garment, hindering Abi≈øhai from killing him in his Tent; yet agreeing, the Lord had delivered him into his hand, and that after the Kingdom rent from him, and given by God to him≈øelf, and he with holy Oyle al≈øo anoynted.

And la≈øtly, for his ≈ølaying the Amalekite, who pretended to have killed Saul ahis reque≈øt, to them≈øelves, as anointed, &c. and upon this they get the heart to trangre≈øs Laws at liberty, and even do what they lu≈øted, yea inverted the ju≈øt ends of univer≈øal good, for the enhan≈øig of ab≈øolute power to their own ends only, neglecting the publike, claiming propriety in the Rights of the Nation, as in private inheritance, though truly to that end alone any power ab≈øolute or limited cannot be pretended to.

To which it is generally an≈øwered, That they who have the power ab≈øolute, and can puni≈øh, have no rule but prudence, in enlarging or re≈øtraining them; they generally u≈øed bani≈øhment; but this in ≈øucce≈ø≈øive or hereditary alterations, upon the ≈øame ground of prudence, cannot be ≈øafe; therefore ≈øome have immured them, and ≈øtarved them, ≈øome impri≈øoned them, ≈øome cloy≈øtered them, ≈øome privately murthered them; but all the≈øe were acts of pure power and force, and left but an implicite con≈øtruction of Ju≈øtice on their actions.

Our new and unparallelled Tran≈øaction doth I know to many ≈øeem Heroick; and if e≈øtabli≈øhed by Law, upon this pre≈øident, would be an admirable adventure, to hold an aw upon the ≈øpirits of great men; and to that end, they de≈øire the explanation of the ≈øupream (power or) Magi≈øtrates Tru≈øts, and in what ca≈øes‚ñ™ it ≈øhall be lawful to arraign them, with the ≈øame legal provi≈øions as King Charls tyed his own hands in the Act for a Triennial Parliament; but I leave treating of this, le≈øt I grate to no purpo≈øe. I come now to ≈øee

div.head: 16. What are the Priviledges of Parliaments, and in them of the Bars to the Supream Power?
div.p: FIr≈øt, we mu≈øt con≈øider, that the≈øe meetings are according to the Rule of pure Native Law, by the advice of many, and tho≈øe duly elected out of the people, to avoid confu≈øion, to take care for the ≈øettlement of all tho≈øe errors, which intervening time produced ≈øince ≈øuch an A≈ø≈øembly la≈øt Congregated; and that both as to the Actions (of the King in his Officers, where the King was held unque≈øtionable, and therefore which was unju≈øt in ≈øome part, his ≈øervants were puni≈øhed) of the higher Magi≈øtrates, and inferior Subjects, either in a legal way, according to the ordinary con≈øtitution of the Nation, or extraordinary in ca≈øe of emergencies, for which no Law was provided.

The examples are manife≈øt in both; Now the priviledges of the≈øe men were, and ought ≈øo to be whereever ≈øuch bars are, fir≈øt (that the due right of the ≈øubject might be pre≈øerved) that tho≈øe who were to be of the Parliament were duly cho≈øen, that is, neither by fear nor favor, which was from either open force, or private warnings or reque≈øts to the friends or dependants of great m ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ , which were commands, (which how broken and ≈øtill are even by Reformers them≈øelves to their ≈øhame not of Reformation is evident.)

The next priviledge is, that being cho≈øen, they being now of ≈øpecial u≈øe and imployment for the publick, them≈øelves, hor≈øes, goods, and menial ≈øervants, were priviledged from Arre≈øts, di≈øtre≈ø≈øes, &c. and only they, (for the law of entertaining by giving protections was a di≈øpriviledge of the common Subjects, for who≈øe ≈øake only they were priviledged) and no more (that other being but a meer Royal corruption, by degrees to make them all ≈øeekers of intere≈øts, upon that ba≈øe Maxime that tru≈øts were to their own benefit.)

The next was, to have free liberty to chu≈øe their Speaker, who was not to be di≈øallowed but upon good Cau≈øe, and that Cau≈øe they were Judges of; for all ≈øee el≈øe, the vanity of the formality, if the approbation be upon meer will; for then there is the
power of Election, and this Speaker they may al≈øo upon good Cau≈øe put out, by the Votes of the greater number.

The next priviledge is, That they have a free liberty to treate of all matters; the a≈ø≈øembling by Kings Writ, the being called his great Councel, are honors of Time, and formal, and cannot abridge their nece≈ø≈øary liberty of free Treaty, &c.

But their power appears, in that they had the Guardian≈øhip of the peoples Lives, Liberties and E≈øtates; and though in the variety of changes, they did as all mortal Powers do, ≈øometimes ≈øubmit, ≈øometimes inforce, as the condition of Times were; we mu≈øt u≈øe a true foot, and a≈øcribe no more to them then is needful, not plead pre≈øidents, but Supream rea≈øon, by which they therefore might and ought, during the forty dayes Se≈ø≈øion, a convenient time (which by convention ≈øeems the time ≈øet, during which the King could not di≈ø≈øolve them) to receive Petitions from all places, by turning them≈øelves into Committees, and hear how matters went with the Nation, upon ≈øuch Repre≈øentations, from the particular Counties, Cities, and Town therein, addre≈ø≈øed to the particular Members, cho≈øen by them for the aid of the whole Nation; and upon the≈øe, to call ≈øome ≈øay the Kings, all agree all the Kings Officers of all ≈øorts to their Accounts, as Trea≈øurers, and that both for Land and Sea; yea Officers of Peace, as all Iudges, &c. and of War, as General, or Lord Mar≈øhal, or by what other name, or names on Land; or Admiral, or &c. at Sea, Captains of Forts; and all others, who managed the Revenues, ≈øo called, of the Crown, that is for the publike benefit; and this power is coincedent to every Bar to Supremacy.

And truely where this is not, it is ea≈øie to believe the Supream Maje≈øty may ≈øoon pretend all is intru≈øted to his own Will, and for his particular benefit: then they may adjudge, and ≈øentence, but not in Committees, but in the whole hou≈øe; otherwi≈øe there is no legal proceeding, and really and purely; this did, and was to re≈øt principally in the Repre≈øentatives of the people, who are the Commons, (the ≈øeparation of the Hou≈øes as with us, and the ≈øingle power of the Lords to Iudge, the Commons to accu≈øe, yet one Court, is much differing from excellent Rea≈øon, if not contrary to it) that ≈øo right might be done to the whole Commonwealth, again≈øt the out-breakings of the King, and al≈øo to every particular per≈øon by re≈øtitution again≈øt the wrong doer; yea, though by the Kings Command, or Commi≈ø≈øion, if not agreeable to the Law.
Now the limited times of Parliament were nece≈ø≈øary, le≈øt otherwayes they ≈øhould abu≈øe their Power, or u≈øurp Supremacy ab≈øolute, and al≈øo become de≈øperate debtors, becau≈øe of priviledge.

And la≈øtly, that while being men and capable of erring, their fal≈øe judgements, if any were, may be rectified by a new; for it was, and mu≈øt be the priviledge of the≈øe highe≈øt Courts, not to have ought done there by any of the Members que≈øtioned in any other Court, onely Trea≈øon, Felony, and the Peace, which being flagitious, the excellency of Rea≈øon admitted no priviledge to; for how could ≈øuch enormous Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øors of the Law be righteous Law-Makers?

The la≈øt priviledge is to have pay for their pains, by a (it ≈øhould be equal) rate, upon all the Freeholders in the County; that is, they who legally had, or might have had a Vote in the Choice; and this allowance was to be ≈øet by Parliament; and who could they better tru≈øt with a little of their e≈øtate, then they whom they had formerly in≈øtru≈øted with the whole? and this was not due till the end of Parliament: So jealous is Rea≈øon of all Supremacy in the corrupted ≈øtate of mankinde.

And ≈øurely none that is not actually in this height, but will agree to this ju≈øt Rea≈øon; and he that is in, if he intends onely a due u≈øe of it, cannot deny it, this is ju≈øt, betwixt the≈øe powers and them for whom they are intru≈øted; for it is plain, as before, that all eminency of power, is ≈øolely and onely for the ≈øafety of the people; wherefore it is fit to ≈øee wherein that ≈øafety doth con≈øi≈øt, and to that end we ≈øhall Quaere.

div.head: What is, and wherein the priviledge of a free Subject doth properly con≈øi≈øt?
div.p: HAving ≈øeen the great and due care of the Law, for the well providing for the Supream Magi≈øtrate, and that it looks at due (both) power and maintenance, and ≈øets limits in it ≈øelf again≈øt all exce≈øs and out-boundings;

We now come to ≈øee after the priviledge of the Subject in the body ≈øo called Repre≈øentative, the priviledge of every particular man, wherein the Supream rea≈øon hath al≈øo looked at every one but as a Member of the whole, and hath ≈øetled that as the greate≈øt priviledge, to do mo≈øt for the publike welfare, and well and orderly government of all the≈øe, in ≈øuch ≈øort, as not onely the principles of Nature, but the long experience of of ≈øo many Ages, and above all the inlightenments of divine Wi≈ødom, have handled out to us in ≈øuch manner as they are without all que≈øtion.

And therefore as it is ≈øufficiently manife≈øted, that particular men are through power, favor, riches, malice, and ≈øuch like, as ready and as de≈øirous to deal unfaithfully, injuriou≈øly, and inhumanely with their neighbours, as the Prince with the people; therefore mo≈øt excellent Rea≈øon, ≈øo called Law, and above all the divine Wi≈ødom hath held out Magi≈øtracy to pre≈øerve as afore≈øaid, again≈øt the≈øe evils by due Laws; and the ju≈øtne≈øs of the≈øe, is the greate≈øt priviledge; and to have them like Gall and Wormwood is the highe≈øt di≈øpriviledge.

The ≈øpecial matter wherein we u≈øually place priviledge is, fir≈øt, to Life; ≈øecondly, Liberty; thirdly, Goods; and fourthly, good Name; and the Law for good Cau≈øe re≈øtrains a mans ≈øelf in the abu≈øe or ill u≈øe of the≈øe, as well as pre≈øerves them to him again≈øt others.
