Now that which gives, is of more value and more honorable then that given: The Heathen expre≈ø≈øed it thus, More glorious is it to rule Kings, ≈øet up, and pull down Kings, then be a King; whereby it is evident, That the priviledge of the Subject, is not to live at lu≈øt, do as he li≈øts, revenge injuries, and act Will for Law, whether in higher or lower e≈øtate, that is, the Magi≈øtrate inferior to Tyrannize over the people without controll, nor to execute what laws he hath in his power as he li≈øt, but according to his rule; nor the ≈øubject to abu≈øe his fellow-Subject, in word or deed, much le≈øs to arraign the Magi≈øtrate and his actions with a forked tongue of envy at his plea≈øure, no nor to mi≈øu≈øe or abu≈øe his own time, his e≈øtate, his liberty or power in his place, and di≈øobey all Law, or at le≈øt que≈øtion and wrangle it, how ju≈øt ≈øo ever, if contrary to his intere≈øt; and how plain ≈øo ever, yet to enter a contention meerly for plea≈øure, and through his pur≈øe-potency, to make evil good again≈øt his meaner, or le≈øs favoured neighbour; In ≈øhort, it is not to do what ever evil Cu≈øtome, or corrupt Practi≈øe, or Selfi≈øh intere≈øt calls Law and due right. I ≈øhall give you but one example or two among the many thou≈øands of Englands Plague-≈øores, not at all, or not ≈øufficiently provided again≈øt; viz.

A. Being a great Merchant, and might be tru≈øted upon his own Bond for an hundred thou≈øand pounds, takes up ≈øixty thou≈øand pounds, with which, and twenty thou≈øand pounds with a wife for his ≈øon, he purcha≈øes five thou≈øand ≈øix hundred pounds per annum, ≈øettles it upon the ≈øon, and his wife, and after breaks; this, and a thou≈øand ≈øuch gallant Cheates are ordinary, and remedile≈øs, though it will be pretended otherwi≈øe.

So again, A. Merchant of London ≈øells upon likeing, at a ≈øet rate, to B. a Merchant in Yarmouth a barrel of Nutmegs, and ≈øends them by ≈øea by C. Ma≈øter. B. di≈ølikes them, pays double fraight, as per agreement and returns them. A. ≈øues B. for them, and recovers. B. ≈øues C. for them and recovers; the value is thirty pound originally, the co≈øts of ≈øuit cometh to one hundred pound, which is as much as C. is worth; C. upon this being ca≈øt at Common Law, flies into Chancery, or upon Affida. di≈øcovers that the truth is, A. had the barrel of Nutmegs, which upon the Trial betwixt C. and B. had been fully proved; but that C. not knowing the ≈øervants of B. though he knew the name of him to whom the goods were delivered for A. his Ma≈øter; and C. coming to Subpoena him to appear as witne≈øs, A. ju≈øtly believing at it ought, that the ≈øhame and dammage mu≈øt at la≈øt light upon him, ≈øheweth C. a wrong man, who takes his monye and the Subpoena, and appears, but can evidence nothing, and B. is overthrown.

Now ≈øuch, and the like Cheates, Thefts, yea as bad as Robberies, are not at all, or ≈øo ≈ølightly, and that with ≈øo much charge, puni≈øhed, as is too much ≈øhame for a Barbarous Nation holding forth common Ju≈øtice to allow.

So the wretchedne≈øs of Juries, and the like, which are ≈øo clean perverted from the fir≈øt in≈øtitution, that though many hone≈øt, ju≈øt, wi≈øe Patriots eye the fir≈øt in≈øtitution with great con≈øideration, yet they now ≈øee them with hearts of Regret, abu≈øed and abu≈øing their high tru≈øts, and all is pretended the liberty of the Subject: So far hath the corruption of intere≈øts prevailed upon all e≈øtates.

To rake in this puddle of Negative Priviledge, were to draw almo≈øt all the ordinary actions and litigations of the Commonwealth into que≈øtion, and arraign all per≈øons in our Apo≈øtate pretending Reforming Age.

I will not therefore expatiate, but come to the Affirmative part of the Que≈øtion, and ≈øee wherein the liberty of the Subject doth con≈øi≈øt properly, and con≈øider the ≈øame, as I have done the other, (though tacitely) generally and particularly.

Fir≈øt therefore I ≈øay, that the priviledge of the Subject is to be governed by righteous and equal Laws, the Magi≈øtrate executing without partiality, his power, in, and for the pre≈øervation of life, goods, liberty, and good name, according to a ju≈øt, known and manife≈øt Law, for all enormities, tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions, offences, and crimes whatever.

This in general; In particular, it is to have the Supremacy of power ≈øo ≈øetled, known, and declared, both in point of Revenue, honor, and power, as con≈øi≈øts with the be≈øt ≈øafety of the whole; and that whether it be in a State Monarchical, or Republical.
Secondly, That the Laws by which they govern, be as far as may be certain, plain, and ea≈øie to be under≈øtood.
Thirdly, That this Law may extend to all offenders; and the higher the tru≈øt, the greater the puni≈øhment; and the higher the injury, the greater the recompence.

Fourthly, That as the Laws be evaded, or difu≈øed, or mi≈øu≈øed, or new evils encrea≈øe, for which no head Law is provided evidently; that this at the charge of the publike be ≈øpeedily remedied, that ≈øo the vitious nature of man may be deterred from acting old, or inventing new forms of ≈øinning.

That the≈øe Laws may extend to the Magi≈øtrate and Subject, Superior and Inferior in all degrees, Political, and Oeconomical; yea, to the ≈øuperadvi≈øing the e≈øtates of con≈øtant, vain, idle Spend-thrifts, (if ≈øuch ≈øhould grow in a decayed State of a Commonwealth, which in a well ≈øetled e≈øtate cannot) as of per≈øons under age of management of their e≈øtates, or Ideots, or Lunaticks, for that vitiou≈øne≈øs in full ≈øence is wor≈øe then in a depraved one;

Yea, To look to apparel and diet, e≈øpecially drinking, and al≈øo recreations, e≈øpecially ≈øo called Gameing; for each mans time growing famou≈øly irregular ought to be limited by the publike Magi≈øtrate; and ≈øo in barganing and ≈øelling; yea, where a medium may be, to ≈øet it, or the Rule for it; Let not this onely be laid upon the preci≈øene≈øs of Religion; No, the Greekes and Romanes did by Nature ≈øuch things; and they without the Law becoming a Law to them≈øelves condemn us who have the Law and yet break it; is not deficiency of Judgement wor≈øe then that of age? and the Law of property is not by this broken.

Again, It is the priviledge of the Subject, that they have fit Judges, Officers, and Mini≈øters of the Commonwealth, qualified according to the Rules of the Law; and can there be better then men of wi≈ødom, fearing God, and hating covetou≈øne≈øs?

Next, That their Salaries be ≈øuch as may be fitting for their places, and not burthen≈øome to the Commonwealth, nor their numbers, and yet enough; and tho≈øe fitly di≈øtributed for the ea≈øe of the poor, as ju≈øtice to both them and the rich.

That all pro≈øecutions in the Law, whether criminal, or other tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes, injuries, wrongs, or debts, be duly puni≈øhed, le≈øt the Land in general bear the burthen of particular offences‚ñ™ well knowing that there are abominations that bring de≈øolation; That the nece≈ø≈øities of the Nation for War and Peace be levied equally and ju≈øtly (and the expences in a ≈øetled way audited and allowed) and that not onely for, or upon man compared with man, but Town≈øhip with Town≈øhip, Hundred with Hundred, and County with County.

The great rea≈øon of many Counties not going about, or ≈øo long delaying the equalizing rates, as to Towns and Per≈øons, was, le≈øt the inju≈øt intere≈øt of Parliament men, appointed for particular Counties, ≈øhould upon the true value of one County appearing, hoy≈øt that up, and never regard the due ballance with others; and therefore that the Law of righteou≈øne≈øs ought to be above the Law of intere≈øt, mu≈øt, as may be, be a≈ø≈øured.

As for example, If a Town were a poor ≈ømall Fi≈øhing Town, as great Yarmouth in Norfolk was and not able to maintain a Mini≈øter, as it ≈øeems it was not, and that it had forty pounds per annum allowed for one out of the Bi≈øhops lands; after it is able to maintain ten Mini≈øters, and have but one or two, that it ≈øhould yet have the forty pounds per annum, and other places ≈øtarve; to take this forty pound away, and make it pay duly an equal portion with others, is general and ju≈øt priviledge, and no di≈øpriviledge.

So Dunwich, Ri≈øeing, and forty places in the We≈øt, to ≈øend Burge≈ø≈øes to Parliament, is a di≈øpriviledge, though originally a due and rightly con≈øtituted; for the rea≈øon cea≈øing, the Laws ought to cea≈øe, and ≈øuch rechanges are our Settlements.

So ill Cu≈øtomes to be continued for Intere≈øt, and publike Grievances tolerated for private commodity, whether of men or Town≈øhips, as the unju≈øt, illegal, and de≈øtructive keeping the ≈øo called A≈ø≈øizes at Thetford at the Brink of the County of Norfolk in Confinio Comitatus, which is again≈øt Law, is a great di≈øpriviledge; for it ought to be in the body of the County, or Head-Town; but if that were ≈øeated inconveniently, yet this is unju≈øt and de≈øtructive; for ≈øo incommodious is the place, that the very i≈ø≈øues lo≈øt there (the place not being able to receive the nece≈ø≈øary attendants) are worth, or I am mi≈øinformed by knowing men, as much as the revenue of the Town is worth; yet in driving on this corrupt intere≈øt again≈øt publike good, I hear good men and great pretenders are engaged.

And it carries little of weight, except for honorary intere≈øt ≈øake (which alwayes hitherto hath been an u≈øual inlet to corruption) That the Judge, a ≈øtranger to the County, ≈øhould appoint the place, or indeed that the place ≈øhould be but fixed, except in ca≈øes of evident danger to the publike, as plague, famine, publike inundations, be≈øiegings, deva≈øtations, or the like; ≈øo that of two accidental evils (not things ab≈øolutely evil in them≈øelves) the lea≈øt might be cho≈øen.

It is likely it will after appear better to take away the ≈øo called A≈ø≈øi≈øes, as to Trials of general actions, and ≈øuch controver≈øies altogether hereafter, as being now become a burthen, rather then ea≈øe to the Subject; for it is evident, the corruptions of tho≈øe meetings continue, if they do not increa≈øe; now ≈øuch things, which were good originally, when depraved, are di≈øpriviledges if after complaint continued.

And I wi≈øh therefore onely I could tell where the priviledge of Engli≈øhmen were; I know where it ≈øhould be, and it may be found thus by parcels; but there is ≈øo much rubbi≈øh and lumber amid≈øt the multitude of Officers, Courts, &c. It is hard, but we will attempt, as briefly as we may, to offer at lea≈øt, which will di≈øcover ≈øomewhat, though we cannot come through all particulars.

In a word Shortly then, Ju≈øtice, and that both for Law and Equity ought to be in the proper County; the Officers known, Fees certain, and not exceeding ≈øo much upon the pound clear dammage; and equity ought not to be ≈øought till Common Law determines the thing fit onely for that Court.

La≈øtly, As to this, that no man be out-ballanced in Law, by power, favor, or riches, as Town≈øhips, Cities, and Corporations again≈øt a mean man, yea, if he had never a penny; nor awed from ≈øeeking ju≈øt things for fear of forfeitures of his lands, as Coppy-holders; all of which I ≈øhall in their particulars further inlarge as occa≈øion offers.

So that it is plain here, That having and executing ju≈øt Laws ju≈øtly, whereby publike peace and ≈øafety, again≈øt the Superiors, and between equals, and well ordering Mannors and E≈øtates, for publike peace, quiet, and benefit be ob≈øerved, and renewed Laws, is the proper priviledge of the Subject.

But as to this point of ≈øafety, we mu≈øt proceed a little further, and that is to look to the power of the Supream Magi≈øtrate in due providing for the peace and wellfare of the people, both among them≈øelves and al≈øo again≈øt others, not by way of Monopolizing Trade for benefit or gain, but ≈øecurity of the State: therefore its no di≈øpriviledge of the Subject, that none ≈øhould ≈øell Ammunition or Weapons of any ≈øort, except Swords and Knives, but ≈øuch as are authorized by the State; So al≈øo that no one keep an Inn, Tavern, Victualing or Alehou≈øe, for that the≈øe hou≈øes are, and ought to have the Magi≈øtrate their Superadvi≈øors, and an account from them of the nature and number of their gue≈øts, lea≈øt any danger thereby ari≈øe to the State. And in ca≈øe of error or default, the offender to be puni≈øhed; and in ca≈øe of inconveniency, the place to be di≈øpriviledged. Again, Its no di≈øpriviledge to a Free-man to have men attainted of crimes ≈øeverely puni≈øhed; yea in ≈øome ca≈øes, not agreeably to the letter of the (at
lea≈øt pre≈øent practical) Law. As for example, a per≈øon dangerous and oft ≈øu≈øpected for criminal matters, as Robberies, Burglaries, Thefts, Cutpur≈øing, and the like, is acquitted by the formal, ignorant, or packed Jury, for want of a clear, more then noon day evidence, which is now with Jurors, through the ≈øervile terrors of ≈øelfi≈øh Judges, expected; if ≈øuch a one for the peace and welfare of the Publique be detained in Pri≈øon, made to work, &c. ≈øo one who hath had his Clergie ≈øeveral times; So of gallant Rogues, who live high, and can give no account how they come by their expences, to ≈øecure ≈øuch is no doubt the great priviledge of the Subject.

The≈øe matters can never prove prejudicial to ju≈øt or good men in a well ordered State; they tend to the well ≈øetling of any State; and although ≈øome may abu≈øe ≈øuch power again≈øt good men, ≈øometimes; yet this is well known, That that is the evil of men, not of the power; puni≈øh the men, and appoint better; but nece≈ø≈øary power mu≈øt alwayes be upheld.

This may be much oppo≈øed by ≈øome whom I have found earne≈øtly to contend that pri≈øoners convict of Theft and Vagrancie, common Milchers and Pilferers could not by the Law be polled, that is, have their long haire cut off, no not when it hath been proved they have made that in≈øtrumental to their roguery. The Cu≈øtome of old will not prevail, but their new fancy, that nothing of rea≈øon is Law, but what we have an adjudged ca≈øe for; this mu≈øt be maintained; for this is their Diana, who ≈øo ≈øtickle for Rogues; and therefore they will not do this; but advantageous cu≈øtomes are revived or created, though no better and le≈øs rea≈øon; thus they Tyth Mint, Anni≈øe, &c. Its no di≈øpriviledge to be enforced to plant; yea, if a Law were to plant the North and We≈øt ≈øide of each inclo≈øure with fruit trees, and the South and Ea≈øt with Timber and other wood; and when any Clo≈øe were above four Acres, to have one row of Timber or fruit in or about the mid≈øt.

It were no di≈øpriviledge to have all Commons inclo≈øed and improved, a certain quantity only kept for the meer poor of the Town; nay its the only way to advance the Nation, provide a≈ø≈øuredly for the poor, who now all are eaten out by one rich Clown; and make good roads for Trade, and take away the Nur≈øe of poverty.

Its no di≈øpriviledge to alter the Heatheni≈øh days of the Moneths and weeks, and idolatrous ones of Saints dayes, Fea≈øts, weeks, &c. Nor to admit no Market or Fayr of ≈øpeciall note, ≈øave on Wedne≈ødays and Thur≈ødays, ≈øo called, that going and returning be not at all on the Lords Day; No, nor to take away multitudes of old needle≈øs Fayrs in England, the principal end as practi≈øed, being only drinking and wantonne≈øs.

Its no di≈øpriviledge, to have a Law, that no ground within a certain ≈øpace of a City or walled Town be plowed, but all for pa≈øture, except allowed, and that onely once in a ≈øet quantity of years by the Magi≈øtrate thereto appointed for nece≈ø≈øity, and then not, except only for Roots, Turnips, and the like.

Its no di≈øpriviledge to be puni≈øhed for keeping Swine, or u≈øing certain Trades in the heart or great ≈øtreets, or neer thereto, of Cities and great Towns; alwayes provided they be not tolerated under a rent or any payment; to be enforced to ≈øweep ≈øtreets, clean≈øe Vaults, avoid Dunghils; yea if it did extend to the avoiding or purging the belly of other excrements then water, in any place, and not bury it.
Its no di≈øpriviledge to have the Magi≈øtrate ≈øet a rate upon what can admit it, nor to puni≈øh the inventors or wearers of new Fa≈øhions.
Its no di≈øpriviledge to enforce by Law to Tyle or Slate all hou≈øes in Cities and great Towns.

To conclude, a general Law can be no di≈øpriviledge, nor any Law which truly intends publique good; the not equal admini≈øtring of that Law, is a di≈øpriviledge; but then the fault is in the Judge, not in the Law, though it may prove very burthen≈øome (as in times of Prerogative) nay de≈øtructive to a particular, which evil will and ought to have a ≈øpeedy remedy by complaint and due puni≈øhment, not by alteration of the Law.

I come now to the la≈øt controver≈øie of Priviledge and di≈øpriviledge that I remember, that is, That men of ≈øuch E≈øtates ≈øhall not (keep Hawks) keep Greyhounds, Guns, ≈øetting Dogs, Nets, and the like; many have que≈øtioned me what benefit we had by all our labours, hazzards, payments, &c. if this were practi≈øed, they had as live the Lord Matravers ≈øhould take away their goods, as the Ju≈øtices of the Peace; but being
informed, what they did was according to Act of Parliament, what he did by meer power; what he did was to break the hearts of the people, and fit them for ≈ølavery; what the Ju≈øtice did was to re≈øtrain the vanity of youth, and keep poor people to labor, that through the vain delights of ≈øporting they might not neglect their Family; what he did, was to en≈ølave poor and rich equally; what they did, was only to regulate exorbitancy, and looked onely at inconvenience; they all re≈øolved the thing was ju≈øt, they would willingly ≈øubmit, and de≈øired a certain enforcement of ≈øo ju≈øt, ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary a Law. 2. That trade ≈øhould be regulated; which mo≈øt a≈ø≈øuredly, as to well working, making, fitting, and trimming of matter, is out of all doubt nece≈ø≈øary, if not of nece≈ø≈øity; but as to the times and places of ≈øale, wherein one Merchant or Trade≈øman may outreach another, and may border upon particular intere≈øt, that is not ≈øo ea≈øily determined; only this the Supream Magi≈øtrate mu≈øt take a note of direction, that there is two evils which to well ≈øettle a free trade mu≈øt be provided again≈øt; Fir≈øt, to loo≈øe a rule which is to place the ≈øuperintendencie of power in the vulgar Artificer, which will at lea≈øt end in confu≈øion; the next is too ≈øtrict a Rule, giving the Ma≈øters of the Company as you may call them, ≈øuch a power as they ≈øhall make Laws, and enforce the execution upon ≈øuch terms as ≈øhall out all Freedom, but only in name; therefore ≈øome general Rules mu≈øt be laid down, and every County mu≈øt have a Con≈øervator of Liberties of Trade, to re≈øtrain from unju≈øt encroachments, either of the poor by multitudes, or rich by power; and this will ≈øurelie≈øt ≈øettle the foundations of all Priviledges.

But there is one Priviledge more yet remaining, which is as it were the e≈ø≈øence of all, or rather that which in the enmity of the world doth ≈øecure all the re≈øt; and that is, that the Subject him≈øelf (unle≈øs he forfeits his liberty) be ma≈øter of his proper Arms, and imployed in the ≈øetled Militia of the Nation; For it is by too frequent experience manife≈øted, that the con≈øtant u≈øe or generall imployment of Forreigners (or meer hirelings, though of their own Nation) is an introductive to pure or meer va≈ø≈øalage; and ≈øurely you Engli≈øhmen, who think Arms beneath you, as mo≈øt of you of late years have done, are only fit, (as men I ≈øpeak it) to be the ≈øervants ≈øervants whom you imploy in that ≈øo eminently powerful ≈øervice; And ≈øurely, the lo≈øs of a Nations glory, is, to enervate its Militia, by ca≈øting the honors of that imployment upon men unworthy ≈øuch tru≈øts, as if they and all other places fiduciary, and therefore more honourable, were only agreeable to rich men, which was done only to ea≈øe publick charges, and that made way for this publick ruine.

This I ≈øpeak to, as taking it for granted, that the time of the lawfulne≈øs of warrs cea≈øe not among Chri≈øtians, nor that it will, ≈øo long as there is ≈øin and error; and ≈øo a Magi≈øtrate; for what the ordinary Sword cannot reach (yea the ≈øupream Magi≈øtrate him≈øelf in ca≈øe he offend) The Sword of the Lord will. But I ha≈øte, and therefore ≈øhall not enlarge, but open this more by another Quaere, which is,

div.head: Whether all Subjects have their Priviledges? And whether, and how they may lo≈øe them and regain them?
div.p: IT is manife≈øt to all men, as it hath before appeared, that there are Subjects by Covenant, and Contract, and by power; Nature gives like priviledges to all men; but it gives them not like hearts to ≈øeek after them; all accompt not priviledge the ≈øame; yea, we hear of them who e≈øteem it an honour to be ≈ølaves; but we look higher then tho≈øe Glo-worms; there is no fire or light in their rea≈øonings to us who ≈øay we have the Sun:
We therefore con≈øider the ≈øtate, fir≈øt of men, who have joyned together to maintain or acquire freedome again≈øt Enemies or Invadors, and have been overcome.

Now here we hold them ab≈øolutely bound to the Law of the Conqueror, and count it not natural wi≈ødom in ca≈øe of utmo≈øt extremity of Tyranny to break out; they can claim nothing of ju≈øt priviledge, they are his ≈øervants, they might have been killed, and to make them ≈øervants was a mercy.

And truly I ≈øee no way for ju≈øt (take ju≈øt for a prudent) heading of the≈øe men again≈øt the Conquerour; if for life, they have ≈øworn obedience; what have been
the i≈ø≈øue of ≈øuch out-breakings, I pa≈øs not of; matters of fact prove nothing, and this conque≈øt without an Oath, if he u≈øes them but as men pre≈øerved, ingages to faithful ≈øervice untill freedom acquired; their priviledge is to live.

And if an equal gets power over his own Nation, it is the ≈øame accounted, how unju≈øt ≈øoever the ground of War fir≈øt was. But in ca≈øe of tru≈øt convented for, and ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion granted, as to a Prince without Covenant, there it is otherwi≈øe. By this we now are come to ju≈øt Originals of Government; here I ≈øay the people, the body, or evidently the Con≈øervators of the Tru≈øts, or Guardians of the peoples Liberties, have a power to call to their aid, and vindicate if the Ca≈øe requires, by Arms the peoples Liberties.

For here is rational ≈øubjection; and that which is mo≈øt rea≈øonable in the ≈øingle Government, is the Obligation of the Prince for his meer tru≈øt; yet that rea≈øon mu≈øt re≈øt in the judgement of the Prince; but this doth ≈øtretch no further then to things good, as in two evils the lea≈øt is to be cho≈øen; but one man thinks this the lea≈øt, and an other that; and ≈øometimes that which was generally thought the lea≈øt, in the i≈ø≈øue proves the greate≈øt; ≈øo in good, the Magi≈øtrate may think that, and the people this, but both evidently good‚ñ™ The Magi≈øtrate may ≈øettle either; Now as the Magi≈øtrate is Judge of good, ≈øo is the ≈øubject of evil; that is, what is de≈øtructive to natural priviledges; for this ≈øubject voluntary ≈øubjects him≈øelf for well living, (the Subject to ab≈øolute power is onely to live) untill convention either by Petition or force ingages the Prince.

Truth is, ab≈øolute powers acquiring their power by force, have a law upon them, by God among Chri≈øtians, light of Nature amon≈øt Heathens, To do as he would be done unto; but he is while he hath not engaged him≈øelf free; but if engaged to man, bound to man; and man if he hath power again≈øt that power may enforce.
It will be objected; Princes will then onely ≈øeek to hold by Conque≈øt and ab≈øolute power and never come to any Convention.

To which it is an≈øwered, it is agreed they will not; for its ea≈øie to believe that men will not do what they never would be brought unto; We ≈øee Chri≈øtian Princes by Covenant ≈øeek ab≈øolute liberty; yea, from the Oathes of their Coronation, which is the condition of the peoples ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion; and whereever an Oath is, the people are free Subjects, if the Oath be required by the con≈øtitutions of the Nation, whether the Prince thinks ≈øo or not.

Now this is plain to him allows he end of Magi≈øtrates to be the peoples ≈øafety; ≈øo that the ≈øole difficulty will re≈øt upon the powers; but he that looks well into the work, will finde that the u≈øe of power is originally Magi≈øterial, or Magi≈øtratical rather; and that exce≈ø≈øes of power, that is, that power which is not u≈øed and improved duly, is as ≈øubject to re≈øtraint as the failing of particular per≈øons.

So that then the powers mu≈øt look to improve them≈øelves ju≈øtly, both backward and forward; behind it ≈øhall ≈øee the Subject free in Nature, and happily before his inva≈øion, u≈øurpation, or ju≈øt defence brought him to va≈ø≈øallage.

Now then looking at him as a Subject, he ought to yield him protection again≈øt all men, and then due means of ≈øub≈øi≈øtance, that is, ≈øuch as con≈øi≈øts with the ju≈øt ≈øafety of the Conqueror, not contrary among Chri≈øtians to the Rule of Chri≈øtianity; alwayes yet preferring Self-≈øafety; for undoubtedly we mu≈øt agree, that if one hundred take one hundred and fifty, or but one hundred pri≈øoners in War, and have three, or two hundred, or one hundred and fifty more come again≈øt them, and they can ≈øee no vi≈øible way of ≈øafe ingageing again≈øt this three hundred, or two hundred, but by the death of them before pri≈øoners, they may ≈ølay them, yea in cold blood; and they that have written otherwi≈øe, to aggrandize the mercy of a particular Prince, have flattered; for in War (if anywhere) my own life is above that of the Enemies.

And if Occurrences ≈øo fall out that ≈øome do not ≈øuch actions, it is rather the immediate working of Providence, then the rea≈øon of man, or Rule of legal Prudence; for all know, the impri≈øoned will ≈øeek their liberty with the death of their adver≈øaries.

And this makes many Conquerors hard-handed in the fir≈øt generation after Conque≈øt, till the State be ≈øetled; and to give the due loo≈øe to the≈øe men after ≈øetled by Conque≈øt, is difficult; the men of the world are various in opinion, and much un≈øetled, they are at la≈øt forced to Providence; and yet who ≈øhews what Providence is? and vain it is to talke of Providence, untill we ≈øee what are the tokens of Providence.

Wherefore before I come to handle how particular men may lo≈øe their priviledges; I ≈øhall a little di≈øcour≈øe of the tokens of Providence whereby a Nation may apprehend deliverances, and ≈øee whether there be any certain enough to engage a Chri≈øtian in what may be called oppo≈øition to Powers.

For to a Heathen to have power to try the event for Liberty, is enough to hold his con≈øcience in ≈øu≈øpence, till the i≈ø≈øue to him manife≈øt the pre≈øent will of Providence; but to morrow he will attemp again.

But the Chri≈øtian ought to obey for con≈øcience ≈øake the Powers, knowing there are none but of God; and that he ≈øets up and plucks down whom and as he plea≈øes; therefore Chri≈øtians ≈øubmit to V≈øurpers in Acts ju≈øt and lawful, yea to Tyrants; and being enthralled, they ≈øeek liberty ju≈øtly, that is,
Fir≈øt, When God ≈øhall upon their Petitions ≈øtir the heart of the Prince to afford them their ju≈øt dues.
Next, They ≈øeek help of their Con≈øervators of Priviledges, if any be; but the≈øe are natural, and ju≈øt to all men.
Again, The≈øe ≈øeek not out eva≈øions for Rebellion, ≈øuch as ≈øome call Providence.

Therefore let us ≈øee further what we can finde in Rea≈øon; Let a Prince come to the height of private wickedne≈øs, is this a ≈øure ≈øign God hath rejected him? No ≈øure, let him err in many acts of Ju≈øtice to particular per≈øons; yet this will not do, ≈øimply con≈øidered; that is, if it ≈øtretches not to an univer≈øal end.
Now ≈øome would bound this to the life onely; that is, if the King, or any Supream, did not adventure upon the breach of Laws for ≈øafety of life, there ought to be no oppo≈øition.

Others make liberty, others call goods Priviledge; but all agree, that when he holds none of the≈øe, he lo≈øeth the nature of a Prince, and is an Enemy, a Lycaon, a Wolfe, and with Lycaon or Nebuchadnezzar to be driven into the Wilderne≈øs till they know the mo≈øt High reigneth over all the Kingdoms of the ≈øons of men, and giveth them to whom he plea≈øeth; and that no Tribe, Family, Linage, or other relation can engage a Duty, but he will incline all hearts, as he did in ≈øeveral ca≈øes among his own people.

Some Quaere this yet if it were ≈øo; and ≈øurely God may do it for Judgement: But O Kings, Princes, and all Supreams, know, while there is a body joyned to a ≈øoul, your foul exorbitances will not be continually brooked; but you having led the people into ≈øins with you, God will either puni≈øh you together, or one by another; therefore look not wholly to the ingageing the con≈øcience of your people, while yours have no bounds; yet this is certain, Providence is allowable in difficult ca≈øes and doubful; if we be in bivio in a ≈øtreight, at a lo≈øs, and Rea≈øon and Religion both ≈øeem ≈øilent, or ≈øpeak not out plain enough, Providences following ju≈øt means, is a warranting ≈øign of approbation of the righteous God.
But in things evidently again≈øt the light of Religion, ≈øetled Law, and good Rea≈øon, Providences I ≈øay onely ≈øo (and mo≈øt men expect no further) a≈ø≈øure not at all.
Yet if effected and ≈øetled, we mu≈øt obey; but till then it is our duty to oppo≈øe, which clears us of Turci≈øm.

By this it is clear and evident, That for any Nation to make an other its pattern meerly from Similitude is no way warrantable; but their ≈øeveral conditions, in all regards, not onely of Nature, but of civil Rea≈øon, is to be con≈øidered, le≈øt we ≈øwerve into the puddle of confu≈øion, while we ≈øeek the pure ≈øtreams of Government, walking upon the ≈ølippery bank of Providence.
The≈øe general heads pa≈ø≈øed, which will to ≈øome clear all the re≈øt; yet to all men of all capacities to which general ≈øort 'tis mo≈øt fit for me to ≈øpeak to, I intend this Treati≈øe.
We come now to ≈øee how particular men in their own free Nations, may become ab≈øolutely bound, or more, or le≈øs.

Now to this it is plain, that as Nations may acquire power over Nations, ≈øo men over men; yet the generalty of Nations Chri≈øtian have avoided ≈ølavery, ≈øo called, of Chri≈øtians; but why they ≈øhould do it to others, is not apparent, except onely in the di≈øu≈øe, and that di≈øu≈øe come from the evil of ≈øervants multiplying to danger, as ≈øhall be made apparent afterwards.

But now, as ≈øome offences become dangerous to life, ≈øome to liberty, ≈øome to
goods, and ≈øome to honor, ≈øome for a time, ≈øome for ever; as the Law is, ≈øo are priviledges of men, lo≈øt, or regained, and that ju≈øtly; As the Romane Mutineers, ≈øome bani≈øhed into Sicilia, and never ≈øuffered to return, ≈øome but for ≈øeven years, ≈øome untill relea≈øed by the Senate, as they were guilty in degrees, ju≈øt as now they are by Act made uncapable of office for one, two or more years, or for ever at the liberty of the Supream Magi≈øtrate; and ≈øurely ≈øuch penalties will, if prudently improved, prove the greater incentives to tru≈øt and politique vertue.

Now as particular men are indulged, ≈øo are Nations, and by faithfulne≈øs or nece≈ø≈øity, are incorporated into Free Societies, as Wales was with us, by which you have the wayes of regaining freedom made plain; the ju≈øtice of them is before di≈øcu≈ø≈øed; but the right of particular men, while acted in due cour≈øe of Law, how ever u≈øurped upon, affords little matter, at lea≈øt at fir≈øt to rai≈øe objections again≈øt the Supremacy of power.
This a≈ø≈øerted, to clear all things, if it may be, we will briefly con≈øider the nature of ≈øubjection.

div.head: Whether Subjection and Obedience be due to the Per≈øon, or to the Power? Whether it be local or univer≈øal, and how con≈øcience binds?
div.p: BY what hath been ≈øaid before, it plainly appears, that the Law doth, and mu≈øt di≈øtingui≈øh betwixt the Office and Per≈øon of a Monarch, King, &c. and all other Supreams upon the like ground, by attributing to them properties incompatible, or no way agreeing with the per≈øon, not onely ubiquity and immortality, but al≈øo infallibility in their Sphears, that is, not to be able to do wrong, while ob≈øerving their rule; this might be enough ro ≈øome men, if intere≈øts had not made us wi≈øe to de≈øtruction.

Therefore to the oppo≈øers we may ≈øeem to look back a little by re≈øolving con≈øcience more clearly, That the intere≈øt of Princes (by all means ≈øeeking to avoid the eternal decree of altering Kingdoms at the plea≈øure of the Almighty, by ≈øetting up, and pulling down at his plea≈øure) ≈øeeking to tie the Subject to blinde obedience, as well in the univer≈øality, as particular per≈øons, without he≈øitation ≈øimply, becau≈øe commanded, is not held forth ≈øo much to a≈ø≈øure the quiet of the people, as to exalt the ab≈øolute power of Princes, to the di≈øhonor of God, and thraldom of Nations; And as before, either power or con≈øent giving this power, the ≈øame re≈øpectively may take it away, except it be a ≈øpecial Ordinance of God; which few, if any, do attempt to make good; neither can that Rule (upon any ground Scriptural or Rational, except God in Scripture giveth a liberty to things ≈øimply unlawful, which who dare aver?) of obeying, &c, either by doing or ≈øuffering, be extended to whole communities, but to particulars, as afore≈øaid, becau≈øe that Nature in the purity of it, intends univer≈øal good; and if the whole body of the Nation agree in it, it ≈øeems to be very evident; but in a knowing Nation, if the mo≈øt knowing, it ≈øeems mo≈øt rea≈øonable; but in a wi≈øe Nation, if the wi≈ødom be corrupted through licentiou≈øne≈øs, as to Gods glory it oft falls out, if the prudent of the Nation not carried away with the≈øe corruptions, agree it, and impowred, though not the greater number, it is lawful, but they ca≈øt them≈øelves on Providence to ≈øupport them.
An other thing in this mu≈øt be cleared, that is, to ≈øatisfie intere≈øt (viz.) what is the power? To which the An≈øwer is at hand in a double con≈øideration.
To clear the Cau≈øe, You mu≈øt con≈øider, that as per≈øons, ≈øo Powers al≈øo may be unju≈øt.

Now to the fir≈øt, It is clear, that Obedience is due to the power; That is, if an U≈øurrer gets tht Kingdom, while the true King cannot yield protection, you are to give obedience; and if the U≈øurper requires an Oath of fidelity onely, you are to yield to it, that is, lawfully may; but if he requires you to a≈ø≈øert the lawfulne≈øs of his Title, it is unju≈øt to ask, and for you to take, and ≈øeems onely a picking of a quarrel, to bani≈øh, or confi≈øcate, or &c. which he may do by his power.
But you will ≈øay, what if the right King cometh again?

I ≈øay in ≈øuch a ca≈øe, you in your place ought to ≈øeek the welfare of the U≈øurper (if behaving him≈øelf ju≈øtly) and ≈øo not condemned by the community; for I give no loo≈øe
to particular con≈øcience, to judge of publick good or evil) if a Souldier by fighting for him, and ≈øo all in Tru≈øts;
Then ≈øurely the Mini≈øter ought not to preach again≈øt him, though not for him, no not to hint ≈øuch matters.

And if he that thinks the Prince driven away hath Right, comes under the Sword of that Prince, his oath of fidelity is not extinct, but ≈øu≈øpended, until the right King hath totally ou≈øted the U≈øurper; that Prince may put an oath of oppo≈øition to the Tyrant upon him, but it ≈øeems not ju≈øt.

Now the rea≈øon of this is becau≈øe God hath only appointed the Office, not the per≈øon, and power and convention are the means u≈øuall of acquiring, and God hath been ≈øeen in both; and man not to be wrecked or racked in his con≈øcience, mu≈øt ≈øubmit when God hath determined.

Some men think the Prince is to be ≈ølain, and his po≈øterity rooted all out; but the≈øe men plow with the Devils Heifer; from this opinion have horrible cruelties, murthers, deva≈øtations, and inhumanities more then barbarous proceeded, and that among Chri≈øtians, to ≈øecure their unju≈øt and al≈øo ju≈øt acque≈øts.

No, it is far ≈øafer to determine his rejection by ≈øuch a total expul≈øion, and make obedience ≈øo far univer≈øal, not ≈øo meerly local after oath once taken; but he that thinks otherwi≈øe, and burthens his con≈øcience with it, ought to abide by that particular witne≈øs, in doing what he can for the particular right he is engaged unto, until he either ≈øees him re≈øetled, and receives the recompence of his voluntary (I call it only ≈øo) faithfulne≈øs, or peri≈øheth under the wrath of his Adver≈øary, or being better informed reconciles him≈øelf, and ≈øubmits to the power; now this is far more due in doubtful ca≈øes, or where two powers both lawful conte≈øt, or where a lawful power is of many per≈øons, and part of them enter conte≈øt, and ≈øub due the other; This, as I take it, is ≈øufficiently cleared. I ≈øhall now proceed to clear other things.

div.head: Whether Common Good may be enforced again≈øt particular Priviledge?
div.p: IT hath been ≈øhewed that univer≈øal good of mankind is the fir≈øt matter eyed in the rule of excellent REa≈øon, ≈øo called Law; next that of Nations; and in Nations under the prudential ≈øettlements of their own, the Rule is, Good is more or le≈øs good as it more or le≈øs re≈øpects or reflects upon the publique intere≈øt and Common Concernments.

Therefore, though the Spirit witne≈ø≈øeth that it was done by Prophe≈øie, yet the rea≈øon of the high Prie≈øt went no further then Common Safety, urging that it was better put the Lord Chri≈øt to death, then the Romanes ≈øhould come and take away the City and Nation; ≈øo the wi≈øe woman of Abel in the ca≈øe of Sheba.
Now this is plain, that the life of a particular Citizen, is not to be valued with the ≈øafety of a City, &c.

But put ca≈øe, that a Prince requires unju≈øt things, or denounces wars, may the ≈øubjected Kingdom, City, State, &c. ≈øtand out? or if he requires the life of a particular Citizen, it may be him, in whom the ≈øafety of the place re≈øts, yea if it be the King of Right; as Jehu demanding Ahabs ≈øon, (it was before Crowned though in a Kingdom ≈øucce≈ø≈øively e≈øtabli≈øhed) I ≈øay, it is meet in this ca≈øe in prudence, to con≈øult ≈øecond cau≈øes throughly; they ≈øeem to do ≈øo; Two Kings ≈øay they ≈øtood not before him, how then ≈øhall we? And in ca≈øe of extremity, they may deliver a ju≈øt man, but not ≈ølay him (as they did Ahabs 70. ≈øons, that was wholly unwarrantable) life is the mo≈øt precious.

Now to them that object they mu≈øt ≈øtand out as long as they can, we ≈øay ≈øo to: but we may ≈øay prudence may avoid evidently ≈øore≈øeen dangers, yea with the danger of ≈øome ju≈øt men, to ≈øave many ju≈øt men, and ≈øeemingly unju≈øt.

For this ca≈øe al≈øo the e≈øtates of particular men may be digged up, high wayes made through them, Bulwarks, Forts, &c. reared, whereby property ≈øeems annulled, yet is only ≈øu≈øpended; but though the Law with us agrees this generally, yet our ≈øo called Municipal Law ≈øeems to deny it in ≈øeveral ca≈øes.
Fir≈øt, though it ≈øeem to agree the Law as to Lands, yet it denyes it to ≈øo called per≈øonal e≈øtate.

For ≈øuppo≈øe inva≈øion, as for example, the Scots (having now many Emi≈ø≈øaries laboring (in Pulpit and Pre≈øs e≈øpecially) a ≈øubver≈øion of our new Commonwealth) invade England, the Governor of a Town may order erecting Forts, and for pulling down ≈øome hou≈øes in the Suburbs, &c. But for enforcing Moneys from him they know have abundance, and yet know no other means of ≈øupply, the Governor cannot do it, but by Parliament, he mu≈øt be authorized.
But the rea≈øon is not thorow paced; for if Lands being the real e≈øtate hath the preferment, why ≈øhould the per≈øonal be better guarded? therefore to ≈øeek Ca≈øes for the rea≈øon is fruitle≈øs.

Truth is, that the difference is not as the one is per≈øonal, and the other Real e≈øtate; but as the one is more properly the ≈øinews of war then the other, and more ≈øubiect to be irrecoverably lo≈øt, and being private de≈øtroyes in ≈øearch the Law of property.

Therefore we ≈øhall not ≈øtate the ca≈øe as the meer Lawyer doth, of forcing away money, but of impo≈øing Taxes, as for the pre≈øervation of the place intru≈øted; And ≈øurely, though to avoid the u≈øurpation of Princes in the Jealou≈øie of Liberties, ≈øuch re≈øolutions have been; it is as lawful to lay ju≈øt Taxes upon the e≈øtate, as to erect fortre≈ø≈øes by the labour of the Citizens, and charge them upon Guards, Watches, &c. And to confi≈øcate e≈øtates, or inflict puni≈øhments, and that to death, upon ob≈øtinate and de≈øerving offendors.
And this mu≈øt be, or the folly, wilfulne≈øs, or pride of ≈øome few, may be in≈øtrumentall by evil example, to render all de≈øperate, as too oft experience hath plainly manife≈øted.

But the truth al≈øo is, that the ≈øufferings of particular per≈øons ought in equal Ju≈øtice to have ≈øome ≈øort of compen≈øation, tho≈øe e≈øpecially which come from the own party, and not from enemies; for a full recompence if in all ca≈øes, would but lay the foundation of Civil Jarrs for intere≈øt ≈øake, in the pure≈øt Commonwealths, among men; and have therefore been avoided.

By this it is clear, that it is not ≈øo much the diver≈øity of Rea≈øon, as of intere≈øt, that hath brought forth this ≈øeeming Law of contradiction, both ca≈øes being in time of eminent vi≈øible danger, war at the door, allowed and acted by prudent and Ju≈øt men.
Now in our ca≈øe let us ≈øee whether the Subject may be ≈øo di≈øpriviledged in time of peace; This will not extend to life, but to liberty and e≈øtate onely, or mo≈øt properly; As for example,

Commi≈ø≈øions to Salt-peter-men to dig in the hou≈øes, Cellars, Ho≈øteries, &c. of private per≈øons, and the like much Quaeried, as almo≈øt every thing is in preparations to great alterations of States.

So the putting down of Fayrs, cutting up of Woods in places of Robbery, making Cau≈øywayes through Mar≈øhes or Fens of particular men, yea forcing the ≈øale of Lands, for works of publick nece≈ø≈øity, or it may be of ≈øpecial convenience to the publick, as put the ca≈øe upon the making of Salt, or to plant Sugar, or make Gunpowder, or the like.

Now there is no que≈øtion, but they who have ultimate power, have the liberty to enact Laws which ≈øhall with equall Ju≈øtice relieve the publick nece≈ø≈øity, and ≈øatisfie the Right and Claym of the proprietor, yea though he were ob≈øtinate, not only not to admit the entry of his hou≈øe, but al≈øo to convey away his Lands, without the ≈øcandal of Ahabs forcing away Naboths Vineyard; for no ≈øupream Power can do that either for honour, profit, or private plea≈øure, without incurring a cen≈øure of unju≈øt; onely the publick good, and that in a more then ordinary manner, can make ≈øuch Acts lawful.

For though we may have ≈øalt without the Nation, and ≈øo Gunpowder and Sugar, yet the≈øe being matters e≈ø≈øential to the wel being of a Nation within it ≈øelf, may and ought to be, and will be provided for in a well governed State, to be prudently improved; And for Gunpowder, and ≈øuch like, the State may a≈ø≈øuredly become the ≈øole ma≈øters of it, both for making, vending, &c. for ≈øuch things ought to be in the publick Cognizance, or there is little a≈ø≈øurance:

Not that I would open a gap to Tyranny; for let unju≈øt Rulers know God will find them out, and their own ≈øtore-hou≈øes ≈øhal be made their enemies Magazines, but
to wicked men if they have power, you ≈øhall not need hint what is lawful; they regard nought but intere≈øt; for the Judge of this common good I refer you to the former Quaere of the ≈øame Nature; and having a≈ø≈øerted that the chief priviledge of the ≈øubject is ju≈øt Laws ju≈øtly executed,
We come to handle the due execution of tho≈øe Laws, and Quaere,

div.head: How and where the Laws are to be Admini≈øtred; and whether in the Native Tongue? &c. and the times of Judgement.
div.p: I Find not any Nation in the world, but had ever their Laws in the Native Tongue, and in the due bounds of Cities, Counties, Provinces, or what you plea≈øe to call them, except in ca≈øe of Conque≈øt, or ab≈øolute power, though not at pre≈øent conquering, yet claiming by conque≈øt; and mo≈øtly admitting no gradual appeals, but at a jump from the lowe≈øt Judge to the ≈øupream; I agree an abundance of Rea≈øon in Gradations, and al≈øo of unrea≈øonablene≈øs; and as with us now practi≈øed, in≈øufferable Tyranny and Extortion in mo≈øt ca≈øes, while ≈øeeking Ju≈øtice doubles the dammage original.

We all agree walking Courts de≈øtructive; and therefore our Ance≈øtors got tho≈øe of the Kings-Bench, and Common Pleas made ≈øedentary; and wherein lay their in≈øufferablene≈øs, but from the exce≈ø≈øive expence of the ≈øuitor in Travail and attendance? if ≈øo, then it is the duty of Judges in Chief, or Law-givers, ≈øo to ≈øettle judicatories, that the remedy be not wor≈øe then the di≈øea≈øe; and be ≈øalutary, not only for the wronged, but to the Nation and people; for it is the duty of all members, much more the Supream ones of a Nation, to ≈øee to the evils and ≈øufferings, oppre≈ø≈øions, cruelties and extortions acted again≈øt any fellow Citizen.

For what is this mans evil to day, if once made but a pre≈øident, will be ju≈øtified as of Right again≈øt another man to morrow; And if this be anywhere held forth in the Con≈øtitution of Government, it it mo≈øt evident in a Republique.

We all agree the Law is our Rule of well living, and that each man ought to be puni≈øhed if he tran≈øgre≈øs; And the Law it ≈øelf ≈øaith, That no man ≈øhall be excu≈øed for his ignorance; And therefore Laws ought to be fitted both in the Tongue and phra≈øe to the meane≈øt Capacity; otherwi≈øe the Law becometh a ≈ønare, as ours hath been too long.

And neither ought there to be ≈øo many, that a man may not well comprehend them; and multitudes of particular Laws is but Civil Popery, as well as holding them forth in an unknown Tongue; And ≈øure in rea≈øon it is as great an error and obliquity to the body and e≈øtate, to ≈øpeak to me the Law in an unknown Tongue, as to the ≈øoul. The open and evident rea≈øons of this my≈øtery is,
Fir≈øt, the Norman Conque≈øt, ≈øetling the Law in French.

Next the Roman yoak, making pleading in Latin; and the Rea≈øons making good this, is the pretext of Learning, which as to the French part can never be approved; for it is an antiquated Language in it ≈øelf, now wholly di≈øu≈øed; and when u≈øed, then onely in one Province; but ours is neither written, pronounced, nor under≈øtood, as that old Idiome of Normandia was.

And our Lawyers, to make it wholly private, have u≈øed all means to draw it into the form of a Canting, or Gibberi≈øh; for it is puni≈øhable in Moots to pronounce in the true Dialect; but we mu≈øt u≈øe the Engli≈øh reading to the French writing, or rather French corrupted by ignorant Clerks, which rendred our books exceedingly imperfect, and even the be≈øt of them but by the ≈øence not to be wholly warranted.
The private rea≈øons are, fir≈øt, this breeds difficulty, that contention, and that gain to the practi≈øer.

The next is a quaint one, and would Ju≈øtice and integrity warrant it, might bear ≈øome weight, but there is nothing in the ballance again≈øt Iu≈øtice but wind and du≈øt; This Machivellian rea≈øon is of the corrupt Court, viz. men by the≈øe private litigations, wranglings and contentions, are fired in ≈øpirit each again≈øt other, and ≈øo are taken off projects again≈øt the publick peace of the Nation; but a Chri≈øtian will ea≈øily beleeve this rea≈øon heightens both publick and private vengeance.

Be≈øides this blind rea≈øon makes no di≈øtinction betwixt poor and rich, ju≈øt and wicked men; but put all to the Oare, and let them tug for Ma≈øtery, and the Lawyer ≈øets on the bank, and with their labour is carried into the Ocean of ≈øo gotten riches; this I pre≈øume ≈øufficiently evidences that the Laws ought to be without any que≈øtion in the Native Tongue, plain, and few, and nigh at hand.

Next let us know how we ≈øhould have them admini≈øtred, wherein waving the private intere≈øts afore≈øaid, the matter will be plain; for it is agreed on all ≈øides, That Iu≈øtice ought not to be delayed, no more then denyed, or ≈øold; the Subject demanding this, had no more but Iu≈øtice, when it was granted in the ≈øo called Magna Charta.

Now I ≈øuppo≈øe this delay mu≈øt intend, not the cu≈øtomary time of lawing, but the due time, and that peremptorily, except in ca≈øes of ≈øo called E≈ø≈øoyn, that is, when ≈øuch due ca≈øe in Law appears, as all rea≈øon mu≈øt agree there can be no proceeding but with greater wrong to the other party, then the ≈øtay can be to this, which is inju≈øtice; but the truth is, to have ≈øo many reiterated ≈øummons, formal and co≈øtly, for ≈ømall cau≈øes, is, yea though it were Law, that is formerly ≈øo either e≈øtabli≈øhed or practi≈øed, unfit to be ≈øo continued.

And in many ca≈øes, formal proce≈ø≈øes are vain, dilatory and ruinous; and the Subjects priviledge is (that is ju≈øt mens) to have all ≈øuch excre≈øcences cut off, and meet Medicine applyed to the wound; the want of which, after ≈øo many Vows, Covenants, Promi≈øes, Engagements, &c. giveth ≈øpirit to the enemy, and ≈øets an edge upon their reproaches, and deadens the hearts of all true friends to Iu≈øtice and Righteou≈øne≈øs.

Some Nations would never ≈øuffer the Sun to ri≈øe upon a crime unpuni≈øhed, committed after the Sun went down; and ≈øo not go down before puni≈øhed, if acted after Sun-ri≈øe; you mu≈øt ≈øuppo≈øe complained of, and po≈ø≈øible to be effected.

But the meaning is, their puni≈øhment was immediate; others gave three days, others fourteen dayes: Now the be≈øt men alwayes give the lea≈øt time, yet enough; delayes, whether in criminall or Civil Ca≈øes, alwayes are the nouri≈øhers of corrupt ends, if not perjuries; our Judicatories are for Civil Ca≈øes in ≈øome places weekly; but the bu≈øine≈øs in formality depends a quarter, half, and ≈øometimes a whole year; let there be ju≈øtice done under a penalty: Now the trick is, delay till the Witne≈øs be gone, or hath forgotten it, or can be wrought off, or the Jury fitted to the turn.

The Heathens abhorred what Chri≈øtians practice, for the Criminal part; the Se≈ø≈øions are or ought to be four times in the year; but the now Lawyers are ≈øo afraid of their own Law; for it is ≈øo doubtful, that few but the Superiour Judges (who by rea≈øon of their places mu≈øt) do or will under≈øtand it.

And hence men for ordinary acts lie ≈øometimes twelve moneths, two years in pri≈øon by Adjournments, and no penalty upon the Iudge; for he is ≈øeldom evidently faulty, but the Clerks; no Commi≈ø≈øion to try him, or a defective one, whereby the pri≈øoner is without all Remedy.

Next the Proce≈ø≈øes for the Tryal before the Iudges, are not every mans purcha≈øe, and the appeal being onely to London, the charge which rich men and free men count nothing of, is to poor men de≈øtructive and un≈øufferable.

And we had need call for ≈øetled Courts and Laws, and the Judges to determine by a day, under a Fine or Penalty; for in Arbitrary ones, and ≈øo remote as London from many parts, and the Clyent mu≈øt go him≈øelf, or his ca≈øe is lo≈øt
and undone, where orders are gotten to day, and then the party out of Town, revoked to morrow, and Order upon Order, Term after Term, and Judges ≈øittings uncertain, onely when they can be per≈øwaded together.

What is it but the Aby≈øs of confu≈øion, and that which threats mo≈øt direful plagues and judgements to the Nation? let the honour of the Nation be never ≈øo much pretended, yea though the≈øe acts were done to enemies both of God and men ≈øolely and onely; For pure and holy Ju≈øtice is pro≈øtituted, if not ravi≈øhed, nay is then made the Bawd to each exorbitant pa≈ø≈øion and affection.

Wi≈øe and Ju≈øt Law-givers mu≈øt therefore ≈øettle Courts in due and fit places, times frequent and ordinary, yea if it were every day, and enforce pro≈øecution under due penalties; And in ca≈øe of appeals (while appeals) which in re≈øpect of difficulties, and that of moment, may be betwixt per≈øons mean and of ≈ømall ability, that they be ≈øetled in due places, and ordered in ≈øuch manner that Right may be done to the meane≈øt, not as in the formal way of ≈øo called Forma Pauperis, and all the Proce≈ø≈øes thence i≈ø≈øuing, where the cau≈øe is determinable, all Dilatory Pleas excluded, and errors of cour≈øe amended, and no error pleaded after i≈ø≈øue joyned.
The≈øe are principal priviledges of free Subjects; but indeed the highe≈øt and greate≈øt are lea≈øt under≈øtood, or regarded by the many.

Now whether the≈øe Laws be admini≈øtred in the Towns, Hundreds, &c. is in the Supream Magi≈øtrate; ≈øurely in the County and in a due place there, both for convenience of Travaile, and Reception of Suitors, not in Confinio Comitatus.

The rea≈øons for and again≈øt this, will not be worth the while, they holding forth nothing of moment, more then what is before declared; onely this, That by this means every County will have a various Law, and carried according to particular intere≈øts of places and per≈øons; but this is not be e≈øteemed; for we allow the Supream power the enacting the head Law.

So that the Law will be the ≈øame, though the di≈øpen≈øation may be diver≈øe then as it is now, and ever will be; for bind what you can, a wi≈øe Iudge will have or make to him≈øelf a latitude; but if truly wi≈øe, who will grudge? while Iu≈øtice indeed is his onely ayme and end.

But to avoid ≈øuch and the like Objections; If the Supream power ≈øettle County Courts, both for Law and equity; and admit once yearly itinerate Iudges, to receive the complaints of Suitors again≈øt all other Iudges; and for determining difficult matters in Law, after the manner of the now A≈ø≈øizes, it will take away all the grounds of intere≈øted objections again≈øt the nece≈ø≈øary admini≈øtrations of Provincial or County Juri≈ødictions, which ≈øome frame from the rea≈øons of County, as Congregational, Independency, or their ≈øeares of introducing the Churches giving an Analogicall Rule, at lea≈øt, of exteriour Governement, to the Commonwealth.

Now having taken this ≈øhort view of the Laws Admini≈øtration, let us in the next place con≈øider the Qualifications of the Law-giver, and Law-di≈øpen≈øer, whereby Iu≈øtice may be executed ju≈øtly, and how to be cho≈øen.

div.head: Qualifications nece≈ø≈øary in Judges; who are to be their Electors; Judges Duties; and Defaults how to be puni≈øhed, and in them concerning all Officers of Tru≈øt.
div.p: IUdges in all their degrees are in the heights of Civil Tru≈øts, they are the Pillars indeed of the Commonwealth; their general Duties are three.
Fir≈øt, to enact good Laws and ju≈øt.
Secondly, to ≈øee them duly executed.
Thirdly, to alter them according to nece≈ø≈øity.

All the≈øe belongs properly and more immediately to the ≈øupream Magi≈øtrate; but ≈øecondarily, and within limits, and according to power all ought to act; like the wheels in a Watch, the one ought to move the other; but the fir≈øt mover hath the ≈øpecial tru≈øt; for all move right or wrong as they do.
Now though the Judges be of ≈øeveral ≈øorts: yet all of them in ≈øome qualifications hold a Rule of proportion.
As fir≈øt they ought really to be fit for the work to which they are entru≈øted.

But this intimates plainly, that the higher the tru≈øt, the more exactne≈øs is required; and the greater ≈øtrictne≈øs, upon legal enquiry, ought to be u≈øed in their both choyce and approbation. To ≈øettle humane things in a humane way perfectly, it is an error to conceive or attempt;

But to aime at the greate≈øt height of perfection po≈ø≈øible, is a duty; therefore in the fir≈øt place, all in places of eminent tru≈øt, ought to be of full and fit age; fir≈øt of full age, which is commonly reputed not under one and twenty years; for though a ripe wit may in the inventive part, in quickne≈øs of apprehen≈øion, and vivacity of ≈øpirit outgo another, yet in the di≈øqui≈øition of parts and ≈øetling the mo≈øt convenient upon a ≈øure judgement, to which experience is requi≈øite, more years ≈øuit be≈øt, and are mo≈øt approvable.

Now as too few years are light, neglective, and ≈øubject to ra≈øhne≈øs, ≈øo al≈øo too many years are froward, heavy and ≈øubject to wilfulne≈øs; Therefore the be≈øt rule is for a wi≈øe Commonwealth to fix an age, before which, and after which, no one ≈øhall be capable (no not with a non ob≈øtante) of ≈øuch tru≈øts.

Our Law, however practized, and e≈øpecially in the ≈øupream tru≈øts, holds forth ≈øuch a Rule; he that is not thought meet to rule him≈øelf, cannot be allowed to govern another; and if he cannot rule according to Law, how unfit is he to be a promulgator of Law? And the be≈øt way is to make ≈øuch choyces ab≈øolutely void.

For the exce≈øs of Age, ≈øixty is accounted a time to cea≈øe Arms, and betake to prayers. I pre≈øcribe not, but cannot finde a fitter. Nature may often ≈øhorten; She ≈øeldome lengthens that date with that Activity which is requi≈øite in all ≈øuch places.

Having done with the age, the next Qualification is ability, not of the body ≈øo much as of the mind; The ignorance of the Judge may be the ruine of the innocent; therefore it is not ≈øufficient that a man hath been Trained up in the profe≈ø≈øion, nor hath been a Reader, no not if he ≈øpent one thou≈øand pound in the Kitchin; but he ought to be wi≈øe among wi≈øe men, who is to rule fools, then ≈øo much more if he be to rule wi≈øe men al≈øo, who may offend; and prudence may reclaim when power is contemned.

The next Qualification is, he mu≈øt be free from all po≈ø≈øible obligations to inju≈øtice in any kind; therefore it was unju≈øt in the King to ≈øeek ≈øuch a dependance upon his meer will from the Judges, that they might thereby be drawn from the ≈øtreight path of Ju≈øtice.

And it is the ≈øame in all other ≈øupreams; It is truth there is an upright man whom no temptation can mi≈ølead; but we are to provide again≈øt errors; vertue needs no curb, the ju≈øt man is a Law to him≈øelf.

Now it is known, Dependance is various in its workings, according to the nature of the man depending; for a timerous nature may ≈øervilely do the Princes Will, without any regard either to honor, or reward; but few ingenuous ≈øpirits are of that muddy temper; the great Mi≈øleaders, are Pride or Ambition, Revenge or Anger, Coveteou≈øne≈øs or de≈øire of Gain.

Now there are to be Qualifications requi≈øite in every Judge again≈øt the≈øe; for the≈øe mi≈øleadings vices, or any of them, will otherwi≈øe turn the publike Ax again≈øt the private Enemy; there is therefore great care to be taken at all times, in all choice of men to places of Tru≈øt, but e≈øpecially in times of the ≈øhakings of Nations, for then the wi≈øe man mu≈øt ≈øave the City, how unthought of, how poor ≈øoever.

Now to prevent the≈øe, the wi≈ødom of former Ages and Nations have all appointed a ≈øet and bountiful allowance for all Judges, which ≈øtirs up able and active ≈øpirits to eminency of vertue, (which can be never extraordinary, in a meer letter Law, where each Ca≈øe particularly mu≈øt have its examplar) All Nations heretofore agreed puni≈øhments for Judges, and all in the mo≈øt excellent tru≈øts, not onely u≈øeful but of nece≈ø≈øity; ≈øome went ≈øo far, through the fear of Tyranny and Oppre≈ø≈øion by men of eminent parts, that extraordinary abilities were ob≈øcured; for the complaint admitted no Trial, Bani≈øhment mu≈øt en≈øue; after-times tempered this Laconici≈øm; finding it was the laying open the State to many Tyrants and Tyrannies to prevent one, that the thing it ≈øelf was the greate≈øt Tyrannie of all. This la≈øt Age went about by all means to explode any que≈øtion of Judges; nay, the Officers of Courts were ≈øo friended, that there was no ≈øeeking Ju≈øtice again≈øt them; but of this more after.
In all Judicial places this is fit, That the Judge have his Salary ≈øet, his publike Fee from the Prince or State; now in this one word to this purpo≈øe (viz.)

The Judge receiving this Fee from the State, this is a publike Fee, wherein each Subject hath his portion; and the duty of the Judge in it is, equally to care for the intere≈øt of both Prince and People or Subject; for the end and re≈øpect of Ju≈øtice is not per≈øonal but univer≈øal; for the qualification of not Covetous, it is of nece≈ø≈øity in a Iudge; therefore as before he is to have a due Salary; ≈øo he is not to take ought above his Salary, at lea≈øt as a Fee: There is much ≈øcandal at this day in Chri≈øtian Commonwealths concerning Bribery.

In Turky it were no wonder, though till corruption through pro≈øperity u≈øhered in the way, it was a wonder, and a ≈øtrange one among them; but that with them a≈ø≈øures their fall near; for this is like a deadly ≈øore, which if in the Judges, infects the heart, at lea≈øt the prime vital parts of the Commonwealth, and then ≈øure death mu≈øt follow.
Thefore it is requi≈øite to have this wound ≈øearched to the bottome; Some for this ca≈øe have been ≈øo ≈øtrict, that they would not admir a Judge to hold familiarity with a father, or a brother.

Some not to take a meale, nor any gift, though never ≈øo ≈ømall; others have particularly ≈øet down what they may take; and that may do well if they peremptorily conclude that all not expre≈ø≈øed is included in the negative.

From this I ≈øhall take liberty to exemplifie; It is not fit any Iudge receive a Newyears Gift, Gown, Cloth, Veni≈øon, Mutton, or the like, from any practizer at the Law, as well as from a Suiter at Law; for though I would not, nor can I a≈øper≈øe any in place of Authority, yet the≈øe things having been found evil and inconvenient, it is evident then that evil may be.

And as good men mu≈øt ≈øhun the appearances of evil, ≈øo wi≈øe Magi≈øtrates mu≈øt take away all things giving ju≈øt occa≈øion of ≈øu≈øpition; therefore it is nece≈ø≈øary, not onely to have the≈øe things ≈øetled by the publike Supream Magi≈øtrate, but al≈øo publi≈øhed, that ≈øo each man may know his duty; and for this ca≈øe it is thought inconvenient any one that takes a particular Fee of any man to be intru≈øted judicially; for many a≈øper≈øions have lain upon Iu≈øtices of Peace, Coun≈øellors, whether de≈øervedly, or not, I cannot affirm; but it is ju≈øtly ≈øu≈øpected, when they have been more fully informed of the Ca≈øe, and pleaded more earne≈øtly then the retained Lawyer for his vi≈øible Fee; but this is the pre≈øent Opinion and thought of many, who al≈øo conceive it ju≈øt, that a Iudge attempted by Bribery, ≈øhould complain to a Iudge duely appointed, and the bribe-offerer convicted to be puni≈øhed as well as the bribe-taker; for neither in the Politikes of Chri≈øtianity will be allowed.

The next Qualification of a Judge is fearing God in the Law; in the Go≈øpel it is the ≈øame, but hath many parts; for ≈øure his qualification ought at le≈øt to be as high as a (≈øuppo≈øed lay) Elder; then he mu≈øt be in Church Communion, and not onely not given to filthy lucre, but ≈øober or grave in his behaviour, ruling well his own Family, (which now admitted, it is a hard matter to fill the ordinary ≈øeats in We≈øtmin≈øter; for ≈øuch is the loo≈øene≈øs of all Government, that Government is e≈øteemed har≈øhne≈øs, cruelty, oppre≈ø≈øion, tyranny, and wor≈øe, if wor≈øe may be;) but this is enough to a wi≈øe man; onely this, he mu≈øt not be ≈øubject to Anger, that is overcome of it.

And it is the duty of the Chu≈øers of the≈øe men, not to ≈øatisfie them≈øelves ≈øleightly in the≈øe qualifications, nor of the people too readily to a≈øper≈øe; for unle≈øs defects be evident and notorious, Wi≈ødom will cover on the one hand, and fear of puni≈øhment, if that be readily allowed, bridle on the other; for there will be ≈øuch an awe upon ≈øpirits, that whom love of duty and vertue cannot prevail over, fear of vengeance will.

I come now to con≈øider by whom the Judges are to be appointed; to which it is ea≈øie to re≈øolve, That it properly belongs to the body Repre≈øentative, none fitter in ordinary cour≈øe, unle≈øs otherwi≈øe ordered by the Supream Power, according to the e≈øtabli≈øhment of a Nation; for a≈ø≈øuredly the chief Judges are the Arteries of the Commonwealth, and therefore a due and ju≈øt dependance upon the Supream Power is requi≈øite, but never would the Supream look to all admini≈øtrations.

And if Judges be in Provinces or Counties as is due, not onely the ≈øedentary at the elbow of the Supremacy, but the chief in the Counties, ought to be at lea≈øt allowed and authori≈øed (though the nomination may be in the County) by the Supremacy; but that all be done in this kinde, by an open plain known publike Law, is mo≈øt requi≈øite.

Now before we come to the duties of Judges, we mu≈øt ≈øhew the nece≈ø≈øity of excellent Qualifications in Judges in point of due temper both of pa≈ø≈øions and affections; for it is before a≈ø≈øerted, that the Judge mu≈øt be bound by a head Law, which takes away the pure Arbitrium, and al≈øo to puni≈øhments which he may not exceed, and that both corporal (and that as well to re≈øtraint of Liberty, as Correction ≈øo called) as criminal or pur≈ø-paiment.

And this Prudence allows an extraordinary care in the due choice, or ≈øpeedy care in removeal of unfit Judges, which is that principally can free from diver≈øity of Laws, according to the divers natures of men, in regard of which diver≈øity of ≈øpirits as fierce and untractable, and quiet and meek, the Magi≈øtrate, as before, ought to have power above what is at all times and to all per≈øons fitting to be u≈øed.

We have ≈øeen that the want of this, and putting men for riches, or Family ≈øake, or other outward relations (as of breeding and the like, but no way improveing them) in place and honored with judicial tru≈øts, yea though but a Ju≈øtice of the Peace, hath made Ju≈øtice it ≈øelf either from weakne≈øs or wickedne≈øs di≈øe≈øteemed; whereas let nothing draw from the natural rational Rule, and you ≈øhall ≈øee Ju≈øtice carry that due Splendor and Maje≈øty, which properly belongs to tho≈øe who bear the Image of Gods name in a more e≈øpecial manner.
Among Judges, I al≈øo mu≈øt intend not onely Ju≈øtices of the Peace, but Con≈øtables, yea and Jurors, who now are made of men of no e≈øteem, and ≈øo ju≈øtly di≈øe≈øteemed.

For Jurors, if they were but bare Judges of fact, yet in that they are Judges, and ought to have their qualifications accordingly; for e≈øtate in them it is nece≈ø≈øary, becau≈øe their disburthen is by dammage.

But as to other qualifications, re≈øpectively as others; for the choi≈øe of Judges, as the the Supream ought to chu≈øe the next immediate; ≈øo it ≈øeems to ≈øome, that the Judges gradually ought to chu≈øe; but that ≈øavors more of form then ≈øub≈øtance; for the nece≈ø≈øity lieth not in the Judge≈øhip, but Supremacy, which if wholly in the order of Supremacy, devolves into Tyranny naturally, as on the other hand into confu≈øion if wholly in the populacy.
To place it in the Judges, is ≈øolely to e≈øtabli≈øh intere≈øt, which yet being mo≈øt inconvenient, is to be waved with greate≈øt ≈øeverity and care.
And it ≈øeemeth be≈øt to place the choice of inferior Judges in ≈øome certain men of the people, duly qualified with due regulations of nece≈ø≈øity to be ob≈øerved.
One word to their duty, which will on the contrary evidence defaults.

The duty of Judges therefore is twofold; fir≈øt, to hold forth practically as well as
literally the true and proper ≈øen≈øe of the Law, and not to admit Formality, Practi≈øe, or Cu≈øtome again≈øt the letter, while the letter holds forth ought of Ju≈øtice, in the ≈øetled State at lea≈øt; for that liberty brings all Laws into the meer will of the Judge.

Secondly, where they perceive error in Law, which gives ju≈øt cau≈øe of exception, its their duty to declare the ≈øame publikely to the Supream Magi≈øtrate, with a fit expedient, who≈øe duty it is to enact a due remedy, and e≈øtabli≈øh the ≈øame accordinly, if upon inqui≈øition the ≈øame be found ju≈øt, otherwi≈øe not; and if they do not, they perform not the tru≈øt repo≈øed in them; for the Supream Magi≈øtrate, though in the Democratike State (where mo≈øt eyes and ears are at work, and jealou≈øies be highe≈øt) cannot di≈øcern each dangerous obliquity in legal admini≈øtrations; therefore they who are intru≈øted, ≈øhould in their places con≈øult for preventing evils as well as for remedying; and this is to have Judges as at fir≈øt.

Their puni≈øhments cannot be pre≈øcribed but according to the nature of other offences, life with life, dammage with dammage, &c. But alwayes provided that the error was intentional, and except the guilt were notorious, to di≈øcharge upon Oath, but withall to lo≈øe his place.

And to avoid all ≈øcruples concerning Magi≈øtrates Elections, as al≈øo for making and enacting due and fit Laws, and knowing the errors of Magi≈øtrates in all places, that there be re≈øpectively fixed places and ≈øure appointed into which it ≈øhould be lawful for any man after promulgation of a Law, or nomination of a Judge, to ≈øet down his Opinions and Rea≈øons, for, or again≈øt the altering, or annulling, or rejecting the Law or Judge, before the Law be e≈øtabli≈øhed, or the Judge confirmed, with a mark, no name to appear to make good if required upon the mark, otherwi≈øe the note to be rejected; and the≈øe kept by ≈øome ≈øworn men under ≈øtrict penalties.
I ≈øhall not treat how far ignorance of any ≈øort excu≈øes; there is enough to hint the general rea≈øon before; I now proceed and Quaere

div.head: Whether the execution of Laws ought to be all after one maner, and all Courts to have the ≈øame Juri≈ødiction, Officers, Proceedings and Fees?
div.p: AS to the Execution of Laws, provided the head Rule be ob≈øerved, that is, life to an≈øwer life, &c. A≈ø≈øuredly the Magi≈øtrate hath the ab≈øolute power to mitigate or inforce as he ≈øees oca≈øion, (take execution for the way of puni≈øhing offenders in any kind;) but if you take it for the Uniformity or Identity of Law in all Counties, ≈øurely there the Law ought to be the ≈øame, if Rea≈øon be the ≈øame.

I dare not a≈ø≈øert it of certainty to be of nece≈ø≈øity that all Chri≈øtians live by the like particular Laws; but I believe that as Nature holds forth but one light to men, and God but one Law to Chri≈øtians; ≈øo that it is mo≈øt clear, and the fitte≈øt way to avoid the ordinary jangles, as afore≈øaid, to ≈øettle that head-Law as our Rule, and to draw by all ju≈øt means to the like con≈øonancy of Rea≈øon in the di≈øtributive, as in the con≈øtitutive part of Law.

And this doth not (as I in all humility conceive) at all cla≈øh with the≈øe tling of Provincial Courts, while as before the whole Law flows from the ≈øame fountain of Supremacy in the head-pipe of ≈øedentary order of Judges, or a fit number to over-≈øee the whole Nation by way of yearly Circuits, admitting, and determining Complaints, again≈øt even ordinary Judges, and that without or Fine or Fee, and determining matters difficult in Law, or referring it to con≈øulation, after; but determining without further expence, and in a certain time; for as before, the Judge, and ≈øo all Officers publike, ought to be paid out of the publike pur≈øe; But the≈øe Judges al≈øo mu≈øt be bounded what pre≈øents they may take, and from whom.
This will ≈øilence all jangles, and the Engli≈øhman ≈øhall know his Law wherever he cometh in his own Nation.

Now as to the ordinary Courts, or Hundreds, it is requi≈øite to have all Officers, proceedings, and fees alike; not that it is intended the Hundred Court ≈øhould have the ≈øame with the County, or &c. or the Me≈ø≈øenger that goes ten miles, no more then he that goes but two; nor he that ingro≈ø≈øes or writes ten ≈øheets, as he that doth but five.

But at a due known allowed rate for all, e≈øtabli≈øhed by vi≈øible and plain Law, Publike, and in Print; and that in ≈øuch manner, that the long hanging of a Cau≈øe in Court,
or multitude of Writs, or warnings of Juries ≈øhould not advantage Officers, or as bad as amerce Suitors.
But that the Judge be fineable; let the pro≈øecutor be inforced to proceed, or his Ca≈øe di≈ømi≈ø≈øed with Fine for unju≈øt clamor and litigation.
Next, all Writs or Proce≈ø≈øes are to be had in the County, and all returnable at one time, be it one, two, three or four dayes or weeks.

div.head: How Appeals are to be admitted, and fal≈øe Judgements remedied and puni≈øhed.
div.p: THis ≈øeems to receive ≈øatisfaction in ≈øome foregoing Con≈øiderations; but in regard that all cannot be ≈øaid at once, I ≈øhall ≈øhortly inlarge; Appealing (in this Que≈øtion) is no more then the waving of the Court, and going to a higher, for ≈øo of nece≈ø≈øity it mu≈øt be.
This I mu≈øt agree is nece≈ø≈øary; but though I allow Appeals, I admit not the many gradations.

The rea≈øon why this grew ≈øo common, was, the meanne≈øs of Judges in County Courts, which was ordinarily put off with an Attorneyes man; but wi≈øe men will ≈øuppo≈øe that the qualifications mu≈øt be intended in righteous Judicatories, according to the tru≈øt; therefore we will ≈øuppo≈øe the County ≈øupplied with able Judges, &c.
I thefore Quaere, what may cau≈øe an Appeal; may fear of inju≈øtice?
No, it ought not to be ≈øuppo≈øed.
But may greatne≈øs of dammage?

No; for the difficulty mu≈øt be either matter of Fact or Law; for Fact, there ought not to be any removeal; rather let ≈øuch extraordinary Ca≈øes (if what need not be ≈øuppo≈øed, mu≈øt be) be delayed, till the Itinerant Judges come down as now.

For the difficulties will be onely or ≈øpecially in Criminals; for other great doubts are generally Titles; and ≈øurely they are cu≈øtomarily made more difficult then they are; however particular right of particular per≈øons ought not to admi≈øt ≈øuch publike hurries, though gain hath guilded fair the rotten po≈øts of intere≈øted Rea≈øon.
But there may yet be Rea≈øons of Appeal, as in Ca≈øe the ≈øuit ari≈øeth between one in the utmo≈øt bound North, with one in the utmo≈øt bound South, or in divers Counties.
Now this mu≈øt have a Rule to ≈øettle in which County, as where the wrong was done, debt to be paid, or &c.

Or el≈øe in a certain middle County; in ca≈øe of not ob≈øerving which Rule, an Appeal ought to be admitted to the Sedentary Judges out of their Circuits otherwaies in, and to be determined at their return, (or by the Judges of both Counties, if adjoyning in the bounds of the County where the wronged per≈øon dwels.)

But the≈øe Appeals are to be allowed under the hands of the Judges of the County, when admitted, and ≈øo by them transferred to the Superior; and if the Appeal be not ju≈øtly grounded, and ≈øpeedily ordered, the Judge to be puni≈øhed, for that he is the Author of delay; but if upon con≈øultation the Ca≈øe be difficult, there mu≈øt be a Certificate to the Superior Judges of the truth of the Ca≈øe atte≈øted by the Complainer, who mu≈øt make it good within a ≈øet time, or the Appeal to be qua≈øhed, and he fined, but the Judges excu≈øed.

Now as to the remedying of fal≈øe Judgements, mo≈øt certainly Writs of Error were ju≈øtly made u≈øe of and allowed, and the notion of fal≈øe judgement for ≈øo thought good rea≈øon waved, and ≈øo complaints ought to be as afore≈øaid; but this mu≈øt not attend the propounded A≈ø≈øi≈øes without ≈øatisfying the Judgment pre≈øently, yea though it be fal≈øe.

Next no error but to be allowed before the Writ i≈ø≈øues forth; for to purcha≈øe the Writ of Cour≈øe, and A≈ø≈øign one Error or more of cour≈øe this Term, then more the next, and then a peremptory day, and then Errors Ca≈ø≈øed, is but legal extortion.
So that it is plain, to take errors totally away, is as bad as to have all allowed; but to prevent the mi≈øchief, let a certain day in Court be to determine errors before i≈ø≈øue, and not after.

Now the puni≈øhments in the≈øe defaults, are and mu≈øt be pecuniary, and that both in the Judges of Fact as Jurors as well as Law; but where the default is evident, there ought to be a di≈øpriviledging for future as to all publike tru≈øts (at lea≈øt for a time) but
out of the Judicial place pre≈øently, yea though the oath be that he was onely mi≈øtaken in Law, and did not do it at all maliciou≈øly, or with a minde of inju≈øtice.
Now to oaths, it is fit any Ju≈øtice of the Peace ≈øhould give it at di≈øcretion; this requires able Judges, and ≈øo ≈øhould Judges be; but of this more in due place.

div.head: Concerning what things the Magi≈øtrate may and ought to make Laws.
div.p: YOu heard before, that there mu≈øt re≈øt in ≈øome per≈øons thereto de≈øigned, either by God, as tho≈øe who claym to rule by ab≈øolute power, or by men, as tho≈øe who rule by Compact or Convention, as who either had no power, but were meerly elected, and agreed with, having no Right primarily; or had ≈øome power, but not enough, and ≈øo condi≈øcended to ≈øome rule, that they might rule a≈ø≈øuredly.

Now this being in one per≈øon, or more, yet the power ought to extend to all things ju≈øtly nece≈ø≈øary to the well being of a Commonwealth; and therefore they have re≈øpectively the general powers of war and peace, life and death.

But becau≈øe we have before hinted, that there was a nece≈ø≈øity of the Magi≈øtrates regulating of tho≈øe things which many men call di≈øpriviledge to Chri≈øtians as well as men, we will according to the rule before laid, that is of the head Law, according to Gods own Law, the God of Chri≈øtians as of the Jew, ≈øee the Government of rea≈øon laid there down both for Divine and Civil wor≈øhip.
Wherein fir≈øt it ≈øeems directly given to the Magi≈øtrate, to have the ordering of divine wor≈øhip to God under the Law.
Now let us ≈øee how this works; for ∆≤zziah is a Leper for acting in the Prie≈øts Office.

Yet the aberrations both of Prie≈øt and People are laid to the Kings charge; and the good Kings commanding ju≈øt things, and not onely ≈øo, but ≈øeeing of them performed, are ble≈ø≈øed; and on the contrary, the evil Kings puni≈øhed, and their Adherents: And tho≈øe di≈øobedient to the King, as (to Ahab) the ≈øeven thou≈øand that never bowed knee to Baal, were tho≈øe who were to take root downward, and bring forth fruit upward.

Now the great difficulty is, to ≈øettle the Magi≈øtrates power ≈øo that he may not bring ≈øin upon him≈øelf and the Nation, by commanding or tolerating things evil and unju≈øt, or unju≈øtly enforcing things ju≈øt and good.

Now as to this, it is to be con≈øidered, that we all profe≈øs Grace is from Heaven, the meer gift of God, and that the Spirit breatheth where it plea≈øeth, as the wind bloweth where it li≈øteth; if ≈øo, the Magi≈øtrate,
Yea grant there were a clear Church Magi≈øtrate, that were by divine Word impowred with the Sword of Paul as the Keys of Peter; could he go further then the outward man? it is plain he could not.

Next then, grant no ≈øuch Magi≈øtrate, ≈øure the Civil (or in ca≈øe of doubt of Spiritual Power) the Civil Magi≈øtrate onely can act clearly; Now for the Spiritual Power to be helped out with the Civil Sword, ≈øurely it is one of the gro≈ø≈øe≈øt vanities that Popery ever broached.
