Let the Ma≈øters interchangeably have times of re≈øpit for extraordinary occa≈øions; This will ≈øpeedily give a large increa≈øe for knowledge, which will make that your Magi≈øtrates in all places may be men of knowledge, which will embelli≈øh the Commonwealth; whereas now mo≈øt Cities, Towns, yea I may ≈øay Counties are de≈øpi≈øed in Government for default of prudent knowing men: A long Robe-man or two guide all, and in this Age of intere≈øt, and the≈øe mens intere≈øts ≈øo vi≈øible as afore≈øaid, all is let run to confu≈øion.
And by this will al≈øo the ≈øeveral Congregations be fitted with able knowing Pa≈øtors, and Teachers; yea hone≈øt vertuous emulation in ingenuous ≈øpirits, will render almo≈øt every Member a Doctor.
This is ≈øeemingly a matter of great charge; therefore before I proceed, I will ≈øee how charges are to be born, rai≈øed, &c. And the relief of Commonwealths in exce≈ø≈øive burthens of people.

div.head: How all the Charges of the Commonwealth, Fees, and Fines, &c. are to be A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed and rai≈øed, and by what Rule.
And the wayes to ea≈øe Nations when grown over-numerous.
div.p: I Know that many will ≈øay this is good in Speculation, but the Practi≈øe is difficult, yea ≈øome will ≈øay impo≈ø≈øible; for you cannot get all men of one mind to it; others that it is again≈øt Priviledge to inforce children from the Parents Tuition, who being Guardians by Nature, the Law will not, may not, admit any Rule to bar his Right?
Others, This is a matter requiring great and va≈øt expence, and how ≈øhall it be rai≈øed.
To the fir≈øt I an≈øwer; If the Magi≈øtrate hath power to make the Law, then duty ought to ≈øubject all minds to unity in obedience.

To the ≈øecond I an≈øwer, That this is ≈øo far from di≈øpriviledging, that it is the highe≈øt, yea the top ≈øtone of Liberty; I dare not ≈øay it is not po≈ø≈øible to abu≈øe or mi≈øu≈øe this power; but if rightly u≈øed, it is the extent of Priviledge; for may a Magi≈øtrate make a Law to keep mad mens children, to educate Ideots, Lunaticks, and the like, and di≈øpo≈øe their goods, to the nece≈ø≈øary u≈øe of their Family, which all Laws of Nature and Nations allow?
Who art thou then Quaerie≈øt? if thou do≈øt it thy ≈øelf, thou wilt grant that mu≈øt be by allowed means and lawful wayes.

I ≈øay not That there cannot be ju≈øt cau≈øes of Negation, but I ≈øay Submit to ju≈øt things in their Sea≈øons, it is your duty; and deny unju≈øt ones when time of trial comes, that is your duty al≈øo. This takes not away your Guardian≈øhip of Nature, but makes your load lighter, e≈øpecially when and where it is greate≈øt; for the mo≈øt poor and ignorant are mo≈øt like to brable and wrangle ≈øuch intendments; for the charge, I confe≈øs its great; but the great Lett will be, if you ≈øettle this aright, the rich mu≈øt pay for the education of the poor, and the barren of them that have children.

For I can allow nothing of a Rate but by an equal pound Rate, and that on all the
e≈øtates of all per≈øons, and that not onely for Wars but for the poor; for maintenance of Mini≈øters, yea for Bridges, Cau≈øywayes, Highwayes, all publike Meeting-places, and that both for Divine and Civil affairs; if you ≈øettle it no higher then Counties at fir≈øt, it may do ≈øomething; but in a young or begun State, it is requi≈øite to ca≈øt all into a lump; were Righteou≈øne≈øs obvious in the di≈øpo≈øers, it would ea≈øily be a≈ø≈øented to.

But now the fear is, and Objections are, if you do thus, the Parliament men will look to di≈øtribution of parts mo≈øt unequally; and they that are be≈øt friended ≈øhall have the be≈øt proportion, though they have lea≈øt need.
As now in general Leavies, The Towns and Counties are mo≈øt free or burthened, as they have active Parliament men, Committee men and Ju≈øtices of the Peace to ≈øtand by them.

Therefore fir≈øt it is requi≈øite that each man ≈øhew forth integrity in his actions, ca≈øt away ≈øelfi≈øhne≈øs; own in deeds what you profe≈øs; be not deceived, God cannot be mocked; The Heathens at the preaching of Je≈øus, yea the Wi≈øe men, they that u≈øed curious Arts, brought their Books of great price and burnt them; come and do likewi≈øe with your advantageous intere≈øts of all ≈øorts; you are all a Nation without ≈øcruple, though no National Church. But you object further:
This Nation hath lo≈øt its Politike Rule, it is over≈øpread with multitudes of men, nay multitudes of poor; ≈øo that to take care for the educating of all the≈øe, is, you ≈øay, wholly unfeazable.
To this I ≈øay, That no Nation, if not plagued with War or Di≈øea≈øes, but naturally it will grow over-numerous.

Now the Magi≈øtrate Supream ought truly to know the contents of his Territory, and be as able to lay out the po≈ø≈øible ≈øub≈øi≈øtance of his Subjects, as the wi≈øe Gra≈øier, to know how many bea≈øts will be depa≈øtured in ≈øuch a ground, or how much ≈øeed will ≈øow one Acre.

The≈øe are the My≈øteries of wi≈øe Regiments, which few Princes or Magi≈øtrates now adayes, if at any time will ≈øtudy, but it is their duty; for from not well con≈øidering the≈øe things, Nations which might in ordinary cour≈øe live quiet, being grown over populous, whereby the due care of inferior Magi≈øtrates is ob≈øtructed, they grow loo≈øe and lazy, then ≈øwarve into crimes;
Then complain of neglects of duty of Magi≈øtrates which is evident; then intere≈øt gains head, the≈øe make parties, and then the Sate is either embroiled or altered.

Therefore if the Princes will in the u≈øe of the wi≈ødom God hath given them to Rule by, Rule well and ≈øafely, they mu≈øt once every ≈øeven years number their people; if the Accidents, I mu≈øt ≈øo call them, of Plague, War, Famine, &c. hath not done it; and either by opening a fit way publikely known of ea≈øing their Counties burthen, by ≈øetling them in an other County; or if all Counties be full, by tran≈øporting them into an other Country avoid this danger.

This Act of Numeration well u≈øed, will take off the jealou≈øie to what end ≈øuch matters tend, and the well and carefully providing for the Colonies will encourage Adventurers; This will enlarge a Nation infinitely; and if well carried on, will by ju≈øt means ≈øo ≈øettle Chri≈øtian intere≈øt, that great, if not univer≈øal, will be the propagation of the Go≈øpel.
Now we ≈øend away Rogues; then you may ≈øend away Preachers, Teachers, Scholars, Ma≈øters of Prudence, in re≈øpect of Chri≈øtian and Civil knowledge.

This fitted, you ≈øee vi≈øibly your charge cannot be ≈øo in≈øupportable; you look at the Commonwealths corruptions, as now wholly ≈øick, wholly defiled, this frights you; but let your ≈øpeculations mount higher; it is not ∆≤topiani≈øme, it is Chri≈øtian wi≈øe order; all you that look for Chri≈øts Raign upon earth, labor after it.

I bid you not ≈øit down by this, this is rational, yours is divine, this may be, it hath been, yours may and is to be prayed and attended for patiently; and if it heightens you in the active part of more exemplary conver≈øation, who will oppo≈øe it, let him fir≈øt live above you, and then teach you, not upbraid your opinion.

But ≈øurely all the Taxes, Charges, Levies, Payments ought all to be ≈øet, a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, and paid according to one ≈øet Rate; ≈øo that each poor hone≈øt Countrey man may immediately re≈øolve his payment, and in ca≈øe of Refu≈øal, the Officer may know how to leavy it, namely by di≈øtre≈øs; and all to have one time, and till that time be pa≈øt, the
Magi≈øtrate ought not to i≈ø≈øue out his Warrant, and then upon a Warrant the Magi≈øtrate ≈øuperior to be ≈øued, not the Officer for levying it; for no rea≈øon he ≈øhould be que≈øtioned or mole≈øted (much le≈øs undone as now) for executing the commands of his Superior; for it is agreed the inferiour Officer in legal Admini≈øtration ought, and ≈øo may act, not que≈øtion; otherwi≈øe each Officer might delay; and therefore it is ju≈øtly con≈øtituted, if he denyes and takes upon him≈øelf the knowledge of the Law; if he mi≈øtakes he is highly finable; and his Fine, and all other Fines, and the Fees, and Salaries belonging to all publick Officers, ought to be ≈øo A≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed and leavied, &c. And where no di≈øtre≈øs is apparent, that is, no goods in the hou≈øe, be they who≈øe they will, or denyal, and they either delay or by denyal, impri≈øonment till payment, if able to pay.

I mu≈øt in this ca≈øe al≈øo remember, That it is fit that no per≈øon as no place be infranchi≈øed from payments; for if one may be, all may be, except onely as nece≈ø≈øity enforces, and then to endure no longer then the time: Kings and Officers have made great advantage of the≈øe unju≈øtices, to the in≈øupportable dammage of the Nation, and ought ≈øpeedily to be rectified; and all Grants, Charters, U≈øages, and Cu≈øtomes to that end to be void.

So have ≈øome Lords of Mannors, holding originally of the Crown, as it is called, as of the Dutchy of Lanca≈øter, got ≈øuch priviledges as they are called, which ought not to be, nor may by ju≈øt Law; for that ≈øuch priviledges are di≈øpriviledges to the whole Community, opening a door to inju≈øtice and irregularity, and con≈øequently to bondage; for all may be freed from charges, taxes, ≈øervices, and the like, as well as one; And to ≈øay it is to be pre≈øumed the Supream Magi≈øtrate will not do it, is vain; they have abu≈øed them≈øelves, and many ≈øubjects much, who have paid largely for≈øuch grants; and after the Princes have been forced to plead they were mi≈øtaken in their Grants, and the poor men have been left remedile≈øs, for their purcha≈øe money.

In the la≈øt place it is fit that all vi≈øible per≈øonal e≈øtates be rated as they appear; and people vi≈øibly rich in Apparel, Hou≈øe, Hou≈øhold-≈øtuff, Dyet, &c. be e≈øteemed as they e≈øteem them≈øelves.

Now the end of all Fines ought to be the defraying of the publick Charges of the Nation, City, or County, and the Offices there re≈øpectively; and to make the≈øe certain by compo≈øition, mu≈øt be as experience hath manife≈øted the inlet to greater corruption and abu≈øes; and though other Ages having ≈øeen the evils of the old way of compo≈øition-evil, de≈øerted that, and therefore gave Fees at large, pre≈øuming they would take their ≈øalary, and fees be≈øides; yet it is manife≈øt it was the evil of bad men; for the other is the be≈øt Law; and puni≈øh ≈øtrictly, and fear not, you ≈øhall have Ju≈øtice exact.

div.head: The Magi≈øtrates Power and Duty as to ordering of Families.
div.p: THis Power hath divers objects, as between the Husband and Wife, Parent and Childe, Ma≈øter and Servant, and ≈øo contrarily, and al≈øo the Ma≈øter of the Family and Strangers.

It is very requi≈øite to be very wary in the head Law; the Lord God only gave the power to the husband generally; Now the exerci≈øe of that power in the Jewi≈øh ≈øtate was Tyrannical and ab≈øolute, and ended generally in divorce; and what needed any inferiour Law where the head Law was ≈øo Magi≈øterial?

But this being either ob≈øolete in it ≈øelf, or made ≈øo, or both (and really the Lord Chri≈øts words intimate no ≈øeparation, except only for Adultery; and that expo≈øition is the foundation to many as they ≈øuppo≈øe ju≈øtly not to make Adultery death; for if ≈øo, what needed divorce, but this is omitted here) and we proceed.

Let us ≈øee what is the Law of the Go≈øpel; truly it teacheth a duty and obedience beyond what the rudiments of the world enable unto: Our Common Law ≈øeems to me in ≈øomething too divine as I may ≈øay; As for example, it will not admit what we evidently ≈øee (viz.) that a man cannot rule his wife; there are women which will offend the Law again≈øt the will of the Husband; and indeed it is vi≈øibly not in his power to help; they will not only ≈øell and give his goods, but break, ≈øpoyle, mi≈ø-≈øpend, &c. They will ≈øome beat the Husband, ≈øome cruelly mi≈ø-u≈øe the
children, &c. and no way to puni≈øh them, but the good man is an≈øwerable for all.

I know the wretchedne≈øs of many men, but there is a little weak Law again≈øt them; Let us al≈øo have ≈øome Law publick for the women with that tenderne≈øs is fitting to conjugal Societies; but there mu≈øt be an aw in ≈øome one or more Magi≈øtrates, even to bridle ≈øuch exorbitances and neglects on either ≈øide, and make due a provi≈øion in all ca≈øes, and that wi≈øely and ≈øpeedily; or Divorces (indeed as u≈øual) will be multiplied, and from thence Fornications and Adulteries clande≈øtine and private, make what Laws you can, though a legal divorce may be waved.

Next as to children, there is no due aw and re≈øpect of or in ≈øome, nay many Parents; the duty of the ≈øen≈øe of education is wholly lo≈øt; there is nothing but rude and exorbitant loo≈øne≈øs; not only Parents cur≈øe Children, or provide not duly for them; but Children the Parents; and for want of a head Rule, no que≈øtion is made more of this then violences in any other relations.

Now in ca≈øe of ≈øuch Rule, it is fit to proceed by a more particular Law; for if upright knowing zealous Judges be not, there is no right; therefore it is fit to make the≈øe Laws Oeconomical more particular then others.

Again, as to Parents neglecting the due provi≈øion for their family, the Magi≈øtrate is wholly beaten out of it; The rule ought to be, that the Magi≈øtrate might take cognizance, what a man can earn if imployed; next that he and his be ≈øet on work; and thirdly, that he doth not, nor ≈øhall mi≈øpend it, but that the hou≈øe-rent and all be carefully di≈øcharged; and then where labour fayles, to be ≈øupplyed by the publick Pur≈øe.

Next for ≈øervants, not each one that will to entertain ≈øervants, unle≈øs vi≈øibly able to maintaine and imploy them; for otherwi≈øe there will be many ≈øluts and more Thieves, with multitudes of Receivers, which the Law can take no notice of.
This Law mu≈øt extend to all ≈øorts of ≈øervants which have not e≈øtates to maintain them≈øelves vi≈øibly; otherwi≈øe there will be from the neglect in one, a vi≈øible carele≈øne≈øs towards all.

Let no ≈øervant under a penalty be hired, but with a publike inrolment in the Town or Precinct Pari≈øhional, or otherwayes; however neither di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, or to go into another Precinct without Licen≈øe of an Officer in Writing; this is the Law of England at pre≈øent; onely carele≈øne≈øs of Magi≈øtrates admitted pride to grow too fa≈øt in ≈øervants, and then all was omitted, and this is a main inlet to Confu≈øion.

It is al≈øo fit ≈øtrictly, by a ≈øworn Officer, to keep the Records of the Birth of Children; for the Age is now gro≈øly mi≈øtaken, and no a≈øcertained way of probation, with a ≈ømall fee, as a groat to the State to pay the Officer for enrolment, ≈øo much for ≈øearch, ≈øo much a Certificate.

For that of Strangers, it is to ≈øettle a little better the power, not only of the Ma≈øter of the Family in general, but particularly of tho≈øe who either by profe≈ø≈øion, are Inholders, or others like them, upon other accidental occa≈øions, who now are by ≈øome per≈øons made ≈øervants to their Lu≈øts, and have no power to bridle exorbitancy that they can know; for to ≈øpeak once for all, it is not enough ≈øome wi≈øe learned book-man knows all the≈øe Laws, or if all the ≈øo called Lawyers did; the Chri≈øtian Law mu≈øt plainly and per≈øpicuou≈øly hold forth to every man his certain known and a≈ø≈øured duty and power in their re≈øpective places; or the guilt, be it blood or otherwi≈øe, I fear lies e≈øpecially, if not wholly, at the Supream Magi≈øtrates door.

div.head: VVhether the Magi≈øtrate may appoint the Ages of Marriage?
And to whom the work of the Marriage belongs properly?
div.p: THe Government of the Family being ≈øetled, let us ≈øee how they part out of the Family; and that is commonly by Marriage; It is agreed, the parents did at their own Liberties di≈øpo≈øe their children; by natural rea≈øon (corrupted I conceive) they again≈øt Nature expo≈øed their children, not onely to the next hand of man that took it up by a ≈øetled place for that purpo≈øe, where they that had not the ble≈ø≈øing of children of their own bodies, might take them off others hand that had many, which hath rea≈øon in it, and undenyable; but their expo≈øings were to meer fortune, as they called it, that is, let the will of the Gods be done, let the Bea≈øts devour it, hunger or cold or both ≈øtarve it, or the merciful hand ≈øu≈øtain it and nouri≈øh it; but the≈øe are wholly rejected with us; the way is to ≈øu≈øtain them till fit for labour or Marriage.
Now that of labor is generally hinted before, none may be brought up idle.

Now for Marriage, there is much to be ≈øaid; The general plea is, the Magi≈øtrate hath no power to ≈øet an age for Marriage; The rea≈øon is generally, that there are divers times wherein Nature works with men and women; and to pre≈øcribe one certain rule for all, is unfit.
Next, it is the Parents duty to take care of that.
La≈øtly, the gift of Continencie is of God, and not of man; and the Magi≈øtrate hath no power; the fir≈øt and la≈øt I ≈øhall couple together, and an≈øwer them thus.

It is truth, divers men and women are of divers tempers and Con≈øtitutions, and therefore one time will not agree to all; but ≈øurely the matter is not whether all men or women ≈øhall marry at one age, but that there is a duty upon the Magi≈øtrate to pre≈øerve the vigour of the Nation by ≈øea≈øonable Marriages; doth it not much more concern us to breed a generation of men fit to manage bea≈øts, then to breed bea≈øts fit for management?
This natural ≈øimilar rea≈øon is of ≈øome force; ≈øurely there is too much loo≈øene≈øs in this our Law, to allow Copulation at twelve in the woman, and fourteen in the man.

Now the di≈øqui≈øition of the other part concerning the gift of Continency will re≈øolve the whole; for I pray you how is the Law of Liberty and Continency to be pleaded? may the Child marry without the good liking of the Parent? Can the Child plead to him that he hath not the gift of Continencie? or do we rather know it is the loo≈øne≈øse of Government, the evil of idle unclean education both in young men and Maids, that inflames affections? The young ones are ignorant of what is ≈øin, and the elde≈øt often, and they fall into contagious offences each with other, before they under≈øtand the rules of wi≈øe Rea≈øon, being led away of natural appetite; and not with≈øtanding all incentives, the father is allowed to di≈ø≈øent from the Marriage of his ≈øon or daughter; and in ca≈øe of di≈øobedience, to cha≈øti≈øe with ≈øtroaks or di≈øinheri≈øon, or both, the ≈øon; and it is done to the daughter; But ≈øhould the ≈øon that had ≈øtoln the daughter bring an Action, or the married ≈øon, could he ju≈øtifie, or not, by the Law?

I profe≈øs the ca≈øe is difficult; for if lawful, why beaten? if not lawful, why may not the Magi≈øtrate ≈øet the rule of re≈øtraint to Naturall appetite as well as the Parent? the publick as the private Magi≈øtrate? for by paternal power and Juri≈ødiction he enforces.

Now the Chri≈øtian Magi≈øtrate therefore upon the whole may and ought to bridle this bea≈øt in man by a di≈øcreet Moderate Law, to re≈øtrain the Lu≈øts of proud, rich, lazy, idle, and ≈øo lu≈øtfull young ones;

And take of the itch of mean ones, by work, and labor of the body and minde, or both, with ≈ølender dyet, and holy exerci≈øes, Divine and Spiritual breathings after
God, in the ≈øen≈øe of our own weakne≈øs, will as well re≈øtrain exorbitant affections in Chri≈øtians, as the love of Philo≈øophy, or the fear of the gods, ≈øo called, could Heathens; Let us not therefore eat to lu≈øt and live in idlene≈øs, and then we mu≈øt marry, O we burn.
It is as lawful from that rea≈øon to have many wives, many husbands, or diver≈øity of men, or women, in the accidents of ≈øickne≈øs, long journeys, and the like of yoakfellows.

The Modern Age is wholly loo≈øe, through pretence of Chri≈øtian Liberty; that is the undoing de≈øtructive principle; and it ≈øeems by many who out of zeal again≈øt humane wandrings, go about to eclip≈øe the glimp≈øes of divine inlightenments, to be fit totally to be rejected; but both mu≈øt ≈øtand: a ju≈øt Liberty with a due re≈øtraint, that Ju≈øtice with Righteou≈øne≈øs be in all.

Now as it is rational, that the publick Magi≈øtrate may temper the liberty of the child, not to marry till a ≈øea≈øon; ≈øo after that ≈øea≈øon to mitigate the Rigidity of the parent is as nece≈ø≈øary, many parents being extream and cruel, forcing them to marry whom and how they plea≈øe, or not admitting Marriage at all.

I know the difficulty of the≈øe bu≈øine≈ø≈øes hath di≈øcouraged, but Chri≈øtian piety ought to advance endeavors in this kind, yea in ≈øome ca≈øes to portion moderately children dutiful and obedient in all other things, and permit them their own choyces, if nothing can be objected on the parents part but meer will.
It is al≈øo fit to re≈øolve the degrees of Marriage; for late Liberty hath made Quaeries concerning a ju≈øt and Regular Law.
And to ≈øee all this done, the Magi≈øtrate is the onely fit man.

The Act is meerly civil; it is old Popery acknowledging Marriage a Sacrament, that onely continues it in the Clergie ≈øo called; Therefore let no Marriage be ≈øolemnized, but before one or more publick Magi≈øtrates thereto appointed, inrolled or recorded in a book of purpo≈øe, with their hands, and of the Parent, if living, or Certificate under hand and Seal of the Magi≈øtrate where the parties live; otherwi≈øe of the Guardian, unle≈øs they be of ≈øuch an Age as is fixed by the Magi≈øtrate, or they be married by Magi≈øterial Authority, that is, though the Parent before refu≈øe, having no ju≈øt cau≈øe; alwayes re≈øolved, that if a Magi≈øtrate offends, or Ra≈øures be and alterations, that the puni≈øhments be exceeding high.

div.head: Who ought to be Guardians, Tutors, &c.
div.p: SUrely in this the ≈øo called Law of England, Common Law I mean, as before-≈øaid, provides excellently above the Civil General of Nations, ≈øo called Chri≈øtian, by placing the next in blood to whom the inheritance cannot di≈øcend to be Guardian; and the duty of his Account is well regulated by the other part of the ≈øo called Law of England, namely the Statutes.
But the Heir in Capite, or by Knight Service, being in Ward till 21. the Heir in Soccage but till 14. the Heir in Burg. Engli≈øh but till he can mea≈øure cloth, tell Money, &c.

The≈øe Ages and Tenures breed confu≈øion, and difficulty can a plain hone≈øt illiterate man know his duty; therefore let one time be for all Ages, viz. not under 21. And till then let them not di≈øpo≈øe by will or otherwi≈øe, nor ought be paid out by the Guardian but nece≈ø≈øary expences, according to the proportion of the E≈øtate at a fixed rate, not above.

And for ≈øucce≈ø≈øions in inheritances to real E≈øtate, let it be in ca≈øe of the death of any brother, &c. as the Magi≈øtrate ≈øhall agree, whether all to the next of the whole blood, or the ≈øon of the ≈øecond wife to ≈øucceed before the daughters of the whole blood.

div.head: Whether it be requi≈øite to have Cities, Town Corporate, &c. And they to have Priviledges and Laws; And whether all ought to have like Priviledges, and the be≈øt way of trial of Laws, or probation of Laws, and by-Laws?
div.p: AFter the youth be grown to Age, they are to become ≈øharers in Tru≈øts, and Duties, and Offices of the Commonwealth, ≈øome in the Countries, ≈øome in the Cities; for the evils of Depredations, Thefts, Roberies, &c. did at fir≈øt nece≈ø≈øarily cau≈øe men to gather into Societies and Companies; and the ≈øame end of ≈øafety in time of War, to have ≈øtrong places to retire to, is ≈øtill; and the ≈øame nece≈ø≈øity did inforce Laws diver≈øe from the other places of the Country; here were Taxes for repairing of Walls, Bridges, Defences, Watchings, Wardings, Pavings, clean≈øing of Streets, Common-Sewers, and the like, which were certain; hence the taking people infected with the Plague, &c. from their own dwellings, and removing them into places ≈øpecially appointed according to their quality; hence men are liable to Laws of conveniencie, temporary, or ought to be, and that for peace ≈øake, which ≈øaves life ab≈øolutely, healths ≈øake, and trades ≈øake, which are but comforts of, and for well-living; but mo≈øt a≈ø≈øuredly Cities being nece≈ø≈øary and Towns,

It is nece≈ø≈øary, and of nece≈ø≈øity to maintain and allow a nece≈ø≈øary di≈øtinct Law within the Precincts, not as Franchi≈øes again≈øt Law, but of diver≈øe Laws according to the nece≈ø≈øity of the place and the trades there driven.

Now the Laws of Cities, &c. though they mu≈øt, in the regards afore≈øaid be diver≈øe, yet in re≈øpect of their proper nature, as bodies corporate, they ought all prefixedly and po≈øitively to have tho≈øe Laws ≈øet and known, and a due enforcing power in a ≈øpeedy way; for the ≈øtanding out of a man in a tedious ≈øuit, cools all obedience, as Experience manife≈øts clearly.

Therefore draw and ≈øettle the Government of the≈øe places by a head Law; the Charter-Grant is but the foundation of Bribery and Extortion, Nurcery of Prerogative and Arbitrary Liberty, and fit to be avoided; Experience hath ≈øo evidenced the Truth, that I cea≈øe to contend, and onely a≈ø≈øert.

This head Law mu≈øt di≈øtingui≈øh Inn-land, and Sea-Towns and Cities; for the other Laws re≈øpectively, they are communicable generally one to another; onely the particular Regulation of Trades, which mu≈øt have ≈øpecial power well ≈øetled to regulate the exorbitances of the Artificers particularlys.

And to that end they mu≈øt, both Cities, Towns, and Companies, have power to make By-Laws which are to be approved; Now to that one word, to the probation of Laws and By-Laws, which being re≈øpectively for the Nation, Cities, Towns and Companies of publike concernment, and what are of particular u≈øe, may have a general influence;

Therefore it is requi≈øite, after a defect Seen, to propound the defect and remedie, which the then chief in Tru≈øts re≈øpectively, for City, Town, or Company, think fit to the City, Town, or Company; That being done, the ≈øame to be promulged for a Law, if allowed; but not ≈øo to be received for a ≈øhort ≈øet time, during which any Citizen, Towns-man, or Artificer, is to bring his Rea≈øons in Writing again≈øt that Law, and propounding a better, or offering expedients to remedy vi≈øible evils, and only leave their Rea≈øons; Then is the Supream Officer to cau≈øe them to be ≈øearched, read, and debated, & if great difficulty ari≈øe, to take the opinion of the Judges in Circuit appointed, who are to determine the difficulty, or the Law, as appointed by the Magi≈øtrate to ≈øtand; if they find difficulty, then to ≈øtate the Ca≈øe, and pre≈øent it to the Repre≈øentative of the Nation, who are to di≈øcu≈øs and allow the ≈øame; alway es provided, that for Regulation ≈øake, from one moneth after need ≈øeen of a Law, and promulged by hanging up openly in ≈øeveral the eminent parts or places of the City, Town, that Law to
≈øtand though not ≈øo good, till another Law be e≈øtabli≈øhed by them or the Supream Magi≈øtrate; for better an evil Law then none at all.

No Law after once e≈øtabli≈øhed to be que≈øtioned by particular men, which enervates not onely the particular Law or Priviledge, but tends to confu≈øion; and as no City nor Town, ≈øo no company ought to be without due Regulation, nor any per≈øon, but in and of ≈øome Company, Decree, or Order ≈øetled and known.

div.head: Whether, and how Cu≈øtoms are to be admitted as Law?
div.p: CU≈øtom hath nece≈ø≈øarily been accounted part of our Law, and that rightly as to the Rule; namely, That no Cu≈øtom is good unle≈øs the ≈øame be rea≈øonable; yet this admitting of Cu≈øtom among Chri≈øtians is of the prophane Apo≈øtate Church, and Commonwealth; for by this Rule the whole Family, Town≈øhip, City, County, Nation, may, as we have done, live all dayes of our life under evil, wicked and pernitious Cu≈øtoms.

Therefore the Magi≈øtrate ought to admit nothing to be pleaded as a Cu≈øtom, untill allowed by certain Judges, who allowing, or di≈øallowing the Cu≈øtom as rea≈øonable, that is ju≈øtly to be u≈øed, by not onely men but Chri≈øtians; the ≈øame is equal to, and is indeed the Law, temporary, or ≈øetled; for a certain limit, or more generally, or univer≈øal, as the nature of the thing is; this will avoid the ingendring of all ≈øorts of corrupt, envious, and ≈øelf-≈øeeking Cu≈øtoms, and cool our greedy, devilli≈øh upholding of them by manife≈øt and open perjuries, and the like.
Then that all particular Cu≈øtoms of particular places be inrowled under a ≈øworn Officer, and publi≈øhed in Print, and a Book kept in every Town or Precinct.

div.head: What is the Magi≈øtrates duty in all Orders of Government and nece≈ø≈øaries thereto; And fir≈øt, whether the Chri≈øtian Magi≈øtrate may admit War?
div.p: THe Magi≈øtrate ought to provide for the well-being of the Nation, or any part thereof repectively according to his tru≈øt; ≈øo let us con≈øider the evils which may di≈øturbe this well-being, and that ari≈øing
Fir≈øt from open war; ≈øecondly, from private force; thirdly, from deceit or fraud; and la≈øtly, from difficulty: Let us a little di≈øcour≈øe therefore of war; and whether Chri≈øtians may war?

Surely, the Church, that is the Congregation of Saints are militant on earth; but that oppo≈øition being again≈øt ≈øpiritual enemies, Satan, lu≈øt, pomps, vanities, &c. are not the ≈øubject of our di≈øcour≈øe; again≈øt the≈øe there is no Quaere; they mu≈øt war; and the≈øe are enemies both outward and inward; and though the children of God will not, cannot war among them≈øelves, yet there are fal≈øe brethren, ≈øuch as go out, becau≈øe they were never in; Heretiks ≈øo called, Deceivers, Lyars, and all ≈øuch as are ca≈øt out of the Church.

Now for the≈øe I ≈øtill humbly conceive, that we mu≈øt look at the nature of the offence; for if it be meerly mental, opinative, and internal from the ≈øouls mi≈øtakings, but not degenerating in actual ≈øcandal; the weapons that are to be u≈øed again≈øt the≈øe, are meerly ≈øpiritual, which are mighty to the beating down of all the ≈øtrong holds of ≈øin, and overthrowing every thing that is not of God; and again≈øt ≈øuch, I ≈øuppo≈øe no outward force, yea though you ≈øuppo≈øe or beleeve them firmly to be Hereticks, may or ought to be u≈øed, ≈øo as they di≈øturb not the Civil Peace.
But a ca≈øe will enlighten ≈øomewhat; Suppo≈øe one doth beleeve, as many are ≈øaid to do, the aboli≈øhing of the Sabboth, may the Magi≈øtrate enforce obedience?

To this I ≈øay, that he that holds the aboli≈øhing of the Sabboth, held a Sabboth was and then mu≈øt acknowledge the power whereby that Sabboth was, and ≈øo the end to which it was directed, which was the ea≈øe of the creature from corporal labor, and for his edification in the ≈øervice of God in the Spirit; This gives no loo≈øe to any Jocundrie that day, no Sporting, no nor idle Tatling, Walkings, but the Spirits Recreations in the Contemplations of Divinity ought to be the repa≈øts of the Soule.

Then a≈ø≈øuredly the Magi≈øtrate may hinder this, and cau≈øe keeping within doors, and puni≈øh offenders; Therefore let not the Gates of a City be opened that day, but to
≈øuch as pa≈øs too and fro, and are known, and that to partake in divine and ≈øpiritual ≈øervices, and that not above a Sabbath dayes journey; and agree that, but dilate not twelve moneths what is a Sabboth dayes journey; but within the private Family there is no inforcing of the Magi≈øtrate; that is, he ≈øeems not to be bound to it, nor is his power evident.

No, the better way to know the care and diligence of the Ma≈øter of the Family, is, to appoint ≈øome men, not as Church Officers, but Civil Inqui≈øitors of Knowledge, who may ≈øee the progre≈øs in Knowledge of ≈øuch as are out of the Schools and Colledges, and puni≈øh, or cau≈øe them to be puni≈øhed at fir≈øt; and afterwards the Parents and Ma≈øters; and not to admit to places of Magi≈øtracy, ≈øuch as are ignorant them≈øelves; ≈øo neither tho≈øe that do not carefully educate and in≈øtruct their Family, whereby they may in their ≈øea≈øon become ≈øerviceable in the Congregation of the faithful.
Now this war of Hereticks and profane per≈øons being over; let us ≈øee what is to be done to tho≈øe without the Church.

I ≈øay to the≈øe, That the≈øe al≈øo as the Religion wherein they were educated, are to be permitted their Con≈øcience without force; ≈øuppo≈øe them Papi≈øts, and ≈øuppo≈øe them Idolators, ≈øuppo≈øe them Turks, and ≈øuppo≈øe them Heathens; for unle≈øs by the pure light of Nature they mu≈øt or may ≈øee it, that is, it be evident and per≈øpicuous; I take it, Rea≈øon, Divine or Humane, corrects not, notwith≈øtanding that Parable of the Servant that knew not his Ma≈øters Will and was to be beaten.

Now this is evident; for among all the cla≈øhings among≈øt opinions untill now, where was it not, that every one ≈øtrove onely to free them≈øelves from the power of others to be inforced, yet would inforce others? but now I take it to be the infinite Mercy of the Lord to reveal this thing unto us that ≈øee it, how many do not; that is they can ≈øee nothing but confu≈øion accompany it.

Now as to the other part of Papi≈øtry, though claimed as part of Religion, viz. That the Pope is Head, &c. and may di≈øpo≈øe Kingdoms, di≈ø≈øolve Leagues, Oathes, and remit obedience to powers, and that becau≈øe he hath ≈øaid it, there is no faith to be kept with Hereticks: All or any of the≈øe being contrary to the peace and ≈øafety of a State, may be enforcedly renounced, and the parties denying ju≈øtly bani≈øhed; I ≈øay not their goods confi≈øcate; for we know many do con≈øcienciou≈øly hold the≈øe things, and with great ≈øtrength of Natural Rea≈øon, as much as maintains the greate≈øt pretending opinion in this Age, and now in conte≈øt with us; And in ca≈øe of Re≈øi≈øtance War is lawful.

So that in brief I take it, War is lawful again≈øt the Enemies of the Church, Spiritually with Spiritual weapons, again≈øt the carnal enemies with corporal weapons of Bani≈øhment in ca≈øe of de≈øtructive errors to peace and civil quiet; and warlike force, where the State and Nation cannot otherwi≈øe in Prudence ≈øecure it ≈øelf for the entring the others Country or Limits.
Fir≈øt, To make that the Seate of the war, where other things are clear, the Law of Nations which admit it, will well ≈øetle it.

div.head: What Arms or Armies he ought to u≈øe, whether his own People or Strangers?
div.p: AS≈øuredly, the nece≈ø≈øity of Arms being pre≈øervation; it were indi≈øcretion to put that ≈øtrength into a Strangers keeping; Experience hath proved it un≈øafe; and Religion will count it unlawful to imploy an other about that which we count ≈øimply evil.

Next, onely to keep the people from delight in blood, it mu≈øt be Civil or Divine Knowledge mu≈øt do that; indeed there is a ≈øhadow of exception in the Law, which prohibites Butchers to be of a Jury of Life and Death; but that was, I ≈øuppo≈øe, becau≈øe mo≈øt of them were of mean and ≈øervile condition, and ≈øo ignorant; for a≈ø≈øuredly the killing of bea≈øts makes not a man carele≈øs of the life of a man in a judicial way; it was the office of Gods High Prie≈øts; though it may in the way of a particular quarrel; next Souldiers for never ≈øo many battels are not debarred the being of Juries.

div.head: How the Militia ought to be ≈øetled.
div.p: ALL Humane Laws have their ≈øettlements, and of them≈øelves naturally devolve into Error; ≈øo that if we eye all the wi≈øe ≈øettlements of Nations in this or ought el≈øe, it is nought worth now: The Jewi≈øh, Romane, Grecian, Egyptian, or other old or Modern; the foundation yet of mo≈øt of the≈øe, being originally Regal and ab≈øolute, held one cour≈øe to engage, as our William ≈øo called the Conqueror did the great men to an ab≈øolute dependance upon him, and by them to va≈ø≈øalize the re≈øidue.

I know many godly hone≈øt people ≈øee no ≈øuch thing; I believe it, God gives gifts variou≈øly; but mo≈øt certain it is ≈øuch dependancies are the Nur≈øes of Feuds and Jealou≈øies; If therefore you will ≈øetle the Militia aright, you mu≈øt ≈øuppo≈øe your Nation or Juri≈ødiction at terms of Unity among them≈øelves, under no great and eminent civil broyl; for then none on the adver≈øe party to them in power, or ju≈øtly ≈øu≈øpected, that is openly oppo≈øing (by pur≈øe or per≈øon) can be for a time entru≈øted; but otherwi≈øe the power muff be in the dependance in the Supream Magi≈øtrate, and their active power by his general Law.

That is, That all within their Limit, from twenty ≈øix, or twenty eight, &c. to ≈øixty, ≈øeventy, or &c. be chargeable to the War; that is to ≈øay, They that have not e≈øtate to ≈øuch a value, to be in inferior ≈øervices, as Pyoners, &c. And of this let the inferior Magi≈øtrate take the ordering care.
Next, All that are of ≈øuch an e≈øtate, to be charged Foot-Arms: All of ≈øuch an e≈øtate Hor≈øe-Arms, that is, Dragoons, and Light-hor≈øe, as the e≈øtate is.

Now as to this, and to all Rates, it mu≈øt be known that there will be multitudes of Quaeries ari≈øing; ≈øome have great e≈øtates fit in proportion to find ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred Hor≈øe; ≈øome in re≈øpect of great and va≈øt real, others va≈øt per≈øonal e≈øtates; ≈øome have their lands lie altogether; ≈øome di≈øper≈øed; ≈øome live in their own, ≈øome in Cities; ≈øome have great charges of children, poor friends, and decayed, ≈øome in debt, and ≈øome have granted out Annuities, Rents, &c. and have outwardly a fair vi≈øible e≈øtate, bur indeed and really ≈ømall.

Now in all the≈øe there ought to be a Rule of proportion with ≈øafety to the whole; for fir≈øt, it mu≈øt be agreed, that the Commonwealth con≈øi≈øts of real and per≈øonal e≈øtate; the real e≈øtate Hou≈øe and Lands, the per≈øonal e≈øtate Goods and Money.

Now this is certain, that all Land mu≈øt have ≈øtock, all Trades mu≈øt have ≈øtock, it is vi≈øible; therefore the rule of Charges of all ≈øorts mu≈øt be the Land and the Stock, and that whether in City or Country.
Now for di≈øcharge of this, it mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity be either theirs who≈øe vi≈øibly it appears to be, or others.

For Lands, in which there is ≈øo much more then Turki≈øh Knavery, if it were inrowled wi≈øely and ju≈øtly, it would prevent much; but due puni≈øhment would take it all away, while impunity breeds offences, that controver≈øie, that gain to the Officer; and therefore is mercy, &c. cried up ≈øo.

This Land, and this Stock is the ≈øub≈øi≈øtence of the Nation; I know Corruption fears di≈øcovery of e≈øtate; for either they are rich, and would conceal it, or poor, and fear undoing: Now to nouri≈øh either of the≈øe corrupt intere≈øts, is de≈øtructive; the la≈øt is mo≈øt to be eyed, but lea≈øt to be regarded; for though ≈øome good come of it, yet it is the mo≈øt dangerous; for from hence comes all the ≈øtock of Bankquerupts, and the ≈øudden undoings of many e≈øteemed rich men; and indeed it is mo≈øt unchri≈øtian and utterly unlawful for a man knowing him≈øelf poor to borrow or buy at a day for what he vi≈øibly and certainly ≈øees not he can pay, though ≈øuch may have thriven.

Thefore allow no di≈øcharge, either for rates of A≈ø≈øe≈øsment of Moneys or Arms, contrary to the vi≈øible e≈øtate, but with certain knowledge of the owner; onely this is fit, that for A≈ø≈øe≈øsments for the vi≈øible per≈øonal e≈øtate abatement be per rate as for land by the hirer (all the Objections are an≈øwered before as to per≈øonal e≈øtate;) and for real, let it be charged as it lies in the Counties.

I ≈øay not in the Towns; it is be≈øt leave that at the di≈øcretion of the Commi≈ø≈øioners, or Judges for Arms, unle≈øs a general ≈øettlement by a ≈øtanding National Law be; only let ≈øuch rents, &c. as are going out bear a proportionate charge of hor≈øe or foot re≈øpectively, as the ≈øaid Judges ≈øhall under Hand and Seal appoint and Record in their Mu≈øter-Book.
