Now I pre≈øume you will not find a better way for the pre≈øent ≈øettlement, then the owner to be at the charge of the Hor≈øe and Arms, the Tenant to find the keeping of it, labouring him rea≈øonably, ≈øo as alwayes to be ready for ≈øervice; and if he dyes not by negligence, but ≈øickne≈øs, or in Military ≈øervice, the owner to find another, otherwi≈øe the Tenant, and the Training ≈øervice by the Tenant al≈øo; for all ≈øervice more then for meer Trayning ≈øervice, ought to be the expence and publick charge of the County at lea≈øt, if not National, which is more ju≈øt; then one County ≈øhall not bear all the burthen of war and charge al≈øo, as is too frequent; and for price of hor≈øe, le≈øt the owner and Tenant differ, let a ≈øet price be ≈øo much for a Dragoon, ≈øo much a hor≈øe of ≈øervice, and this price to be ≈øet yearly at ≈øuch a day.

But finding in divers places where the lands lie, will ea≈øe ≈øome part of the ju≈øt doubt of the great mens over-powring the County by pur≈øe and power, but nothing will avoid it wholly, except it be enacted, that no one man find above 6, 8, 10, &c. hor≈øes or Arms; and that for every one that he is in proportion of e≈øtate chargeable above that number, let him pay ≈øo much yearly as ≈øhall be ≈øetled to the publick pur≈øe, or for the ea≈øe of ≈øome particular ≈øervice; but better all to come to the publick pur≈øe either of the County, or of the Nation.

Next, all Arms are to be owned the Nations or Publicks, yet to be in the hands of the particular per≈øons charged, unle≈øs di≈øpriviledged. Next, the≈øe Arms mu≈øt be imployed in War by fit men, and even to Chri≈øtians it may be ≈øo requi≈øite (if it be not ≈øimply unlawful) to admini≈øter a Military Oath of obedience to the Officer, according to the Tenor of the Commi≈ø≈øion of the Officer, or General, of faithfulne≈øs in his tru≈øt; for though ju≈øt men and vertuous are true for hone≈øty ≈øake, yet the evil will not, but the fear and con≈øcience of an oath will reach far with the wor≈øt of men; And ≈øo to the Souldier re≈øpectively.
Let this, and the rea≈øon of the di≈øu≈øe be well Quaeried.

Some pre≈øume the be≈øt way of ≈øettlement is to charge ≈øo many Arms only upon the Town≈øhip, whether hor≈øe or foot, or labourers in the wayes or carriages, and all to bear their equal proportion; now this generally may be good, but the particular rule wil vary every moment; either or any of the wayes may do, ≈øo the Commi≈ø≈øioners as they are Judges, do ju≈øtly; for all Laws as Governments are not ≈øo much good or bad by In≈øtitution, as by Execution; to this end it is fit as mo≈øt think, to give a general Oath of faithfulne≈øs in their tru≈øts, although they agree it true, that the generalty of men are ju≈øt for Righteou≈øne≈øs ≈øake, oath or no oath, they are the ≈øame; And ≈øo on the contrary; but in a Commonweal, in the State that England is now in, it is fit to make Laws of this nature, probationers for a time in each County, and by due returns of what is done (which is ≈øo required, but neglected, for that in all things its noted only from all Acts and Ordinances, and In≈øtructions earne≈øtly required for a day or two, and then rejected, which is a great over≈øight in them ≈øupreamly concerned; for it is vi≈øible, all men are by this beaten out of the road of ≈øetled obedience, and ≈øpin out time to attend the i≈ø≈øue; and that falling out as of old, they will never be forward to ≈øervice after; ≈øo for ≈øervice in Arms, the forward appear, the other ≈ølack; ≈øo in A≈ø≈øe≈øments upon the true value, the forward pay to the utmo≈øt peny, the other half, no puni≈øhment but talking, no, deal gently; thus is all ≈øen≈øe of obedience to Powers and Authorities de≈øtroyed by the Powers them≈øelves, and their ≈øelf-ended Agents, ≈øeeking to make parties; for one ≈øuch time and per≈øon-≈øerver ≈øhall in this corrupt Age have more followers then 20. hone≈øt men.) But I return to my task, If the ≈øupream Power have due returns, let them ≈øee and judge out of the ≈øeverall experiments made, what is fitte≈øt to be the general head Rule, and way of the charge of Arms; Its vi≈øible in our condition at pre≈øent, the generality of the Nation are unfit to be entru≈øted; but for accidental evils there can no particular remedie be well pre≈øcribed: the general Rule wi≈øely executed mu≈øt be the top ≈øtone under God of the ≈øafety. Magazines in the ≈øeveral Hundreds for the publick Arms of the Hundred, or the chief Town adjoyning, or ≈øuch head Town, or Town of defence in a County, to be the Magazine of the County: the≈øe have all their objections, yea in a ≈øetled ≈øtate, all or any may be u≈øeful, and in a di≈øtracted one may prove de≈øtructive: now the difficulty is but to find out the be≈øt as we mu≈øt ≈øay for the pre≈øent temper of the Nation: for its certainly true, to ≈øettle unity, love and peace,
and root out the jealou≈øies and acerbities which are ri≈øen in a Nation; its fit to have all the ≈øame general Law; the Supream Magi≈øtrate ought ≈øo to admini≈øter Law, that it be the ≈øame to all his Subjects. To follow the crochets of Machivilian Politicians by tran≈øplanting ≈øouldiers, is to nouri≈øh ab≈øolute dependences, ≈øuch as free Common-wealths explode, & only rai≈øe to an eminency of power to do good or evil at lu≈øt, which is tyrannical; no; a nece≈ø≈øary dependance is all here hinted, which though ≈øome may extend farther then others, yet while its rule is not ab≈øolute, nor its con≈øtant practice, there is no ju≈øt ground for exception; by this its plain, the Laws mu≈øt be equal, that is, re≈øpecting time, place, per≈øon, e≈øtate &c. and ≈øo univer≈øal; now for the leading and conducting of the≈øe, whether to place the whole under a general Command, ab≈øolute and ≈øetled, of a known Military Officer, or of a Civil Officer, as now the Sheriff; and the other to be ≈øetled by the Supream power, as need is, is worthy enquiry, yet ea≈øie to be determined; for if it be looked into, both will be ≈øeen nece≈ø≈øary; for the ≈øetled Law of England alwaies allowed the power of the County to ≈øuppre≈øs Riots, &c. and again≈øt ob≈øtinate offenders and oppugners of the Publick peace; therefore the chief Judges in the County mu≈øt have an Officer duly con≈øtituted, who ≈øhall ≈øee to the execution of the Laws; next to give the ancient Colonel or the Col. of Hor≈øe in each County the chief tru≈øt in order, re≈øerving ≈øpecial power of making an extraordinary Officer in chief, is (while Commi≈ø≈øioners for the Militia are a Court re≈øident) the mo≈øt (evidently) ≈øafe way. Now we are come to con≈øider a nece≈ø≈øary engagement, and that is the pay of Officers and Souldiers of the Trained Souldiers of the Nation. To this its ea≈øily an≈øwered, if in actual ≈øervice pay is nece≈ø≈øary, the doubt is only in time of peace; now not to di≈øtingui≈øh of peace as ≈øetled peace, and di≈øturbed peace, intervalls of peace and war, or outbreakings or fears; I ≈øay in the mo≈øt ≈øetled times, its fit the Officer have ≈øome ≈øetled pay, be it more or le≈øs, as the Supream power thinks fit. I ≈øhall not enlarge concerning that; what the age of Souldiers is, is not ≈øo needful; ours is the be≈øt way that requires an able man of body, and of this the Commi≈ø≈øioners are ab≈øolute Judges. Its not much requi≈øite with us what rank a Hor≈øman be of, e≈øpecially if the State be mixt Monarchy, ≈øo called, or Republical; for honours engage not to a dependance, that is, ≈øhould not but as the Law requires.

For offences done in the field, and as Souldiers, let them be tryed by the Commi≈ø≈øioners for the Militia, without any form of complaint legal or in writing, that is ≈øo nece≈ø≈øitated, and let the Mar≈øhal ≈øee the Judgement executed.

For all things which now the Heralds exerci≈øe in Office, and which the Lord Mar≈øhal did take cognizance of, they ought properly to come to the Commi≈ø≈øioners thereto appointed in the County; and that for the Militia is the fitte≈øt; for Honours aro≈øe from Arms, and with them let the Records of Honors remain.
The Li≈øts of them enrolled Souldiers;
Tho≈øe authorirized to make and fell Arms, Powder and Ammunition of all ≈øorts;

Let them al≈øo have the ≈øole power of watching and warding, but by a like head-rule of a proportionate charge, and let them have a ≈øet way by a joint con≈øent at Se≈ø≈øions, or as is by the Supream Magi≈øtrate appointed to rai≈øe monies to pay, in ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity, ≈øuch as are imployed by them for the nece≈ø≈øary peace of the County.

Let them appoint Superadvi≈øors of Taverns, Inns, Alehou≈øes, &c. and let them have their Licen≈øes from them, if allowed by the Ju≈øtices at Se≈ø≈øions, and you may make a Re≈øervation of a Rent to the State to defray charges; but to admit that entrance to increa≈øing gain, is a vi≈øible in let to all villany, in enervating the good Law under colour of publick benefit, which is mo≈øt carefully to be avoided, as the ≈øhelter to private knaveries. La≈øtly, the rule of puni≈øhments, that is the general Law of puni≈øhing mutinous refractory and di≈øobedient Souldiers, and that both in actuall ≈øervice, and al≈øo in ordinary mu≈øters and trayning (or better to expre≈øs it, appearing in Arms) is to be con≈øidered, and ≈øome other way thought of, e≈øpecially for trained Souldiers who are not in con≈øtant pay, then ca≈øhiering or taking away of Arms; for the de≈øpi≈øing of Arms is yet in mind, and the honour of the tru≈øt of Arms is unknown; it mu≈øt be corporal puni≈øhment, as whipping, with ca≈øhiering ≈øome incorrigible, rude, unworthy per≈øon, or running the Gantlop, and this by the judgement upon vote of the Officers of Troop, Company, or Regiment, if the Regiment be there. Seek not many, but fit ≈øouldiers; but look none keep Arms but tho≈øe charged or allowed by the Militia or Ju≈øtices, as now one is fit, if not of nece≈ø≈øity.

I have now but one word to the Commi≈ø≈øioners and Officers, and in them to all Officers of Tru≈øt, Judges, and others, be ≈øtrict in your duties to your Supreams, and require nothing but ju≈øt things, and obedience will flow of it ≈øelf; it is the Military power that in all alterations of State gives forth the Rule of Government; from their order is the Nation ≈øetled: Reduce therefore your Di≈øcipline to a ju≈øt and ≈øetled Rule, and then each one labor to beget this opinion in your Souldiery, which is truly a Chri≈øtian as well as prudent humane Maxime, That the riches and ≈øafety of the Ma≈øter is in the emulation of ≈øervants; but as that, ≈øo this mu≈øt have a ju≈øt emulation; and by that the Army, and ≈øo the Commonwealth will be e≈øtabli≈øhed and pre≈øerved; but this emulation is fit to be a little better known; It con≈øi≈øts principally in the glory of doing good, but that doing good is materially in avoiding or hindring of evil: I mean they that will faithfully ≈øerve the Commonwealth, mu≈øt not only keep the Laws them≈øelves out of con≈øcience of their own duty, but al≈øo ≈øee to, and as much as in them lies, that is, as lawfully they may in their places enforce the performance of them by others; the want of which hath ≈øo di≈øordered Civil Government, that he that requires or advi≈øes but the obedience to the Law, or a ju≈øt and con≈øciencious regard thereto, is thought, nay called a bu≈øy-headed fellow, a Roundhead, a pragmatick, ≈øelf-conceited, ≈øhallowbrain'd fellow; Turks and Heathens will ri≈øe up again≈øt us. Gent. you it is that mu≈øt redeem Authority buried in the a≈øhes of politick mercy, which hath de≈øtroyed Kings, & will ruine this Commonwealth ere it hath the honour of a ≈øettlement, unle≈øs the prudence of power ≈øet it on his legs again, with the ble≈ø≈øing of the Spirit of the eternal wi≈ødome, without which all mans labor is in vain. But I proceed with my intended ≈øettlement.

div.head: Whether Indictments or Appeals are to be pur≈øued in cau≈øe of crime, or both.
div.p: HAving done with the due regulation of Arms (which under God are the great ≈øtaies and ≈øupport of men, to a≈ø≈øure their peace, quiet, repo≈øe & enjoyment of what God by their friends or labors hath vouch≈øafed them) for I mu≈øt agree that the foundation of humane happine≈ø≈øe ≈øub≈øi≈øts in the providence of the Almighty, however he u≈øeth us as in≈øtruments, that is, gives ≈øucce≈øs to our endeavors thereto. We come now to look at the civil ≈øettlement in the remainder; and fir≈øt becau≈øe the criminal part of law is of mo≈øt and greate≈øt concernment, as looking at the life of man, I ≈øhall therefore look fir≈øt at that; now in this the difficulties cau≈øing difference are the≈øe; in an appeal, there mu≈øt and ought to be witne≈øs be≈øides him that appeals; for he is the accu≈øer, and that either in his own right, or as next of kin, but all for private benefit. Secondly, there the dammages are to the party, and it is a per≈øonal thing proper to the complainer, and he may de≈øi≈øt when he will, and compound as he will. The Indictment is at the ≈øuit of the ≈øupream Magi≈øtrate, ≈øolely for the benefit of the Commonwealth, and the State hath all the goods, and all dammages; and the pro≈øecutor, or complainer, is here a witne≈øs for the State, but at his own charge, which is as now u≈øed, unju≈øt. The Intere≈øt therefore of the Magi≈øtrate & the Subject ought here to be compromi≈øed rationally, for a≈ø≈øuredly, if life goes for life, dammages are cut off as unfit, or of unequal value to be rendred for the life of a man; therefore the heir, or wife, or friend who ≈øhould bring an appeal, as I conceive, ought to have no forfeiture; ≈øome recompence may be, where the life is lo≈øt, as in all ca≈øes of Murders and voluntary con≈øiderate killings, and in all appointed duels, not in heat of blood, e≈øpecially if for ought the Law gives a remedy (for great abu≈øes di≈øpuni≈øhable by Law, it ≈øeems not rea≈øonable) but of this more after.

Now for to clear this, indeed it is requi≈øite that there be, as is ju≈øtly ≈øuppo≈øed in Law, an Attorney for the State, whether called Clerk of the Crown, Clerk of the Peace, or what other name you will give him, ≈øetled in every County, who upon a ≈øet day each week, by vertue of his place, ≈øhould receive all complaints, and that upon oath, him≈øelf being duly ≈øworn, and then by and with the con≈øent and advice of one or more Ju≈øtices, ≈øhould frame an appeal generally, thus: I do challenge you A. for the peace of the Commonwealth, to an≈øwer to B. for the death, wounding, &c. of C. whereof you are accu≈øed; and let B. and another witne≈øs make two witne≈ø≈øes; and upon the finding of him guilty, let him be fined moderately, that is, ≈øo that at lea≈øt a fourth part of his e≈øtate be left him; The like Law al≈øo in ca≈øe of Maym, wounding, &c. whereof two parts to the party wounded, &c. a third part to the State to bear all charges (for it is not fit to add charge & lo≈øs of time to him that is before oppre≈ø≈øed) in ca≈øe of life, let life an≈øwer
life, unle≈øs by mi≈øadventure, yet then he mu≈øt be fined, but not to the party, but to the State, and that but to a third part of his e≈øtate reall or per≈øonal, to bear charges; and where the life is lo≈øt, the charges mu≈øt al≈øo be apportioned in like manner. For the leavying this, the way is before ≈øet: but for di≈øcovery of e≈øtate, there is the difficulty; but in Lands admit no tru≈øts for deceit, nor u≈øes to cheat, and the e≈øtate in the Land will be vi≈øible: and take the goods in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion at the time of death, and all is ≈øatisfied that can be expected.

Only let a ≈øet time be for Creditors to come and be ≈øatisfied; al≈øo that the Commonwealth be ≈øatisfied, and the members not ruined, undone, and impoveri≈øhed: Thus ≈øhall both intere≈øts be ≈øatisfied, and the multitudes of legal quarrels by indictments, &c. will be quitted, which have freed many rich Murderers, Poy≈øoners, &c. and of other offendors multitudes, when there have been poor pro≈øecutors. That this mu≈øt be done in the County where the fact is committed, is owned; Let the transferring him from one County to another, when taken out of that County, be ≈øetled in an ea≈øie and ≈øpeedy way; and that a Judge be there ready to determine ≈øuch ca≈øes, weekly, if not daily: however to examine witne≈ø≈øes immediately upon Oath, (which all Ju≈øtices mu≈øt have power to give as they ≈øee cau≈øe; therefore make wi≈øe and hone≈øt Ju≈øtices better then yet are) and let this be taken as evidence, as far as is credible, and let not witne≈ø≈øes ≈øtay a moneth, a quarter, a year for Tryal, and at unrea≈øonable charge: and as ≈øoon as gone, a Tryal; if ≈øtay, a flaw in the Indictment, though the Evidence be plain.

This was Englands old Law; and the rea≈øons are the ≈øame; the alteration was the ≈øweet benefit, not Ju≈øtice or Righteou≈øne≈øs: Why cannot the Ju≈øtices in Ordinary in the County, try Felons, Murders and Trea≈øons, as well by a ≈øetled Commi≈ø≈øion as a Special one: And in all faults, the condition of the fault, and the quality of the per≈øon ought to be ob≈øerved. In an Amerciament, or Fine, I would have but one word for all pur≈øe-pains; for that is ju≈øt, and is our Liberty of old, and now ought to be.

For Murderers of them≈øelves, and Murders and Man≈ølaughters by unknown per≈øons, let ≈øuch rule be as is proportionate for Fines, to deterr, not ruine Wife and Children; and enquiry in all by one ≈øpecially appointed, as with us per Coroner; but let his power and Fee be certain, that he encroach not on the Office of the Ju≈øtice, who is but Inqui≈øitor; yet it might be better to give every Ju≈øtice that power. For Deodands, let the Law be ≈øetled by ≈øome Rule of proportion, which our Law books hold not forth but ≈øolely for the advantage of the Crown ≈øo called; yet under the Right of God as the Prie≈øts portion, this ≈øeems wholly ≈øuper≈øtitious.

For words threatening life, let good Sureties be for the peace; and let due publick and evidently hearty confe≈ø≈øion of his unchri≈øtian walking be before remi≈ø≈øion. This will quiet all double Controver≈øies. For of ≈øuing fir≈øt an Appeal and then an an Indictment, fir≈øt Indictment, and then action, brings that there is no end of labour.
Now let us ≈øee how Felons are to be apprehended.

div.head: How Felons ought to be accu≈øed and apprehended.
div.p: FOR this, for the ≈øecurity of the Priviledge of the people we mu≈øt di≈øtingui≈øh between palpable and publick, ju≈øtly known or probably ≈øu≈øpected Malefactors, and private, and concealed, yet with ≈øome light and po≈ø≈øible cau≈øes of ≈øu≈øpition.

Now in all known ca≈øes, and ju≈øtly ≈øu≈øpected, every one may apprehend without a Warrant, yea if but ju≈øtly, that is, upon ≈øtrong pre≈øumptions ≈øu≈øpected becau≈øe of flying; but in ca≈øe of but probable lighter and le≈ø≈øer ≈øu≈øpitions, no man ought to be apprehended but by Warrant, that is, the cau≈øes of Su≈øpition allowed by the Ju≈øtice, the Warrant is to be granted; if he denyes, the party may go to another; and where ever ju≈øt ≈øu≈øpitions be, or a warrant, the party complaining, except the informations be feigned, or cau≈øes of apprehen≈øion meerly ≈øugge≈øtions, no ≈øuit ought to be; and in ca≈øe the per≈øon be ob≈øtinate and dangerous, or the number many, the Civil Officers may undoubtedly crave the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Military power of the Nation, if any be ready, or otherwi≈øe rai≈øe them, and it is no di≈øpriviledge at all. Now ≈øhortly let us ≈øee how they are to be dealt withall when apprehended.

div.head: How and where impri≈øoned? How maintained? And of the Trea≈øurers therefore.
div.p: AS≈øuredly, things are be≈øt tryed immediately as acted, and would ≈øave much needle≈øs if not unju≈øt and imprudent trouble and vexation in the world, and then impri≈øonment would not be a que≈øtion of ≈øuch controver≈øie.

But in ca≈øe it ≈øhall be delayed a ≈øhort time; for it is unju≈øt to delay ≈øo long as re≈øtraint and charge there (happily of an innocent) ≈øhall bring a greater evil by beggering wife and family, then the original dammage.

Yea, grant it were for Murther; but put it ≈øo; Let the Pri≈øons for criminal offenders be only within walled Towns, or at lea≈øt Corporations, in re≈øpect of the multitude of Inhabitants nece≈ø≈øitated to incorporate, and come under particular Government, not contrary to the general Law of the Nation.

Next, Let them there be maintained at the charge of the County at a ≈øet Rate, if they have not whereof to live, and this according to their condition; and if clearly not guilty of offence again≈øt the Commonwealth, let them be acquitted free from Fees or Fines. To this end, as before, Let the Gaolor and all Officers have Fees from the State out of the Fines; Let there be ≈øpecial Tra≈øurers, to whom the Atrorney for the Commonwealth ≈øhall pay the Fines, as the Record is; for in this there ≈øhall need no abateing of Fines: for all men ≈øhall ≈øtill have ≈øomething to live upon.

For their imployment in pri≈øon, let it be according to their Trade, if not highly criminal, that is for life, in which Ca≈øes the more ≈øpeed ought to be, that ≈øo he may again return to the ≈øervice of the Commonwealth, and ≈øu≈øtentation of his particular Family, unle≈øs a per≈øon notoriou≈øly factious and dangerous, and that in time of danger; in which Ca≈øe better re≈øtrain Liberty private then endanger the publike ≈øafety.

div.head: Who is Baylable.
div.p: THe an≈øwering body for body is now out of u≈øe, or it had better be, and one onely word of bailing u≈øed, wherein the party is to appear at a day, or the Recognizance, that is the ≈øumm wherein he was bound, to be forfreted.

Now ≈øet the Rule certain; in high Trea≈øons where the party is eminent; and times dangerous, ≈øurely to admit Bail were vain; therefore re≈øolve the contrary, for it is no priviledge; yet as ≈øuch, it would be claimed and breed Tumults, or lay the foundation of Sedition.

But for mi≈øpri≈øion of Trea≈øon and words, let them be bayled; but in all Trea≈øons, as in all Ca≈øes of death, ≈øpeedy trial is of nece≈ø≈øity; if the ordinary Judges be not ≈øufficient, ≈øend down either at the Circuit, if ≈øuch may be agreed, or adjoyn others of the ≈øame or adjacent Counties in a ≈øetled way, that the Subject may truly know his time for trial, otherwi≈øe to be bayled of cour≈øe, and ≈øet the Judge his power in certain, that he may know his duty, and perform it without, or be duly que≈øtioned, and his rea≈øon known why he denies.

But for Bayls in Man≈ølaughter, and the like, ≈øet down the value; as for Example, for Man≈ølaughter, two hundred; Maim, one hundred; wounding, fifty; beating, forty; a≈ø≈øault, twenty; or leave it to di≈øcretion of Ju≈øtices, onely put not in men unfit; our pre≈øent ≈øhame.

And thus let all Vagrants, all idle per≈øons though ≈øeemingly, able to live of them≈øelves, if ≈øu≈øpected, or not able to give a good account to the Ju≈øtice, go under bayl for their good behavior, or be ≈øent to the place of their birth; or if found refractory or dangerous, ≈øet to work in Bridewells, well ordered, and ≈øufficiently provided with good, wi≈øe, and faithful Vi≈øitors, Ju≈øtices of the Peace, there to be till enquiry be, or certificate of their condition, that order may be taken accordingly.

Now for the Trial of all per≈øons, let it be, as ≈øpeedy, ≈øo publike, and with one Coun≈øel (no more) if they plea≈øe, who may freely and openly ≈øpeak the Law and no more, not manage evidence as is now u≈øed; and if the Judge denies the Law, let an Appeal lie to the next Circuit under the Councels Hand, and with his Rea≈øon; but if the Judgement be affirmed, let the Councel be highly fined. All the≈øe matters are ≈øubject to devolve into meer Form, except Ju≈øtice in the Supream Magi≈øtrate aws all; for according to their example do all others frame them≈øelves, therefore it is ≈øtill fit they be under due and vi≈øible regulations.

div.head: How Debts are to be Recovered.
div.p: HAving briefly pa≈ø≈øed the≈øe Heads, I come now, before I come to treate of the way and manner of Trials particularly by twelve men, to treate of the Civil Policy as diver≈øe from Criminal, and look at that as it looketh at Liberty, Goods, and good Name.

And in this I ≈øhall pa≈øs over the Introductions to Debts, which are Trading, Bargaining, Selling, Giving, Granting, Bequeathing, and the like, and the con≈øequences thereof; now as to this all Revenge is but be≈øtial, Satisfaction is Rational.

Now the ≈øatisfaction mu≈øt be either from Lands or Goods; Lands for the benefit of Po≈øterity ought to be pre≈øerved as much as may be; therefore till there appear no Goods, there ought to be no Proce≈øs again≈øt Lands; but as the evil pre≈øent is alwayes heavie≈øt, ≈øo the liberty of the Parent is to be e≈øteemed above the future advantage of the i≈ø≈øue, and then the lands are to be ≈øold.

Our Law holds forth things ju≈øt enough; I cannot in my con≈øcience but ≈øay the fault is principally in the Practi≈øer and the Judge; the one to move unju≈øt things, the other to determine them; although I believe many of the Errors were brought in upon Prudential grounds, rather then Legal, or to avoid the rigidity of the Letter originally.

For thus it ≈øtands, the Law being thus anciently, that fir≈øt Goods, then Lands, then Liberty was to be ≈øei≈øed for debts, &c. upon a ju≈øt and proportionate Rule, nece≈ø≈øity found wayes to evade: Quaere the Goods, and they were others; Quaere the Lands, and they were aliened; and to run through the difficulties of all the≈øe Trials, the burthen was found too great, and therefore the Law of impri≈øonment at fir≈øt by Atre≈øt was brought in; That it is again≈øt Priviledge, that is as u≈øed, I believe it highly; but that it is again≈øt Priviledge duly u≈øed, is not to be deemed.

We ought in all things to remember we are Chri≈øtians; our profe≈ø≈øing well, and practi≈øing ill, makes bad Chri≈øtians, nay meer civil ones Athei≈øts, and keeps good Heathens from Conver≈øion; Surely now, we by our Laws make ≈øuch multitudes of poor, that we ≈øee no way to relieve them, and therefore we exact not the Law of common di≈øtributive Ju≈øtice; I dare not be too bitter; The Lord write upon the hearts of Magi≈øtrates ≈øuch (let me ≈øay Chri≈øtian) affections, that the poor may be rightly maintained; but that is not my task here, therefore I proceed.

If any Debtor be, let the Creditor come to a legal Officer appointed, and there Avow in the word of a Chri≈øtian, that ≈øuch a one is truly indebted to him in ≈øo much, and ≈øhew particularly how; if the publike Officer knows the man re≈øpon≈øal, let the Debtor be immediatly ≈øummoned to an≈øwer to the Creditor for ≈øo much, be it by Bill, Bond, Book, Promi≈øe, &c. If the Officer knows not the Creditor, then let the party be ≈øummoned, and if he denies the debt, then let one legal Witne≈øs (for all men are not to be admitted Witne≈ø≈øes) Avow; by that I mean a Prote≈øtation in the name of a Chri≈øtian as before a Magi≈øtrate, that he knows the thing; then if the party ≈øatisfies not the debt by a day, let a Plea be entered.
No more but thus; A. of ≈øuch a place, impleads B. of C. for ten pounds which he ows him upon a Bond or Bill, or as the matter is.

Then let the Debtor an≈øwer thus; B. to the complaint of A. for the debt of ten pounds, denies the debt, promi≈øe, Bond, &c. or pleads ≈øo much paid, and tenders the re≈øidue, with ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to the Order of the Court.

If he appears not, let an other ≈øummons go by way of exacting the party or parties to appear under the penalty of the value of the debt; if he appear not, nor any Attorny for him being warned, let the goods be immediately ≈øei≈øed and inventoried by one ≈øworn man or more, and apprized by ≈øworn men, as they are truly worth, then to be bought at the fir≈øt hand, to the utmo≈øt of their knowledge; and let one Ju≈øtice of the Peace admini≈øter the Oath, to appear equally and indifferently between Creditors and Debtors; then let a Jury of twelve or ≈øix men, ≈øuch as ≈øhall be lawfully called of the next neighbours, capable of the great tru≈øt of ≈øuch Judgement, ≈øufficiently qualified with e≈øtate to recompence, knowledge to di≈øcern, and faithfulne≈øs to act according to knowledge, for ≈øuch ought all Juries to be, and then the Trial by Juries is excellent, where the matter needs, or will bear the delay, except you ≈øhall ≈øo enforce obedience, that Trials may be ≈øpeeded as called; then the debt proved, let not payment be till all Creditors be called in, and then let their debts al≈øo be proved, not allowing above forty dayes for all, and then let the goods be divided into three parts, if there be no other e≈øtate; otherwi≈øe three parts of the whole be di≈øtributed proportionately as the re≈øpective debts amount, a third part ≈øaved to the Creditor, &c. And the ≈øame Trial that ≈øettles the goods, let it pa≈øs the lands, and let the Sei≈øure of the Land and Sale be by the publike Magi≈øtrate, but all enrowled in a Book for that purpo≈øe.

div.head: How Lands are to be Recovered.
div.p: SUrely the old way of State and Sei≈øin ≈øo called in the ≈øimplicity of that Age was good; but to ≈øpeak it once for all, it is the Magna Charta, the great priviledge of Free men, that they may make Laws according to nece≈ø≈øity.

I write not this to de≈øtroy, but enlarge the Subjects Priviledge, who now by the practike part of Law are deprived of the ju≈øt end of Magna Charta, and all el≈øe. I know there is a conceited humerous generation, that are content with nothing but the Letter of Magna Charta, and others as much again≈øt it; I ≈øhall equally walk equally between them; It was then a good boundary to the Prerogatives of Princes, and power of Judges; and it were better to follow that truly now, then to be again ingulphed in as va≈øt an Ocean as no Law, in the variety, multiplicity, and difficulty of Laws; for how many things, literally ob≈øerved, would plainly much prejudice the Commonwealth; but I proceed.

Lands then in ca≈øe of doubt mu≈øt receive a Trial, as for other matters of value, before a publike Judge, the cour≈øe by a ≈øhort complaint, at a day ≈øet for both parties, with their Witne≈ø≈øes pre≈øent, who can prove the matter in que≈øtion, or upon Oath made that they are ≈øick, or ≈øuch Ca≈øe as is allowed upon Oath taken before a Ju≈øtice of Peace; the Affidavit of ≈øuch per≈øons may be read, atte≈øted under the Ju≈øtices Hand and Seal.

Alwayes provided the Affidavit without another ≈øpecial Witne≈øs doth nothing; and in Ca≈øe that the land be adjudged to the complainant, to be immediately awarded, and delivered within three dayes, under the penalty of a Fine Treble value (for the time it is holden above three dayes) to the rent for half a year: For obedience in Civils mu≈øt be rendred to mi≈øtaken judgements, final or primary; if final, for ever; if primary, till death of the party, unle≈øs he lives ten or twenty years; for it is fit to ≈øet a time after ≈øuch judgements, that ≈øo it may be fit for a Purcha≈øer, who may otherwi≈øe pay his money, and lo≈øe his land; if the Demandant or Complainer be not able to make good his Title, let him pay the Fine for the charges of the Defendent, as is adjudged in open Court, and then let him be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed; which Fine mu≈øt be according to the nature of the offence, and the e≈øtate of the party, both being con≈øidered.

div.head: How Equity is to be pur≈øued.
div.p: BUt it may happen that part of the money in a per≈øonal action, or complaint is paid, and that the land is forfeited in ca≈øe of a Mortgage upon a Cau≈øe equitable in Law, as enemies hindred, great Waters, robbed going to tender the money, and bound, or the like, (not voluntary neglects as now, whereby the controver≈øing in Courts is more expen≈øive to the Subject then the Army) which appearing in the legal Court before the Judge there; let him tran≈ømit the Ca≈øe upon his word of a ≈øworn Judge (that is intended upon his Oath) that there is ju≈øt matter of equity, and let him ≈øee the Ca≈øe, and examine what Witne≈ø≈øes he plea≈øes, and fend for what other he judges fit; always provided, he decrees the Ca≈øe within a ≈øet time, as ten dayes at the furthe≈øt, and then let po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion be continued, or adjudged, as the Ca≈øe requires.
This al≈øo mu≈øt be pur≈øued, that no rule at Common Law, or Order ≈øo called in Court of Equity, but be Ingro≈ø≈øed, Read, and Signed by the Judge before going out of Court.

Now to ≈øome, there will ≈øome difficulties ari≈øe at fir≈øt; what needs this double work, may not one Court determine Equity al≈øo? Next the Lawyers will never agree an Order with the Judge in Court, advantages are ≈øo ≈øought and preferred, as daily experience manife≈øteth.

div.head: Whether Law Courts and of Equity al≈øo, are to be?
div.p: FOr this it is mo≈øt certain, that while men, we mu≈øt in all lawful ways give ≈øatisfaction to the experienced evils ari≈øing among≈øt men, and that as the evil is capable of reformation; heretofore many delays and draynings of the truth in a ≈øet legal cour≈øe was thought a good way, (or at lea≈øt ≈øo pretended) to make ju≈øtice pure; form was ≈øet up to an eminent height, and ≈øeeing the Idol men bowed down to it, and it was thought better to part with ≈øome real Ju≈øtice then lo≈øe a ≈øhadow, which gave refre≈øhment to ≈øo many, &c.

Now, this though it may have ≈øhadow, which as the world grows pa≈øt amu≈øing, will fall of it ≈øelf, ≈øo it hath ≈øub≈øtance; for the work is proper to another judgement, and of it ≈øelf likely to be ≈øufficient for one Court, e≈øpecially if tho≈øe men be impowered to hear and determine all ≈ømall matters of equity, as it is fit.
The other Judges in Civil Courts ≈øhould do all matters of trifle, and al≈øo all ≈øuits both legal and equitable of poor men.

div.head: What, and why pleaders are to be, and their Duties.
div.p: SUrely, the knowledge of the Laws municipal, and ju≈øt, and righteous, ≈øetled Cu≈øtomes of Nations, which are Laws, are highly to be honoured, e≈øteemed, and provided for; they are the left eye of the Nation, as the in≈øtructers of the Nation in the knowledge of divine wi≈ødom are the right eye.

Now to draw men to ≈øuch labours, there mu≈øt be ≈øome allurements; we had ≈øo many, that of late years it drew all the prime wits and parts of the Nation that way, and all the Courts being at We≈øtmin≈øter, the whole Nation during the ≈øo called Terms, was void of requi≈øite Government; for the≈øe wits to maintain and encrea≈øe their honour and riches, had made the Law ≈øo difficult, that good hone≈øt Knights and Squires in the Counties, yea though they had ≈øtudied the Law, dur≈øt not venture upon a matter extraordinary; how then ≈øhould Citizens? and the≈øe, and the Attorneys, by the adjudges tricks and niceties, had buried Ju≈øtice pa≈øt finding out by Juries; each man had his legal quillet to deceive the hone≈øt man, prejudice the State, and yet ≈øatisfie his ≈øo called con≈øcience.

Now if pleaders be rightly u≈øed, then they are no more but men skilled in the Law, who are for the party who choo≈øes them for their Councel, that is, ≈øuch upon who≈øe judgement and skill in Law they will depend, to make good the Law for them to the Judge, to manage evidence, which ≈øome have been famou≈øly infamous for; to do what they can for the Clyent, that is by lawful or unlawful wayes to get the day, is mo≈øt unchri≈øtian.

Thus yet old Lawyers through tricks, u≈øe to deceive young Lawyers, and unpracti≈øed Judges, or old, or ≈øleepy, or ≈øuch ignorant ones as have been admitted and continued, till they with credit of con≈øcience left their place; therefore it is unfit any Lawyer ≈øpeak but to the Law, and that only to the Judge, and that to enform him, and require his advice, and that he ask the≈øe que≈øtions. Let all the≈øe Lawyers after admitted to plead, ≈øet in the Court, below the Judges, covered but when they ≈øpeak; and any one as a friend to ju≈øtice though not retained, may ≈øpeak to the Iudge his opinion; And let all but the pre≈øent pleaders be as a≈ø≈øi≈øtants, as to ≈øo much as information of the Law according to their skill and knowledge; let but one be retayned for one man, and let not his Fee be above two ≈øhillings ≈øix pence; and that a ≈øupply be, let each one have a pen≈øion or an office from the State, and then in ca≈øe it amounts to a competent ≈øalary, it is better to allow no Fee at all; The objections of lazine≈øs and
the like which will en≈øue upon this, are no way an≈øwerable to the nece≈ø≈øity of giving ≈øtop to the immoderate labouring after riches now in this generation, and that onely to be Fathers to a lazy idle ignorant gallant Son, &c.

div.head: What Attornies are to be, and their Duties.
div.p: MAny will think Attornies as needle≈øs as Courts of Equity, and ≈øo they are; yea truly not of ≈øo much nece≈ø≈øity; yet much good there is in Attornies. But ≈øo many is to nouri≈øh knavety and ≈øhew an unchri≈øtian Commonwealth; for many of them cannot live, no more then many Lawyers, without much contention; Which ≈øhews ≈øtrongly that our Commonwealth is but baptized Chri≈øtian, with water, not the Spirit of love, meekne≈øs, gentlene≈øs, peace, long ≈øufferance, forgiving as we would be forgiven; Oh the ≈øad ca≈øe of Chri≈øtendome ≈øo called! I mu≈øt grieve to think of it, though others laugh at me.

But while all men are not capable of the plaine≈øt forms of Law, it may be conceived requi≈øite to admit men who ≈øhall appear by their warrant to an≈øwer for them; but men to be nece≈ø≈øitated to it of cu≈øtome, as now, ≈øeems not ju≈øt; Two belonging to every Court of Judicature is enough; let his duty be onely to receive in≈øtructions from the party in the matter of Fact, and to ≈øet down the witne≈ø≈øes names in a paper for the Judge, and to what they can ≈øpeak, but not to ≈øpeak in the Court, but to the Judge, and let them have a Fee as the Magi≈øtrate ≈øhall think fit.
Let both Lawyers and Attornies be ≈øineable by the Judge, and all that plead as ≈øuch in Ca≈øe of mi≈ødemeanor, and that without a Jury.

div.head: Whether Debtors be to be impri≈øoned.
div.p: Surely where there is neither goods nor Lands to ≈øatisfie, the rational man, the Law of Chri≈øt, of Love, will not ≈øtill engage to ≈øatisfie angry revengeful per≈øons, in exorbitant and irrational appetites; therefore if he will take oath that he is not worth a third part of the Debt, that not exceeding ≈øixty pounds, or what ≈øumm the ≈øupreme Magi≈øtrate thinks fit, let him be freed; let the oath be general or particular, I care not; for he that will ≈øwear upon a tru≈øt, will ≈øwear upon no tru≈øt; but let the thing concealed be forfeit: if you will not do this, keep not debtors in pri≈øon, rather make them ≈øervants; the ≈øame for Felons, Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øors, and the like.

div.head: Whether ≈øervitude be lawful among Chri≈øtians? &c. And whether fitting, or not?
div.p: SUrely the Almighty wi≈ødome appointed nothing in it ≈øelf but ju≈øt, and that ju≈øtly, yea above other Law-givers, who from want of prudence, oft multiplied ≈øervants to ≈øuch numbers as they oft oretopped their Ma≈øters and the Laws; but the Lord by allowing ≈øervitude among his people, yet limiting it for a time, gave ≈øatisfaction to ju≈øtice every way; the proprietor was ≈øatisfied by labor, where e≈øtate failed, and the ≈øervant had his day of freedom, and the danger of multitudes was never obnoxious to them; for we ≈øee the Lords and great men offended in forcing ≈øervice, but not the contrary; ≈øervice therefore well limited, is held by many and tho≈øe prudent men, and godly Chri≈øtians, no way di≈ø≈øonant to the Liberty, nay equality of the Go≈øpel, wherein by Chri≈øt we are brethren, and fit to be practi≈øed as well as bound Apprentices, but with well tempered Laws.

As fir≈øt the power not to extend to life or mayme, next not work above ≈øo many hours in a day, then to be cloathed again≈øt cold, and fed for Natures ≈øu≈øtenance, that is, he ≈øhall be better then in a pri≈øon; the greate≈øt difficulty will be to make ≈øervants of wife and children; for it ≈øeems to ≈øome unrea≈øonable, that they ≈øhould be made ≈øervants: Our Heralds in many heads have made ≈øuch ≈øhatters, that they cannot think fit a high-born man or woman, or the like (which are accidents of inferiour providence, as I may call it) ≈øhould be ≈øubject to the univer≈øal Law of Mankind; but certain it is, if all Debtors, &c. pay or ≈øerve, the≈øe men ought not to be excluded; but that the women mu≈øt follow the condition of man, is not of nece≈ø≈øity, no more then to be impri≈øoned, &c. ≈øhe mu≈øt be mi≈øerable, but needs not be in ≈øervitude, nor the Children.

Now the Law-maker ought to ≈øettle ≈øomething again≈øt them, upon two grounds; Fir≈øt, of ≈øatisfaction; ≈øecondly, of aw or fear; upon this ≈øcore to make the children and wife ≈øuffer, would do much as ≈øome think; but I conceive otherwi≈øe; for ≈øelf is generally neere≈øt: Next for children, it would or might ruine education, whereby the publick lo≈øeth more then the private gains.

La≈øtly, for the wife, if all parties be plea≈øed, let them come and ≈øerve together; otherwi≈øe not; But under the Law of mercy to ≈øhew mercy and love, let the evident poor man be di≈øcharged, as before, with ≈øomething to begin the world; but once more repre≈øs idle hou≈øes of all ≈øorts, vanity in Apparel, &c.

And ≈øettle e≈øtates, and rate them truly, and keep ≈øtrict and ju≈øt Government, and you will not complain of poor, nor fear cheating, nor need ≈øervitude, but with content of all parties; but above all, take off high Covetize, and preach by example, as precept; Magi≈øtrates, Mini≈øters, &c. men of all ≈øorts having food and rayment, be therewith content. But becau≈øe U≈øury is ≈øuppo≈øed a manife≈øt cau≈øe of beggery, and is ≈øo much que≈øtioned in the world, and ≈øo beaten by the Pope and his Councels, and U≈øurers ≈øo accur≈øed, and our Law pre≈øent onely wincks, tolerates not, let us a little con≈øider that, and Quaere,

div.head: Whether ∆≤≈øury be lawful? And how compared with Letting of Lands.
div.p: I Take U≈øury to be a Covenanting for to receive the principall with intere≈øt; Now the rea≈øon of the coming to a ≈øetled way of u≈øe by particular per≈øons, that is, twenty, fifteen, ten, eight, ≈øix, or four in the hundred, was upon con≈øent of parties to avoid tedious and deceitful accounts and reckonings, and the like, (the Laws ≈øettles it to avoid exce≈ø≈øive gripings) ju≈øt as in Lands the Tenant hires now at a certain price, and puts the gain in his pocket; truth is, we are a light, loo≈øe, proud, lazy, prodigal Generation; for we have had much liberty, educated under no re≈øtraint, aw, nor fear, no reverence of youth to Age, of people to Magi≈øtrates, of poor to rich, no order, all men now Ma≈øters, all brave, all for back and belly; this ≈øpends fa≈øt, and gains are decrea≈øed, and oft all lo≈øt, and then the fault is u≈øe-money: I pray what difference between being undone by a cruel racking Landlord, or a biting hard-hearted U≈øurer? you will ≈øay all one; He that gains little by Land or Money, cryes, I had rather take money, and hire Land to give account; I am undone; ≈øome by being unfit to manage Land, or Money; others by ill managing of it; he that thrives, will never agree to this; no, that were to be alwayes a ≈øervant: Again, ≈øome will over-purcha≈øe them≈øelves, and receive four in the hundred in Lands, and pay eight; and this ruines them; others have good Trades, in debt, purcha≈øe, pay u≈øe, and thrive; Nay it is certain, Money is a more po≈ø≈øible way of great increa≈øe, then Lands; and the Complaints even in all Nations much what alike; therefore I conclude as to that it is fit to regulate letting out of Moneys; but it is al≈øo fit to order ≈øome proportion for Lands, or give a Rule for Landlords, that ≈øqueaze a poor ignorant labouring creature, as we do a Honey-comb; let neither be permitted unju≈øtly; and for rich Tenants, let them not defraud the Commonwealth.

This premi≈øed, U≈øury in it ≈øelf may be lawful, if not forbidden; now if it be forbidden, let me ≈øee where it is; if it were Typical, it is aboli≈øhed; if judicial generally, it is rational, that is, all tho≈øe Laws hold forth the rea≈øon of commanding, or prohibiting plainly, and then let us ≈øee the rea≈øon.

Now if you take it judiciall ≈øpecially, as proper to the Jew, then it mu≈øt by like rea≈øon run thus, Take no u≈øe of thy Brother a Chri≈øtian; the Engli≈øh Tran≈ølation hath it poor Brother, which to me plainly hints the Law, and its rea≈øon, and that ju≈øtly; and this not ob≈øerved, is unchri≈øtian; ≈øo to impri≈øon for meer u≈øe, the principal received, much more all lo≈øt; and that not by neglect, folly, or exorbitancy; for all the≈øe differ the Ca≈øe in the Court of Chri≈øtian Con≈øcience; but for rich men to detain u≈øe is unju≈øt, or if able to pay, for to plead it while cloathed as Princes might be, is a ≈øhame to the Governours; God hath not bound us Chri≈øtians to Laws of meats, particular Judicials, wherein the command was onely to try obedience, therefore regulated; it is without que≈øtion as lawful as letting of Lands, much more lawful then buying for three pence in the ≈øea≈øon of the year, and for half a years benefit of laying out of the money, to get twelve-pence, fourteen-pence, which is ten fold, nay one hundred-fold wor≈øe u≈øury then twenty per cent. yet this is u≈øual and never ≈øtumbled at; but to double is counted lawful nece≈ø≈øary gain; how ever if the Law allows not, let it not wink; I now come upon the rule of like rea≈øon to Quaere,

div.head: Whether tortures be lawful among Chri≈øtians, and whether again≈øt Priviledge?
div.p: WEE have before agreed what Priviledge is, and wherein it con≈øi≈øts, and that publike good is to be preferred above private.

Now we come to particular que≈øtions concerning it; and that is, whether it be again≈øt Priviledge; but being that the re≈øolving of the other part of the que≈øtion will in the greate≈øt part, if not wholly a≈ø≈øoyl that:

I fir≈øt examine, whether Chri≈øtianity allows it; I might fir≈øt have determined, whether Nature allows it; for if Nature ≈øeeks Self-pre≈øervation, it allows it not; then ≈øurely it is unnatural to force to overthrow Self; it is agreed, many dete≈øtable Murders, Rapes, Adulteries, Trea≈øons, &c. to the pre≈øervation of States, and glory of God, in ju≈øt puni≈øhing of offenders, have hence ari≈øen; but this may be Gods mercy to bring good out of evil.

Our Rule is, Let's not do evil that good may come of it; Now this hath al≈øo been manife≈øted, that much evil have come of it; not onely many Innocents have ≈øuffered in it, but by cruelty have been fal≈øely accu≈øed by ≈øuch parties, ea≈øie natures being drawn, and in the torment have ≈øpoken any thing; ≈øo that it is no certain Rule, and if no certain Rule, and a ≈øevere puni≈øhment, and that of one not convicted, it is not onely unchri≈øtian, but irrational; the vain Chri≈øtian I know, is ready enough to ≈øeek a≈ø≈øurance again≈øt fears by ≈øuch extremities; but it is better to tru≈øt Providence, be≈øt ≈øo to live as not to fear to die; I ≈øhall not enlarge in this, which is ≈øo plain, but ha≈øte and con≈øider

div.head: Whether all publike Offices and Charges be to be born by the publike Pur≈øe, and what is the publike revenue.
div.p: IT was never denied in any State or Nation; For the labourer is worthy of his hire: The Laws of this Nation allow it; yet onely to a competency for the nece≈ø≈øary charges of the place; not the charge which Pride, Vanity, and Cu≈øtom hath introduced, or may.

Now a≈ø≈øuredly this ought to be ≈øetled in certain, or rather to be ≈øo ≈øetled, as may be reduced to a certainty from the Judge Supream, to the Con≈øtable and Scavenger, who≈øe place is now di≈øu≈øed to the great di≈ørepute of the Nation, and offence of Natives, as well as Strangers, and the Laws take no notice of them, onely Cu≈øtoms of Cities, &c. which Cu≈øtoms, how good ≈øo ever, are made ≈øo difficult in pleading from Form, and ≈øo chargeable, if granted by Charters, that the Government is wholly lo≈øt and di≈øu≈øed; they ought to have power to imploy men to clean≈øe all places of filth, carry away dunghils, &c. and puni≈øh offenders, and they to be paid out of the publike Revenue.

Now the publike Pur≈øe and Revenue is all mens lands and goods equally rated; deny this, and all men will make places of Tru≈øt ≈øerviceable to their ends: Nature is above Rea≈øon, above formal educative profe≈ø≈øing Religion, and mi≈øleads Saints oft-times. I cea≈øe further inlarging this, having in other part ≈øetled the Rea≈øon of it before.

div.head: How mad men, Ideots, &c. are to be provided for.
div.p: IT ought not to be in the power of every man to make or adjudge Ideots Lunaticks, &c.

Therefore it is fit in every County ≈øome Court be appointed, as to appoint Guardians and Tutors to children, ≈øo to determine who are mad, and who fools, and to order the management of their e≈øtates, and places to be ≈øpecially provided for them with a ≈øettled Phy≈øition; and if the party be able, his e≈øtate mu≈øt as the Magi≈øtrate appoints bear the charge; otherwi≈øe the publike and this Court to order all Bridewells and Pri≈øons, and Commi≈ø≈øioners to that end authorized, ≈øpecially with ≈øetled power to determine the ≈øame, and all matters thereupon ari≈øing, and to Record it; all yet to have ≈øuperintendent Judges Vi≈øitors, as afore≈øaid.

div.head: Whether the Tenures of the Nation can ≈øtand with the freedom of the Nation?
div.p: PUblike and Univer≈øal con≈øent took away not onely the Tenure in Capite, which was originally the great mans dependence upon the King, and after great and ≈ømall being become every ones purcha≈øe while annexed to Lands, which was incongruous, but al≈øo Knights Service, becau≈øe of the dependence of mean per≈øons upon Lords by Sword-Service; and the rather for the incidents now become ≈øo in≈øufferable, of Ward≈øhip, Marriage and Relief, and the prime rea≈øon effecting it next to the power which ≈øtruck the fir≈øt ≈øtroak, or nothing had been done, was the original ground of the In≈øtitution of the Tenure cea≈øed.
I need ≈øay no more for Coppyholds; a wi≈øe unintere≈øted man will ≈øpeedily conclude the rea≈øon of the in≈øtitution of the Tenure is gone.

Truly you Lords of Mannors, you it concerns, I pray con≈øider upon what grounds you hold Courts, ≈øwear men, Fine at plea≈øure, ≈øeize goods, or de≈øtrain; a cunning Lawyer might find you all in the forfeiture of all your Mannors: How many Mannors have ≈øprung up ≈øince Prohibition? but this is but by the By; the State may look to ≈øuch Chequer Rents and forfeits in time; but to the thing it ≈øelf.

The≈øe dependences are vi≈øibly de≈øtructive to the peace, quiet, and purity of Government in the Nation; next the forfeitures are unju≈øt, being con≈øtantly for no cau≈øe rea≈øonable; again the pro≈øecution or finding it is al≈øo unju≈øt, being by the ≈øo called Homage the Lords men; this abu≈øe is evident; Some Lords ≈øetting them≈øelves in Court, and threatning the Homage if but que≈øtioning the rea≈øons of the matter in que≈øtion, and make them find what they plea≈øe, yet ≈øworn.

La≈øtly, incertain Fines are wholly unju≈øt; and above all the dependences of Free men; for now Coppyholds is al≈øo become each mans purcha≈øe, yea Free mens; this is clear again≈øt the original Con≈øtitution; and the rea≈øon cea≈øing, the Law ought to cea≈øe; but if the intere≈øts of Lords prevail for the pre≈øent, that there be no totall abolition of the name, and remembrance of that Tenure, no more then of Capite and Knights Service, which is equally ju≈øt; yet let the Commonwealth have its due freedom, let the Fines be made certain, one years clear value, which cannot be above two parts in three.
Next, No forfeitures; next to pa≈øs by free deed; la≈øtly, all as Free-hold at Common Law, except onely the Rent; for it is better enlarge the Rent and have no Fine.

La≈øtly, let no Rent be di≈øtrainable for upon the land after eighteen moneths due; and for the apportionment of Rent, let it be recorded between Buyer and Seller; and if parties concerned cannot, let two Ju≈øtices of the Peace upon hearing both parties determine it, and let it be recorded in the Pari≈øh or Town-book, to cea≈øe all Controver≈øies after.

To clear this, Let a Commi≈ø≈øion i≈ø≈øue to ≈øome per≈øons to return a Survey of all Mannors, when granted, what Cu≈øtoms, what Tenants, what Rents, Free or Coppy; the quantity and nature of lands, particularly the value yearly, that ≈øo a foundation of ≈øettlement may be laid; but becau≈øe of the great advantage hath been ≈øaid to accrue to the Commonwealth by Coppyhold-lands, above free and Charter-hold, in re≈øpect they were not ≈øubject to cheats, frauds, &c, as Free-hold lands, let us a little con≈øider how lands are to be pa≈ø≈øed.

div.head: Whether Inrollments ought to be in each County, and how, and the way to avoid deceit in Conveyances, &c. and of Frauds, and the be≈øt way of puni≈øhing them.
div.p: HEretofore Deceits were not ≈øo frequent; men, yea even the highe≈øt preferred honor above inheritance; Now as the love of riches, the god of the world prevailed, ≈øo private intere≈øt grew, and from thence loo≈øene≈øs of Law; and the jealou≈øie between our Kings and people, made Laws come forth difficulty, and when ever they came, the intere≈øt of one ≈øide was vi≈øible, or the Law ≈øo choaked with ambiguities, or incertainties, or ≈øo ≈øhort in the main, that it did but add to Contention, be≈øides the difficulty of obtaining them, without an active leading Parliament man were the Author or eager promoter, which in tho≈øe dayes few would or did undertake out of pure zeal; ≈øo that men ≈øet down willingly by the evil, and lookt to prevent it as well as they could, and take their chance, as they called it, among≈øt others, rather then ≈øtir for new Laws of any ≈øort.

This made of late years, the legal robberies of cheating and truly fraudulent conveyances encrea≈øe (as well as Letters) yet not within the adjudged remedy of Statute, frequent; for it is as ea≈øie to avoid the Statute as to quench ordinary fire with ≈øcalding hot water; one good Law again≈øt all frauds, is better then a hundred of the be≈øt again≈øt fraudulent conveyances; the rea≈øon is ≈øo gro≈øs and vi≈øible that it neds no pre≈øident, there are yet too many.

But while all po≈ø≈øible means of the exact purity of Ju≈øtice are to be indeavored by all Magi≈øtrates, e≈øpecially Chri≈øtian: It is ju≈øt and requi≈øite, that they take the hint of the good hath flown from the manner of pa≈ø≈øing of Coppyhold E≈øtates, which truly proves, that an Office of Inrollment, at lea≈øt in the Head-Town of every County, is of nece≈ø≈øity, with ≈øuch due regulations as is fit; and in the ≈øame Office, a pa≈ø≈øing of the wives con≈øent, by ≈øealing the Deed of Sale, or relea≈øing it; provided, the Act be done before two Ju≈øtices of the Peace, be as good as a Fine; the Dedimus upon the Fine, is to meaner per≈øons, le≈øs fit to be tru≈øted then ≈øome Ju≈øtices may be; however not under the con≈øcience of an Oath, which all they be; the charge of a Fine is not ≈øo much (though to ≈øome it is more then they are worth, and ought to hold ≈øome rule of proportion) as the trouble, care, delay, &c.
Let there be therefore alwayes ≈øome authorized to take the≈øe.

There is another legal, I dare not call it deceit; the Cu≈øtom hath e≈øtabli≈øhed it, as a Fine to bar the i≈ø≈øue, intayle, or a recovery, or both, with ≈øingle and double voucher; but what is this but Cu≈øtom again≈øt the Statute Law, by the a≈ø≈øent of the Statute? I know the Eva≈øion is but a meer Eva≈øion; it is better to mould the Law anew; for the Law is both wayes unju≈øt; for the Statute Dedonis, is in it ≈øelf a perpetuity, and would ≈øettle lands impa≈øsible in a ≈øhort time, and then all men mu≈øt flie to the Supream Power for remedy; let them therefore ≈øettle how lands ≈øhall be De jure; as for example,

The elde≈øt ≈øon to have all, two parts of three, or three of four, or a double portion, or at the will of the father; provided he gives it no otherwi≈øe but to him and his heires: and indeed all other e≈øtates are but to be a little over-wi≈øe; but in this I ≈øhall not undertake to pre≈øcribe ought.

I ≈øhall onely add, let the Law be; All frauds to be puni≈øhed by Pre≈øentment, which found legally, dammages to be to the party according to the value proved, and then a fine to the State, according to the Law and the nature of the offence. Now this, according to Law, brings us to di≈øcu≈ø≈øion of Juries,

div.head: Whether it be be≈øt to have Trials by Juries? and in that of the Cour≈øe of all Trials Civil.
div.p: ALL agree, that right is to be done; but many, nay mo≈øt differ about the way; and certainly there are divers wayes, and all good; but there are better wayes, and the be≈øt; but the diver≈øity of Opinions is great in the≈øe; for ≈øome call that be≈øt which others call but good: ≈øo various is Judgement, much more Opinion; for many which have found the good of one ju≈øt, wi≈øe, di≈øcerning Magi≈øtrate, will think him better then a Jury of Twelve; and they that have found corruption in one Magi≈øtrate, and Ju≈øtice from Twelve men, abhor what they call Prerogative Sentence; it mu≈øt be a≈ø≈øented to that while in the fle≈øh, the be≈øt men are ≈øubject to fails and mi≈øtakes, and therefore to drain Ju≈øtice hath been thought the be≈øt; this with popular jealou≈øie in the ju≈øt fears of dependencies of Judges rivited England to the maintenance of Juries, who will not ea≈øily forgo it; and though there is at pre≈øent ≈øo much mi≈øcarriage, that I think there is far more evil then good by them to the Nation, I would not their temporary ejection, but their due, ≈øtrict, and ≈øetled Regulation.

But fir≈øt, every Ca≈øe is not worth ≈øuch trouble; but Ju≈øtice mu≈øt be done in every Ca≈øe; and unle≈øs you will pay Juries for their pains, they cannot travel; therefore to avoid this, you mu≈øt make Judges in every Town; and though the letter of the Magna Charta is general, yet do but the Ju≈øtice of Magna Charta, and the Subject will not complain. Ju≈øtice never wrought di≈øpriviledge, and is above Magna Charta. But before we proceed with Jurors, let's ≈øee how Ca≈øes ought to come to the deci≈øion of Juries, then what Juries, &c.

Now it is ju≈øt, that before any ≈øuit be, the party wronged ≈øhould fir≈øt privately ≈øeek peace, then call the party before a Magi≈øtrate to know what the difference is, and ≈øee if it yet may be compo≈øed; if this will not do, let a Magi≈øtrate allow a legal controver≈øie.

Then let his Ca≈øe be ≈øet down ≈øpecially as it is, after the nature of an Action upon the Ca≈øe, and let Oath be of the truth of it, and that he is able to make it good by Law; let the Ca≈øe barely be ≈øtated, no Conceits, no Opinions, but the naked truth, which the Complainant is to make good.

Let this alwayes be within twelve moneths after cau≈øe of Action. Then let a Summons go to the Defendant by a ≈øworn Officer from the Court, or the party, or ≈øome other making Oath of the Summons; if he appears not, let a Note be fixed to his door, (under a ≈øevere penalty to any one to take off) requiring appearance, or to ≈øhew Cau≈øe; if neither be done, let the Trial immediatly be awarded; if he appear, let the day of hearing be ordered and entered in the Court-book, (and that truly by the Clerk under a ≈øevere Fine, immediatly to be deducted by abatement in his Salary;) after which time, let a Jury of twelve or ≈øix men (for it is not the number that doth the work, I think ≈øix be≈øt; but that conte≈øt is not worth the while: the alteration of an old received way is the greate≈øt objection) be warned, not under the penalty of twenty, or one hundred pounds, and nothing ever paid, but of ten or five ≈øhillings, to be a≈ø≈øuredly levied to the States u≈øe immediatly of Cour≈øe, unle≈øs ≈øick in bed, or otherwi≈øe imployed in the Service of the Commonwealth in the County above twenty miles, or hindred by Providence; which Cau≈øes ≈øworn and allowed, may excu≈øe or e≈ø≈øoyn him; for not ≈øummoned, the Officer is ≈øworn, and mu≈øt admit no pre≈øent conte≈øt.

Now the men mu≈øt be knowing, under≈øtanding men, and of e≈øtate to an≈øwer dammages, (if that be continued) if they give a fal≈øe Verdict, which is ju≈øt, being they are properly Judges of the dammage: now if they and the Judge differ upon the Law, let them do it at their peril; for the Ca≈øe, let it be ≈øtated, the Judges and their hands with the Coun≈øel pre≈øent ≈øet to it, and let the yearly Judges decide it; and if the Judge be faulty, let him, otherwi≈øe the Jury be fined to the State; and if they give a fal≈øe Verdict, that is, go not truly according to what is truly alledged and proved, unle≈øs they or ≈øome of them of their own knowledge know the thing of which they are bound to give the Court publike Cognizance; for Juries as other Judges are under a Rule of Rea≈øon and Common Ju≈øtice.

then Jurors mu≈øt be of the next inhabitants to the place where the fact was Committed, of the vicinage, neer dwellers, ≈øo that they know the parties, their lives and conver≈øations, and thereby judge; But there ought to be no relations of Con≈øanguinity or Affinity within three degrees; for although ≈øpiritual or publick relations ought to be preferred above natural, yet this is now little known, le≈øs regarded.

La≈øtly, he mu≈øt not be who is a Jury-man, a common Swearer, Drinker, Company-keeper, nor ejected any congregation as an evil per≈øon, an offender again≈øt the peace and quiet of the Nation, or one that hath declared his opinion before ≈øworn: It is agreed, it is be≈øt object again≈øt the Juror before ≈øworn, but what the court is mi≈øtaken in, ought not to be proceeded in; therefore till they be as we ≈øay gone from the bar ju≈øt objections may be offered; but the Judge mu≈øt not allow objections as to favor or ≈øurmi≈øes after ≈øworn; if it be, let it be proved (for let no Juror after ≈øworn be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, but the rea≈øon recorded) and this proof is ea≈øie, and then let him be fined.

div.head: When Judgement ought to be, and Execution. And when void.
div.p: IUdgement ought immediately to follow Execution, unle≈øs ≈øome ju≈øt cau≈øe, and that only in Law be offered; and for execution (notwith≈øtanding the cau≈øe which may be for delay alledged) let the goods be ≈øecured, or the money depo≈øited, or no cau≈øe allowed; And if the party be pre≈øent, let him enter caution immediately to perform the judgement; or otherwi≈øe to impri≈øon his per≈øon, is not di≈øpriviledge if he be able, till he performs it, let the caution be ≈øetting his hand to the judgement, which ought to amount in Law to above all Statutes or Cu≈øtomary Judgements; alwayes provided if the execution be not within twelve moneths, upon any Judgement whatever, the Judgement to be void; for the long hanging of judgements and other ≈øecurities is al≈øo legall inju≈øtice; I ≈øay no more.

div.head: Offendors in impannelling Juries, Imbracers, and the like.
div.p: FOr offendors in putting in knowingly unfit Jurors in any kind, let them be fined, and the Fines high, and deducted out of their ≈øalary, if any in hand; otherwi≈øe by di≈øtre≈øs, be≈øides lo≈øs of that place, and di≈øabled of any other, for at lea≈øt ≈øome years, for it mu≈øt be perjury, for he is a ≈øworn Officer.
For drawers of Iurors, or informers of them aforehand, to draw them to one party, let all be upon pre≈øentment, and tryed and fined.

div.head: What Di≈øtre≈ø≈øes are lawful.
div.p: THe Law is ju≈øt that no man be de≈øtrained in that whereby he principally earns his living, if ought el≈øe be.

But to di≈øtrain one man for a Fine due from a Hundred, Town, &c. this is hard, without ≈øpeedy remedy, is unju≈øt; let this be generally committed to a Court, and right done as the fact appears, that is, let an equal rate be, and the Con≈øtable and Over≈øeers gather it, and pay it immediately with re≈øpect to his dammage adjudged and ≈øet; and if they will not, let the Court enforce the rate, and all charges upon it; and ≈øo in all other Ca≈øes.

div.head: What to be done in ca≈øes of wa≈øte, &c.
div.p: IN ca≈øe of wa≈øte, let the forfeiture be certain; for Tenants for year by Lea≈øe, let it be their Term, except an incom be, and for that let a Jury mitigate.
For Guardians of Infants, Tenants for life, and the like, let it be treble dammages, tho≈øe to be a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by a Jury.

div.head: What to do in Commons.
div.p: THis is a matter of large extent, and is one of the great ≈øores of England, which wants healing.

Our Commons are either appendant, appurtenant, or by rea≈øon of vicinage, and were originally the relief of the bea≈øts of the Plow, and for the breed of young Cattel for the Freeholders, and do primarily belong to them; and as their Farm was, ≈øo might they put upon the Common greater or le≈ø≈øer quantity of Cattel, according to proportion.
But long ≈øince the rule of Commoning was lo≈øt, and Commons are become the ruine of the generalty of the poor, to whom Commonage belongs not.

For fir≈øt they get a Cow in Summer, and live idlely of that, and not providing again≈øt winter, they buy dear in the Spring, and ≈øell cheap at winter; and the rich, ≈øo long as the pur≈øe payes not, few regard how things go; by this at la≈øt mi≈øerable and remedile≈øs beggery en≈øues, be≈øides the general neglect of Commons, as of all matte ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ of publick intere≈øt, whereby many poor are undone by lo≈øs of their bea≈øts, the ground ≈øpoiled, and not half improved.
And la≈øtly, no due extant vi≈øible rule ≈øet, which ought to be in all Counties anew, and Rules for dreyning and improvement, beyond what the Commi≈ø≈øion of Sewers can reach.

To avoid this, it is nece≈ø≈øary, as in other matters, to empower ≈øome Gent. to con≈øider the Commons (give them only their charges nece≈ø≈øary at a ≈øet rate) let them have power (if you can pitch upon tru≈øty per≈øons) to ≈øettle Commons if you will continue them; otherwi≈øe to part them proportionably, and improve them by ≈øeveralties, leaving a ≈øet part to the poor only, to be improved for them, according to order of the Commi≈ø≈øioners, by the over≈øeers for the poor, and the order recorded in the County-Book for that purpo≈øe; and al≈øo in the Town, or Towns, if there be entercommuning; this is the be≈øt way of the two, as by experience meeting with more evils, and remedying them, then the other way is capable of, in a pre≈øent ≈øettlement, and is a≈ø≈øuredly far more durable.

Let free Warrens, and Fold-cour≈øes be con≈øidered, but not at the height, and ≈øetled where they plea≈øe in ≈øeveralty; this, if wi≈øely and prudently ordered, will afford not only a great and mo≈øt con≈øiderable improvement, but will afford a mean of ≈øetling the Nation; and may now be done without danger of In≈øurrections or Tumults; And let but the ≈øetling of Tenures be carried on rationally, plainly, and prudently with it, and the Generalty of the Nation will a≈ø≈øuredly ≈øee the clear benefit of change of Government.
Provided they may have Ju≈øtice that they may abide by, that is, know a≈ø≈øuredly when to end, as to begin, and at what expence.

div.head: Who ought to have the over≈øight of Bridges, Rivers, &c.
div.p: NOw as all matters of right and wrong are under the cognizance of the Supream Magi≈øtrate, who as he cannot by him≈øelf di≈øpatch all bu≈øine≈ø≈øes belonging to the Land, but by many hands, ≈øo much le≈øs all both at water and land, and all the evils accruing and ari≈øing in, from, and by both;

Therefore it is fit to have a Magi≈øtrate ≈øpecially deputed for cognizance of all ≈øuch matters which now lay in the cognizance either of the Admiralty, or Commi≈ø≈øion of Sewers, or Iu≈øtices of the Peace re≈øpectively, or for which any Commi≈ø≈øion is i≈ø≈øuable upon any Statute, with ≈øuch rules as are nece≈ø≈øary, both for amending, judging, and determining matters yearly emerging, and al≈øo ≈øuch as are meerly accidentall, and that in the re≈øpective Counties, yet in ≈øuch a way as the errors in the adjacent parts of Counties may be tryed without infringement of Liberties, which is be≈øt by a mediety of Jurors impanelled yearly, one year by the appointment of the Judges of one County, the other year by tho≈øe of the other County, and ≈øo by cour≈øe con≈øtant in tho≈øe places, we ≈øeeing the exce≈ø≈øive charge and trouble of purcha≈øing Commi≈ø≈øions; for let a Statute appoint five ≈øhillings only as in ca≈øe of the Commi≈ø≈øion of Sewers, you can have none under five pounds, and ten, or twenty pounds attendance to procure it.

div.head: Who are to be admitted witne≈ø≈øes in Judicial Tryalls?
div.p: IF Jurors be to have knowledge and e≈øtate, and that in ≈øuch manner as may an≈øwer the Tru≈øt, then ≈øurely in ≈øome mea≈øure witne≈ø≈øes, upon who≈øe evidence the Jury is ≈øworn, to lay the foundation of their judgement ≈øo called Verdict, ought to be men fit to be beleeved; The Law principally looks fir≈øt at infamy, e≈øpecially perjury; but this being legal perjury, the puni≈øhment was ≈øo penal, and the Law ≈øo difficult, that few were complained of, fewer attainted.

Now this is ≈øure, moderate puni≈øhments, ≈øeverely executed, curb more then ≈øevere puni≈øhments remi≈øly or not at all. The Law in the next place lookt at Excommunication, for relations they are not valued in Law as to witne≈ø≈øes.

A≈ø≈øuredly he ought who is a legal witne≈øs to be of ≈øufficient under≈øtanding, next not convicted of notorious crime; for ju≈øtly what is the cau≈øe of rendring a man uncapable of the benefit of the Law, or rejection of Church-Society, ought to be admitted if proved, a good plea again≈øt the witne≈øs; yet let ≈øuch a man ≈øpeak, but not upon oath; for he that obeyes not man for Gods ≈øake, nor God for his own, is not be allowed to call God to witne≈øs; for in his acts he denyes him, though with his mouth he owns him. If it be askt, Why heard?
Then I an≈øwer, he may ≈øpeak truth, but is unworthy that ≈øacred Te≈øtimony.

Therefore the Magi≈øtrate mu≈øt from his words and probabilities and circum≈øtances, and ≈øo the Jury gather the truth of the matter; but where the man is capable of oath, let him be ≈øworn, whether 'twixt the State and Subject, or Subject and Subject; for right is the ≈øame.

There is al≈øo nece≈øsity to hear the wickede≈øt mans Te≈øtimony, though not ≈øwear him, becau≈øe we cannot alwayes chu≈øe witne≈ø≈øes; therefore e≈øtate is not requi≈øite, nor can be ≈øtood upon in witne≈ø≈øes, as in Jury-men, who are to be cho≈øen.

For point of favor; I find in this Age it is of great importance; for ≈øuch relations in Nature are generally preferred to, (though unworthily) relations either of Countrey or City, earth or heaven; few men leave all for Chri≈øt, Truth or Ju≈øtice ≈øake; Therefore I would admit the notice of alliance, but not the objection, and hardly carry it upon ≈øuch a ≈øingle Te≈øtimony.

div.head: When Laws have their beginning, and how to be promulged.
div.p: AS≈øuredly there ought to be a day certain, before which in the ≈øeveral Cities, Towns, Hundreds, &c. re≈øpectively, there ought to be an A≈ø≈øembly of the people, tho≈øe at lea≈øt who are, or may be, or immediately are concerned in that Law; and there, by ≈øome one or more of the Ju≈øtices of the limit, or ≈øome other thereto appointed, the whole nature of the Law, and the rea≈øon of it, ought to be opened; and the people exhorted to obedience them≈øelves, and al≈øo to ≈øee that their Neighbours do the like, which is of nece≈ø≈øity.
But the inability of Iu≈øtices, and difficulty of Laws, have rendred the people wholly doubtful and ≈øtupid, or petulant and ≈øtubborn.

And before ≈øuch promulgation, no puni≈øhment but of the Iu≈øtice for not promulgating, or Certificate of the default of the repre≈øentative for not tran≈ømitting the Law, the ≈øame to be ≈øetled and publi≈øhed accordingly.
The lew knew all Mo≈øes Law, the Chri≈øtians Lords know not their Law, they are all en≈øhrined in the brea≈øt of the Iudge; but enough of that.

div.head: The Magi≈øtrates duty to repre≈øs exce≈øs in Apparel.
div.p: THe mind of man is apt to take impre≈ø≈øions of ≈øundry Natures, and education may a≈ø≈øuredly rectifie Nature; much of this re≈øts in Apparel; for vain light Apparel makes the ≈øpirit lofty, not ≈øolid, and changes of habit adapt to mutability of fancy, a light fla≈øhing wit in ≈øtead of a compo≈øed judgement; Proud, humerous, ≈øelf-conceited and ≈øtubborn, in ≈øtead of a re≈øerved, prudent debating or ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion. div.head: What to be done in Ca≈øes for which no Law is ≈øet, or the Law clearly abu≈øed, annulled and antiquated.
div.p: SUurely there is no offence, no tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion, but it falls under ≈øome Head of general Law; yet Circum≈øtance may aggravate it ≈øo, that to qua≈øh the thought of it in the corrupt heart of man, there is exemplary puni≈øhment requi≈øite upon this account.

This for criminal matter; ≈øo for all defects and deceits which be remedied by Statutes Supplemental ≈øo called of the Common Law, that is, ≈øince it was pre≈øumed, that there was no Law for which there was not an adjudged Ca≈øe in the Year-books, leaving the Rule of the ≈øtring to go by the bow, or in ≈øome things which ought to be remedied, but now cannot; as for example.

A. ≈øojourns in the hou≈øe of B. his Nephew. B. after this ≈øhuts the doors again≈øt Father, Brothers, Uncles, Friends and all, and will ≈øuffer no one to ≈øee A. or ≈øpeak to him; the Magi≈øtrate is complained to, he hath no power. A. is thus impri≈øoned, it is fit to be provided that the Magi≈øtrate ≈øhould take a ≈øworn Clerk, and make A. his Will not to be altered but by the Magi≈øtrate ≈øent for by A. but it cannot be done, that is lawfully, and A. is now kept a pri≈øoner till death, his e≈øtate, as informed, all ≈øei≈øed and converted by a debauched man, a rebellious di≈øobedient ≈øon, and ungratious Nephew. Thou≈øand ≈øuch things are, which while the Magi≈øtrate is tied from the Rule by particular Laws, lay as heavy judgements upon the land, e≈øpecially upon the Supream Magi≈øtrate, who as a wi≈øe and good Phy≈øitian ought to have a ≈øalve for every ≈øore.
The Rule of Law is, Quae ≈øunt minoris culpae, ≈øunt majoris infamiae; the≈øe things which are unju≈øt, while profitable and unpuni≈øhable, are the Tetters of the Commonwealth, they do ≈øpread daily.

Therefore it mu≈øt either be re≈øolved, the Magi≈øtrate in Ordinary ≈øhall puni≈øh them as the Cau≈øe is, that is under the Rule of the head Law, if plain, or not criminal, or criminal re≈øpectively; otherwi≈øe, to attend a meeting of divers Judges, or the extraordinary Judge for Criminals, and in the mean time to ≈øecure by bayl or impri≈øonment as the Ca≈øe requires.

div.head: Whether Duels be lawful or not? and other Trials by fire, and water, &c. As in the trial of Witches, ≈øu≈øpition of Adultery, &c. and all doubts.
div.p: I Shall fir≈øt treat of Duels, which is without que≈øtion unlawful in all Ca≈øes, yea of the greate≈øt doubt.

But fir≈øt to ≈øpeak to plain Ca≈øes, mo≈øt of which are di≈øgraces, affronts, &c, for which the Law gives none, or not con≈øiderable ≈øatisfaction or reparations: Now it is clear in Law and Rea≈øon, that when words and ≈øigns become dangerous and prejudicial, the Magi≈øtrate ought to provide accordingly to repre≈øs; King James made very rational orders in the very cau≈øe of Duels, but ≈øaw them not executed; which di≈øgu≈øted the mo≈øt di≈øcreet ≈øpirits; but it was evident, the catch was but to halter the great men in the Springe of the Star-Chamber Law; ≈øuch policies never throve yet; Piety when the end is Gods Glory, with the peoples good (not particular per≈øons intere≈øt) is the be≈øt policy.

Let therefore the Magi≈øtrate no longer count words light, while they bear the weight and price of blood, but repair every breach, give a ju≈øt recompence for every lo≈øs, and then puni≈øh tran≈øgre≈ø≈øors ≈øeverely in ≈øuch Ca≈øes; for many think they may ju≈øtly become their own avengers where thc Law affords no remedy.
