The Lord Mar≈øhall did take notice of ≈øome of the≈øe matters, but not all, and that with ≈øuch delay and difficulty, that the parties were better try it ≈øhortly; therefore for all words, give ≈øpeedy remedy; let the complaint come pre≈øently to the Judge, and receive a trial accordingly as the Supream Magi≈øtrate ≈øhall order.

For the ≈øecond part, which are difficulties, ≈øu≈øpitions, &c. we have no infallible word to warrant it; the practi≈øe aro≈øe rather from Heatheni≈øh Super≈øtition, then Chri≈øtian Faith; therefore we are to leave them to Gods judgement, and ≈øettle the matter rather ≈øome other way, as of lot in Ca≈øe of doubts in civil claims, which a≈ø≈øuredly is lawful.

But as to the other ≈øu≈øpitions, there the cau≈øes of ≈øu≈øpition are to be examined, and if approved, they are either evident or doubtful; if evident they convict; if doubtful, they render ≈øu≈øpected.

Now in all Ca≈øes of ≈øuch Tendencies to ≈øu≈øpition, if the parties ≈øu≈øpected walk ≈øtill ≈øu≈øpectedly, they are to be puni≈øhed, but not to the height of puni≈øhment; and puni≈øhment mu≈øt increa≈øe as crime does; but to entertain jealou≈øie too far is dangerous. Therefore let all Magi≈øtrates ≈øee ≈øome grounds before they admit Que≈øtion, more before they puni≈øh.
For the Ordeals, were they an infallible certain Rule, they might be u≈øed; but for want of that, they are unwarantably made Laws where ever u≈øed; and therefore where u≈øed, to be rejected.

div.head: What Religion the Magi≈øtrate is to ≈øettle; or his Duty and Power therein. Whether, and how there be, or may be two Supreams.
div.p:
I Have Implicitly ≈øcattered ≈øome opinions tending to the re≈øolution of a great part of this Que≈øtion, which I ≈øhall not again meddle with; my intention here being onely admitting the Magi≈øtrate Chri≈øtian, to Quaere his duty in the variety of opinions, and ≈øo reflect a little upon our pre≈øent doubts, and dicu≈øs them ≈øo far as may tend to ≈øettle, not divide; for for ≈øome high opinions of the Churches Power over the Magi≈øtrate, and for the e≈øteemed ob≈øtru≈øe and difficult opinion of the Magi≈øtrates acting as a Church Officer; both intending, notwith≈øtanding their expre≈ø≈øions, a ju≈øt
latitude to the Supream Power, but ≈øpecially exalting Chri≈øt and his Kingdom above all, yea though alledging the very words of the Pope, That no Chri≈øtian Magi≈øtrate but mu≈øt be a Church-Member, and ≈øo inferior to the Church it ≈øelf, whereof he is a member; for the Officers, as he is a member, mu≈øt give him the Rule, or the Congregation, yea though he were a Pa≈øtor or Elder him≈øelf.

I conceive this ≈øhort Tract, wherein ≈øo many particulars are briefly hinted, onely to draw them into di≈øcu≈ø≈øion, is not fit to open that controver≈øie, which mu≈øt be with much Wi≈ødom, Prudence, Judgement, and ability of divine Learning di≈øcu≈ø≈øed, or it will but cloud more, and tend to heighten the differences of intere≈øt twixt Church and State: I ≈øhall therefore (for the pre≈øent at lea≈øt) forbear to open that Controver≈øie, and look onely at the Magi≈øtrates duty generally; for his power, I make it the Handmaide onely to his duty.
Religion therefore being the proper object of the ≈øpirit of the inward man, is not the proper ≈øubject for the Magi≈øtrate as a man, nor of his power, no not though a Chri≈øtian.

Yet while there are Hypocrites in the world, and the Notion of Religion may veil Trea≈øons and Obliquities to the State, being and well-being of the neighbour; it is the Magi≈øtrates duty to ≈øee to the≈øe, as before; but as to the particular contentions of Chri≈øtians, in, and concerning, or Doctrine, or Di≈øcipline, it is not clear that the Magi≈øtrate hath ought to do in it, while the outward peace be not di≈øturbed thereby; I will exemplifie generally.
Suppo≈øe the Doctrinal Quaere be, How many Sacraments? Or whether Bapti≈øm came in lieu of Circumci≈øion, or di≈øcent from the particular ≈øeventh day as a Sabbboth, and the like.

We ≈øee plainly, that while the Magi≈øtrate u≈øed his power according to his opinion, as the Magi≈øtrate inclined, ≈øo matters went generally; and the oppo≈øites in opinion oft crucified each other, ≈øeldom converted.

It is well known, the great cau≈øe of our Embroilments now, is the difference pretended, betwixt tho≈øe of the Congregational way, and tho≈øe of the Pari≈øhional Di≈øciplined way; I have purpo≈øely omitted this matter to this conclu≈øion of the Work, to ≈øumm up all; for it is plain, the Controver≈øie ≈øtands thus, as is hinted in the fir≈øt Part,
Whether the Churches are to be gathered anew?

Now to under≈øtand this fully, it is to be noted, That the Church of England is counted Schi≈ømatical by Rome, renting from her, as ≈øuppo≈øing ≈øhe had ≈øo far parted from the Doctrine of Chri≈øt, as that there was no po≈ø≈øible ju≈øt Chri≈øtian Communion with her, which the Puritan mu≈øt ≈øtill hold, that is, the true Pre≈øbyter.

We have ju≈øtly bani≈øhed Super≈øtition, and wickedly given free ≈øcope to prophane≈øs; the lives of the be≈øt are ≈øo far≈øed with the rudiments of the fle≈øh, in eating,

for if in in Pauls time one eat fle≈øh, another Herbs, one meat ≈øacrificed to idols, others not, ≈øome kept dayes, others not:

Why this Ado, e≈øpecially with Chri≈øtians in a Church way? for in the Magi≈øtratick order ≈øurely he may (however he will) enforce, not prophaning the day he appoints as afore≈øaid; and though they onely of his opinion keep it regularly, yet none of any opinion ≈øhall de≈øpi≈øe it and him irregularly, and if they do and go unpuni≈øhed, be a≈ø≈øured the Magi≈øtrate is in the greate≈øt fault, he is or loo≈øe, or lazy, or both.

Now to ≈øetle it as Tythes, were the What, and how, and where, and when, and to whom well ≈øetled, it cannot be unlawfull, that is to give a tenth; but to admit it as of duty to the Mini≈øter as to the Prie≈øt, to plead cu≈øtomes of and for Tything, as well as to deny cu≈øtomes of not Tything, are all equally ab≈øurd, if throughly ≈øcanned; A maintenance, and that onely, is agreed due by all to them that Labour in the word and Doctrine; but the whole Mini≈øtery hath with us been ≈øo Generally corrupted, that not onely men have made or pretended con≈øcience to pay any Tythes to ≈øuch wolves in ≈øheepes Cloathing, but from the vanity, wickedne≈øs and perver≈øne≈øs of the≈øe men of corrupt minds, have que≈øtioned whither a mini≈øtry be.

Here is a hard task for the Magi≈øtrate; for he hath been nece≈ø≈øitated to take that power into his hands, which at fir≈øt him≈øelf que≈øtioned whither it were lawfull for him or not, but attempting and finding no danger pre≈øent, the fear is now lea≈øt he ≈øhould not let go his hold.

I pre≈øume this is clear, he may and will declare if he have any Religion, which he approves; this is mo≈øt naturall; that he will e≈øtabli≈øh what he con≈øents not to, who can per≈øwade him≈øelf of it? all that I can ≈øay is, if he be a Chri≈øtian, let him with all meekne≈øs and in the evidence of truth by all Chri≈øtian means labour to win all, but to enforce none but the wicked and di≈øobedient to ju≈øt and righteous Lawes; The want of which is the great di≈øgu≈øt of all good men: but I ≈øhall not enlarge here of that.

The Churches power then con≈øi≈øting principally, if not wholly, in things plain and evident, it is mo≈øt certain that the Magi≈øtrates Power in ordinary ought not to ≈øtretch ≈øo high, much le≈øs exceed; that is to help where that with humane thoughts ≈øeems to come ≈øhort, as the Church hath hitherto held;

Now in this I ≈øhall ≈øpeak one word to the great and weighty con≈øideration of the Supremacy of power, and whither, and how, there be, or may be Two Supreams, which will a little clear up the way for amity among≈øt ≈øo called Chri≈øtians of all opinions.

Fir≈øt we mu≈øt con≈øider the ri≈øe of the controver≈øie is from the word of God in all the new Te≈øtament, wherein all words of ≈øaving knowledge are directed ≈øoly, wholy and onely to the Elect, Saints at lea≈øt by calling and profe≈ø≈øion (which in their ≈øea≈øon ≈øome think, nay beleeve ≈øhall govern the world) and at the≈øe as called out of the way of the world, to a more holy and ≈øpirituall ≈øerving of him.

Now ≈øome ≈øuppo≈øe this was to be done onely in a Church way, which both Papi≈øt, Greek Church and Prote≈øtants of all ≈øides agree, that is, that the Magi≈øtrate Ruling among Chri≈øtians in ordinary ought to be a Chri≈øtian.

Now ≈øaith the Church of Rome, and all, as a Chri≈øtian he mu≈øt be a member of ≈øome vi≈øible Church; if ≈øo, he mu≈øt be ≈øubordinate to the Pope, and a generall Councell ≈øaith the Pope; to a generall Councell and Fathers of the Church, lay the Biblers of old: To a generall Councell and the Kirke, ≈øay both the Lutheran and Calvini≈øtical Divines; All which, place the Power of the Church Authoritatively in the Officers or Officer Supream.
Now tho≈øe of the Congregational way of all ≈øorts di≈øtingui≈øh as the re≈øt do.

Fir≈øt in that the Supream Magi≈øtrates are men, and ≈øo members of Churches, they are Subject to the Di≈øcipline of the re≈øpective Congregations and Churches, but as Magi≈øtrates they are di≈øtinct Officers in the world for the good of all men, and the peaceable and quiet Governing of tho≈øe committed by God to their charge.

Now as a member, he is inferior to the whole; And as a man he is Subject to Ordinances; But as a Prince, he is not Subject to the Church; for as the Prince cannot as Prince perform the Offices of a Pa≈øtor:
So neither can the Pa≈øtor, Officers of one or more Churches, intermeddle with the ruling power of the Prince as a Pa≈øtor or Church Officers, in any of their opinions.

Now for Supremacy, they who are Chri≈øtian Princes and Pa≈øtors, will not ≈øtrive for the Supremacy of Power, but keep their fixt places. All Saints are now the Kings, Prie≈øts, and Prophets of the mo≈øt High God; But more e≈øpecially the chief Magi≈øtrate in Ruling repre≈øents the Kingly Office of the Lord Chri≈øt, and the Pa≈øtors and teachers the Prie≈øtly and Prophetical.

The Prince Governs the Commonwealth according to the Judiciall Law of the Almighty God, the Law of pure righteou≈øne≈øs laid forth in both the Te≈øtaments; And the Pa≈øtors and Teachers and Elders Govern the Church in di≈øpencing the Ordinances and Rules of the Go≈øpel: the Pa≈øtor principally if not only in Preaching of the Doctrinall part of Chri≈øtianitie; the brethren appointed to teach, in opening the practicall part of Chri≈øtianitie.

I know that ≈øome hold, that all ought to come under the pure notion of Church Government, and all Magi≈øtrates to Rule as Church Officers; I allow it fit to be Queried; but I pre≈øume it is the wickedne≈øs of our pre≈øent age blinds our eyes, that we ≈øee not all that all of them who pretend to ≈øinceritie de≈øire; And I ≈øee not, notwith≈øtanding our variety of opinions, but that all that have not the mark of the bea≈øt, ≈øhall ≈øit down with Abraham, I≈øaac and Jacob, in the Kingdom of Heaven.

By this it is plain there is in the Church of Chri≈øt, the Lord Chri≈øts Sub≈øtitutes in Governing the Nations by the materiall ≈øword according to a Law of righteou≈øne≈øs, and Ju≈øtice, which man may comprehend.
And there is the Lord Chri≈øts Sub≈øtitutes in holding forth to the ≈øeverall Churches the Go≈øpel of Love; the one hath the ≈øword of Ju≈øtice, the other that of the Spirit.
In the order of Government, the Pa≈øtors and all the Saints mu≈øt ≈øubmit to the Supream Magi≈øtrate as to Chri≈øt the King.

As a Chri≈øtian, the Magi≈øtrate mu≈øt ≈øubmit to the Doctrine and Di≈øcipline of the Church of Chri≈øt, as a member of that body whereof Chri≈øt is the head, as a member, a Chri≈øtian, ≈øubject to the Ordinances of the Go≈øpel: As a Prince ruling ju≈øtly tho≈øe committed to his charge.

It will be thought that this admitting of the Prince ≈øubject as a member, will make his power ≈øub≈øervient to the end of that particular Congregation to which he is a≈ø≈øociated; And this will breed Emulation, and at la≈øt divi≈øion; Now let this throughly be con≈øidered in the cau≈øe original; and the head of this fountain of bitterne≈øs being ≈øtopped, the ≈øtreams it is hoped will be dried up.

From whence doth all this proceed but from the opinion of the benefit of uniformity, and from thence the nece≈ø≈øity? and thus we War, that we might have peace, and in≈øtead of convincing by Love, and waiting the appointed time, when the vi≈øion will a≈ø≈øuredly make ha≈øte and come, and will not tarry, we enforce; labouring as we think by humane wi≈ødom, politiquely to prevent the evils we imagine may grow to a di≈øturbance of the Peace of the Church; And ≈øurely this pride of heart and humane Wi≈ødom, this thinking ≈øo well of our ≈øelves, and looking at the opinions of Chri≈øtians more then the lives and conver≈øations, which is next to the eye of every man, and whereby God, and Chri≈øt, and the Go≈øpel is vi≈øibly di≈øhonoured, is the ≈øource or ≈øpring of the quarrels of Chri≈øtians: our duty in practicall Chri≈øtianity is ≈øo plain, and our conver≈øation ≈øo contrary, that it is the Wonderment of a Morali≈øt, and all our divi≈øions for Church Government.
Power, oh had we Power.

And what brethren, could you do with your Power? could you raze one opinion out of the heart of any con≈øcientious man, now after ≈øo many thou≈øand yeers (man leave this vanity) Chri≈øtian, now after ≈øixteen hundred yeers, learn to know the motions of the heart are only in the hand of the Lord; teach in ≈øea≈øon, and out of ≈øea≈øon, to draw to the Faith; but let the Spirit of man be convinced of the duty of Faith; What ≈øen≈øe and rea≈øon, is capable of in the plain Law, enforce ≈øo far as to ≈øecure the peace, and expiate ju≈øtly the offence.
For the Quaere of the power of Churches one over the other, I ≈øuppo≈øe it is beaten ≈øufficiently, and in whom the Power of ≈øetling of Pa≈øtors, and Power of excommunication re≈øts.
I ≈øhall now proceed, and as a nece≈ø≈øary Quaere treate a little
Fir≈øt of Impropriations, and then of Pre≈øcriptions?

Impropriations to ≈øpeak plainly, are of two ≈øorts; the fir≈øt called appropriations being the granting pre≈øentative benefices to Religious hou≈øes; The other was the freeing of ≈øuch Lands as were given to Religious hou≈øes, from the payment of Tythes; the ground of this was the ≈øuppo≈øed vertue that was in the prayers of the≈øe Religious per≈øons; but indeed there was a knot of carnall Policy al≈øo, which was to keep the people ignorant by admitting little preaching, which was counted the mother and nur≈øe of Sedition.

Now this Arrow came not only out of the Popes quiver, but ≈øecular ≈øo called Princes, after he began, followed, till at length the Abbyes, Mona≈øtaries, Fryeries, &c. had, abounding in riches, and thereby abounding in ea≈øe, growing Luxurious and ≈øinfull beyond belief, fulfilled the mea≈øure of their iniquities; and Henry the 8. was the in≈øtrument as afore≈øaid to plague them, who yet looking rather at Lucre and Power temporall, then Religious duty, did not return the Benefices and Tythes into the Ancient cour≈øe, but conveyed them ≈øtill along to the owners of the Lands of tho≈øe Mona≈øteries, &c. to which they were annexed as they are ≈øtill continued.
Now as many had ≈øuch things by particular grant, ≈øo others held them, and ≈øome other onely by pre≈øcription; but the not doing of three or four things, makes Reformation difficult.

Fir≈øt the not ordering all Chri≈øtians in a Congregational way, either limited or parochiall, or ab≈øolute, which is be≈øt, without which a choice of a ju≈øt, ≈øafe and equall repre≈øentative (Chri≈øtian) will never be.

Thirdly the di≈øcharging of all pre≈øcriptions, cu≈øtomes, Grants, &c. of particular priviledge of old, either of places, times or per≈øons.

La≈øtly, the ≈øetling one Law weight, mea≈øure and tenure preci≈øely throughout the Nation. Now to ≈øpeak one word of pre≈øcription, I take it to be but only the continued Right of a particular per≈øon, or family, or now of a Corporation, Town≈øhip, &c. So that upon due and full ≈øearch, it ≈øeems to me no more then a cu≈øtome in many places and ca≈øes.

Now for this, the time of pre≈øcription ought to be ≈øet certain; next the ≈øame ought after once pleaded, to be ≈øetled and publi≈øhed ju≈øt as a cu≈øtome, ≈øo that no publike Right may not be publikely known, and the Ju≈øtice of it owned; for many pre≈øcriptions are as unju≈øt as many cu≈øtomes, and equally to be di≈øallowed, as ari≈øing upon fal≈øe grounds, evil in them≈øelves, or tending to the dammage of the publike. I now come to Quaere

div.head: What Law the Chri≈øtian Magi≈øtrate ought to ≈øettle.
div.p: THis I ≈øuppo≈øe many will accompt a needle≈øs quaere, both in re≈øpect that the law judicial generally is formerly a≈ø≈øerted requi≈øite to be the head law, and al≈øo a forme or kinde of ≈øetled proceeding in law, agreed to be principally according to the rea≈øon of the common law ≈øo called of the Nation, herein laid down as grounded on the word of God.

But my intent is a little to di≈øcu≈øs the rights of the ≈øo called common law, and civil Law, and whither it be fit to allow ≈øuch divers courts of ≈øo called divers laws, and to ≈øearch ≈øhortly whether they were originally one and the ≈øame, or not, which I really ≈øuppo≈øe they were; for it is evident that although the fir≈øt writers of our laws u≈øe not the forme of words of the civil law, dividing the law into the tomes of the Dige≈øt, the Code, the Authentick, and the Feuds;
Yet the rule of Ju≈øtinians In≈øtitutes which are an epitome of the Dige≈øt, is by them wholly ob≈øerved.

Now the Dige≈øt or Pandect, that is the new called In≈øtitutes (for they are various in names) I agree to be but the drawing of the multitude of particular opinions and judgements of many venerable ≈øages of the Law into one ≈øetled body of Law, containing variety of learning, upon particular Titles of law or head laws, which laws being grown exceeding voluminous and intricate, the Engli≈øh neglected them; and few being learned, they were under the ≈øword di≈øpen≈øed with, and politiquely brought into the Clo≈øet of the Conquerors brea≈øt; and as the condition of the Nation required, were enlarged or ≈øtreightned at plea≈øure: And upon intere≈øt only, the municipal law or cu≈øtomary Law of the people was by ≈øome ≈øetled in oppo≈øition to the ≈øo called civil Law.

Now this intere≈øt was partly of Princes, who found the Civilian ≈øtill to draw ≈øtrongly towards the advancement of Papall intere≈øt; partly of the practizer, who hereby ≈øiding with the Prince, at la≈øt drew the Civilian into a narrow room, and got the name of common lawyer, as ≈øtudious of that law which was u≈øed and received among the people by tradition generally, and in time they got preheminences and liberties as we have ≈øeen e≈øtabli≈øhed.

We have known the great ≈øtrifes that have been in the≈øe courts not out of con≈øcience of the intere≈øt of ju≈øtice to be either more faithfuly, or more ≈øpeedily, and at a due rate executed, but to bring gri≈øt to the Mill, as the mini≈øters glory was to have a multitude of Auditors, no matter how few Chri≈øtians, they would but ≈øcan his Doctrine, que≈øtion his life, and unle≈øs he were more worthy, ≈øcruple adding more to his former abundance.

So the≈øe mens honor, was, to have their courts packed with ≈øutors, that the ≈øeveral practi≈øer from the Judge to the dore-keeper might have his Fee; from the≈øe ≈øhifts grew the ≈øo called prohibitions, con≈øultations, &c. And the poor Sutor was undone, while the Courts admitted Fir≈øt with ea≈øe the Quaere, and then eagerly pro≈øecuted their own dues and rights before his could be determined, which was ever ≈ølow paced enough.

This evidences the nece≈ø≈øity of ≈øetled Fees in all places, and that from the ≈øupream Magi≈øtrate; This al≈øo clears the ca≈øe that the ≈øupream Magi≈øtrate mu≈øt admit but one Law in practice and proceeding, nor one ≈øort of Lawyers; he may for the advance of learning order the ≈øtudy of it in Latin and all the exerci≈øes.

But the practi≈øe all ought a≈ø≈øuredly to be in the vulgar tongue of the Nation, and in that tongue to be con≈øtantly printed, and al≈øo all precepts and proce≈ø≈øes of the Courts what≈øoever; for the pure executing of ju≈øtice is more to be eyed then humane learning; For as in the Eccle≈øia≈øtick State, when the ordinances of men and unction of men are preferred above, and ju≈øtle out the ordinances and unction of the Lord, the Church is Apo≈øtate:

So when intere≈øts overtop ju≈øtice, and ju≈øtice and righteou≈øne≈øs are become Nominal, Topical heads, Hypocritical Colours to wilder the people, the State is al≈øo Apo≈øtate; and as long as either of the≈øe work in Church or State, the Apo≈øtacy, the fatal ruining Antichri≈øtian Apo≈øtacy reigns.

Therefore all the Courts of a well con≈øtituted Nation, a Nation that ≈øeeks the welfare and freedome of her people indeed, mu≈øt have a body of Law proper to the Nation, and this mu≈øt as before, be ≈øo ≈øetled, that every Subject may in due ju≈øt and evident way partake the benefit of it; therefore it mu≈øt all be common, and keep that name, that weak ones may not be offended, what law ≈øoever be ≈øetled; for it is mo≈øt properly belonging to the Community.

La≈øtly, admit as little form as may be, yet I would ≈øettle the habits of Judges and practizers in all Courts, but by way of honor; for I intend but this one word, the glory of form is lo≈øt where form is made Common, Scarlet, the ornament of Judges is the guard of a Groom in the≈øe daies.

div.head: Whither offices may be put to ≈øale.
div.p: IN a word this is the plain inlet to all corruption; admit this and your ≈øetlement mu≈øt totter; to di≈øtingui≈øh betwixt judicial places and other, is but to hook in a liberty to unlawful things by degrees; for all are officers tending to the execution of Ju≈øtice, and it is unju≈øt to pay too much, and to ≈øtay too long for ju≈øtice, as well as to be denied ju≈øtice, or have fal≈øe ju≈øtice; Admit ≈øuch practi≈øes, and all eva≈øions of Law will be not only ≈øtudied but practi≈øed; one evill admitted, a thou≈øand follow.

That ju≈øt and hone≈øt and wi≈øemen have done it, and do it, is not worth the while; the ≈øhort an≈øwer is, there is no man but errs, And ≈øoone≈øt in matters of intere≈øt, much more where cu≈øtome ≈øignes the lawfulnes of it; but a word to what makes it ≈øeem lawful.

Suppo≈øe the place be eighteen hundred pounds per annum accompted, as the Chancelours was in the late Kings time; and Sir John Finch pay ≈øo much annually, viz. Two thou≈øand pound to Duke Hamilton, Two thou≈øand to Lord Au. and at la≈øt hath four or five thou≈øand pound a year only to him≈øelf.

So the Prothonotary of the Common Pleas to pay eleven thou≈øand pounds for his place, and have eleven, twelve, thirteen, fourteen, fifteen hundred or two thou≈øand pounds a year, had he not better have had it freely, and only five hundred, then if he had died within a year, left his only daughter a beggar, and his Friends engaged only to purcha≈øe a more then nece≈ø≈øary allowance? I could ≈øet down who had this money, how it was ≈øhared, unle≈øs wi≈øe and hone≈øt men then mi≈øinformed me.

By this it is clear, that there may be a ≈øufficiency to ≈øettle the intere≈øts of the ≈øupream Magi≈øtrate, if they have wi≈øe and hone≈øt men to carry on the work, upon foundations of certain Ju≈øtice, and pay every officer, and the Supream Magi≈øtrate to be a gainer, however no loo≈øer, but the people to be ≈øurely advantaged in the ju≈øt procedure and I≈ø≈øue of their litigations.

Now for the choice of Officers it is ≈øetled before; both in the qualification hone≈øt and skilled; and in due manner approved; and in places of many Officers, where aptne≈øs is by the cour≈øe of ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, if no objection bee, is mo≈øt plau≈øible, but not to be tied to it.

Now the way to have good Officers, is to ≈øettle eminently ju≈øt Judges; and to gain them, is not to have too many; and in yong States or beginnings this is of ab≈øolute neee≈ø≈øity; for without it ruine is unavoidable.

div.head: The nece≈ø≈øity of educating Sea-men, and the way of breeding them, and from that of the Politique Law to re≈øtrain eating of Fle≈øh.
div.p: THis quere is of great concernment to This Nation and I≈øland; God is our ≈øupport; but the means which the Lord affords us, are not to be neglected.
Therefore in the fir≈øt place we ≈øhall look at the way of encrea≈øing, and breeding Mariners.

I ≈øuppo≈øe it is clear to mo≈øt intelligent men, that by the fi≈øhery, there by long being abroad in ≈øtormy ≈øea≈øons, and high Seas, whither great gain invites them, they become not only inured to the Sea, but grow hardned and dreadle≈øs, their experience being much more then either a Merchant or man of War can atchieve; So that where they breed one able Mariner, a poor North Sea-man breeds Ten. I mu≈øt therefore be the care of the Supream Magi≈øtrate e≈øpecially to provide for even the≈øe.
The fir≈øt care is that they may fi≈øh ≈øafely, therefore the convoy ought to be ≈øufficient.

Next when they come home, there mu≈øt be vent for the fi≈øh; The ob≈øtacle is the old ≈øuper≈øtition of the Lent, or the Forty dayes fa≈øt: the ju≈øt and prudent Magi≈øtrate can ea≈øily remedy this, by making it Twenty eight or Thirty daies.
There is an objection or two again≈øt the ≈øea≈øon.
Fir≈øt religious or ≈øo ≈øuppo≈øed, ju≈øt before Ea≈øter, and carries the time of ≈øuper≈øtition: ≈øetle it to begin upon a certain day of the Month yearly and that ≈øcruple is gone.

The next is Phy≈øical: then is the return of the year, and our bodies which ≈øhould then receive be≈øt nouri≈øhment, are filled by fi≈øh with cold and flatulent nouri≈øhment; this may ≈øeem much to ≈øome, but it is not worth the while: for ≈øuppo≈øe there were nor fle≈øh nor fi≈øh, there is variety of meats to live on for a month in England.

But I ≈øuppo≈øe two daies in a week truly ob≈øerved to have no fle≈øh ≈øpent were better; for ≈øee how Lent was kept: lay in ≈øo much fle≈øh before as ≈øerved the hou≈øehold; And ≈øo it would be, ye will ≈øay, for two dayes in a week; I agree it; therefore I ≈øay truly ob≈øerved: therefore as in the hi≈øtorical part I propound that the rea≈øon of every law be divulged, and con≈øcience from conviction of the benefit of it engaged to obedience, and no way like that, as the examples of Catholique ab≈øtinence now manife≈øt.

But if the Magi≈øtrate would u≈øe force, I ≈øhall offer the be≈øt and mo≈øt rea≈øonable way, which is to ≈øend to every hou≈øehold in every town ≈øo many fi≈øh at an equal and ≈øet rate by him, according to the number of his family, ≈øo many fi≈øh for every head by the year, accompting two daies in the week wholly for fi≈øh.

Now the benefit of the pre≈øervation of yong Cattell, is great and warily to be provided for: therefore let the Magi≈øtrate enact, that all Lambe killed before ≈øuch a day ≈øhall be forfeited, and the killer and eater to forfeit a price.

Secondly the wool and skin is then ≈øerviceable.

Now for Calves, the laws for rearing of yong Cattell mu≈øt be made in
them more certain; for Bull Calves needs not in many places to be pre≈øerved equally as others; ≈øome al≈øo are plainly unfit for to be reared, at lea≈øt by opinion; Therefore there mu≈øt be a loo≈øe to them more then others.

div.p: ASSuredly the taking of cu≈øtomes, &c. engages the Supream Magi≈øtrate to the guard of the Sea; now this done, many think the work is done, and cu≈øtomes are due clearly; but the Subject mu≈øt bear his private lo≈øs.

Others Chri≈øtianlike ≈øay that there are providences which none can e≈øchew, and for the≈øe each one mu≈øt bear his own burthen. Next there are remote places wherein Traffique is thought ≈øetled; Yet clearly in dominions of other Princes and States, and that for any Supream Magi≈øtrate to a≈ø≈øure their Subjects in all places, is impo≈ø≈øible. Therefore the Engagement of the Magi≈øtrate mu≈øt be ≈øetled.
Fir≈øt that the Piracy be within ≈øuch a precinct or bound.
Secondly that it be a ve≈ø≈øel of the Nation.

Thirdly of goods lawful, but not that if any goods unlawful were in the Ship, no recompence be, but that recompence be only for lawful, that is not goods prohibited, whether for importation or exportation.
Fourthly to a Subject of the Nation, in other ca≈øes let the cu≈øtomes of Nations prevail.

But in the≈øe ca≈øes it is ju≈øt that Recompence be to the loo≈øers by the Supream Magi≈øtrate out of prizes taken by his men of War, which ought therefore to be valewed, and returnes made Annually to the lo≈øers as their lo≈ø≈øes are proved in time; allwaies provided a high puni≈øhment, bee to him or them abu≈øe the State.

Now there is great difficulty made of the proof of the≈øe things. But we perceive it is ea≈øie to the State if the Governors have a minde; for the lading will appear in the Bill or Cocket if they have it; if not, and

That that be mi≈øcarried, they can have what they can claime out of the office from whence they ≈øailed; And the Principal Merchants can quickly make out the work; e≈øpecially if all Merchants be brought under rules of Trade as they ought to be, what ever is yet alledged to the Contrary.

div.head: How all Accompts for the Common Wealth are to be ≈øetled &c.
div.p: THis ought al≈øo to be done in the ≈øeveral Counties; there, are the men be≈øt known and their dealing.
Admit complaints to men impowred, and that with ≈øpeedy and due Ju≈øtice, and ≈ømall charge, and men in con≈øcience will complain oft, where little or no cau≈øe is; but that is quickly ended.
But make it difficult, and Envy and Malice are the only accu≈øers; men do accu≈øe then not of but out of con≈øcience only.

Let the times be ≈øet po≈øitively wherein to have all accompts cleared, and yet let none be called to accompt upon error after a ≈øet time; for I would have all formal accompts cleared and burnt once in ≈øeven years, they are not worth the keeping; let the Auditors be carefully a≈ø≈øigned, who are to prove the accompts, and let the puni≈øhment
be in ca≈øe of Error or Arrears ≈øecuring e≈øtate, till cleared, and the per≈øon, except good Sureties be; for it is clear, it is the due pro≈øecution of ju≈øtice is the great priviledge; and if nothing but ≈øecuring per≈øons will keep them in due order, let the work be done.
For the Iudges, they mu≈øt have power to call to account as oft as they ≈øee cau≈øe, but all to be ended with the year as afore≈øaid.
And let all Trea≈øurers and Officers have their fees from the State, as before.

Next let them have their offices onely during well abearing, and ≈øo much in the pound truly for all di≈øcoveries of deceits, and the work will manage it ≈øelf, e≈øpecially if once the erroneous principle of conceiving it unchri≈øtian and unbrotherlike for a brother to enform of a brother be beaten out of the world.

div.head: In whom is the Right and Power of Calling Councels.
div.p: THis is a great Que≈øtion, much ado is made concerning it in the world, and yet all to little purpo≈øe; for that mo≈øt ≈øpend their time onely in treating what was done; but few upon what right it was founded.
It is not, nor cannot be intended here, who ≈øhould Congregate the people in Civil Matters.
No, it is intended in Que≈øtions doubtful, troubling the peace of the Churches of God.

Now it is plain, by what hath been ≈øaid before, that the latitude of the Magi≈øtrates power in the≈øe ca≈øes, is only the pre≈øervation of the publick Peace; otherwi≈øe he hath but the relation of a private Chri≈øtian.
Therefore as Emperour, King, or State, to ≈øettle, or convene a Colloque, A≈ø≈øembly, Dyet, or Councel, Provincial or General, he hath no Power in a Church-way.
It mu≈øt be only prudentiall, to a≈ø≈øure or continue the publick peace in the be≈øt way they may, wherein all things that are not unlawfull and be expedient, become lawful.

But to a≈ø≈øure the jealou≈øie of the Supream power, it is not requi≈øite to have ≈øuch publick Conventions without the Magi≈øtrates permi≈ø≈øion; but to turn this ≈øufferance into a Right, was an Error.

Again, for the Churches to de≈øire the Magi≈øtrates permi≈ø≈øion, and after to enforce a Grant, or ≈øummon without, was a greater fault; for their profe≈ø≈øion admits le≈øs deviation; ju≈øt Magi≈øtrates will not deny the Churches lawful meetings, while the Churches ≈øeek but lawful things lawfully.

Now as the Churches have the fir≈øt in≈øight, as by Office, into Church Errors, it is their duty to con≈øult a remedy; and if a meeting of ≈øome few Churches, yea be it provinciall, ≈øhall be required, till error ari≈øe, it may not be unlawfull; they have the Right.

But if the Magi≈øtrate upon error ≈øettle a Law to prevent that error, (further the Magi≈øtrate ought not to go, and ≈øo far he may) then the Churches ought to ob≈øerve that Law; But in ca≈øe of Error, or ≈øuch Conventions as are po≈ø≈øibly dangerous to the Civil Peace, the Supream Magi≈øtrate ought to be advi≈øed, and ought to be obeyed, if di≈ø≈øenting, yea though his di≈ø≈øent be not in ≈øome eyes well grounded; for this evil is the lea≈øt, however experience hath manife≈øted in a ≈øuper≈øtitious Age the Churchman prevailes, in a ≈øwording the Magi≈øtrate.
What I have written, may to many ≈øeem doubtful, to whom the power of Right belongs.
But the plain meaning is this; This being a Church-Affair, an A≈ø≈øembly for the ≈øettlement of con≈øcience, it is the proper work of the Churches.

And if the Churches have power over one the other, as in the Popi≈øh, Epi≈øcopal, and Presbyterian way; the Summons ought De jure to move from the Church, but the Magi≈øtrate may prohibit, and ought to be obeyed; but divers Churches di≈ø≈øenting this in fact, cau≈øed fir≈øt an addre≈øs to the Imperial Power, and ≈øo it would do again; al≈øo the very Congregating ≈øuch Members into one place, ought, both for the ≈øafety of them that meete, and the place where they meete, and of the whole State, to be not onely with the knowledge, but the approbation of the Supream Magi≈øtrate; and the rather, for that though tho≈øe elected ought to go, yet no Chri≈øtian may be debarred; this in that way, and in the Congregational way more clearly will a≈ø≈øure, that though the bu≈øine≈øs be a Church bu≈øine≈øs, and concerning matters of meer con≈øcience: yet the great matter, is, as they are men, to con≈øult of difficulties and this is the Church-work; and therefore the Magi≈øtrate ought not to pre≈øcribe the Chri≈øtians met what to propound.
For I pre≈øume, That ought to be long before manife≈øted; fir≈øt, in the private Congregation, then in the adjoyning Churches, yea, in publike Conventions.
There is another part of the Quaere, that is, Whether the Magi≈øtrate may ≈øummon without the Churches prayer?

Now as to the right, a≈ø≈øuredly as a Father of the Country principally intru≈øted for the good, welfare, and peace of his people, and as a Chri≈øtian taking notice of unchri≈øtian Controver≈øies, he may invite a≈ø≈øembling the Churches, and may require it, but ought not enforce untill the civil Peace be actually di≈øturbed; he leaves the ≈øin at their door. This root of bitterne≈øs aro≈øe from thoughts of the nece≈ø≈øity of remedying what was ami≈øs, and venturing all for that, which is true and fal≈øe: A fal≈øe colour of truth with a real mi≈øtake; the Magi≈øtrate cannot enforce here; the Church mu≈øt have its due liberty here; otherwi≈øe we mu≈øt admit by the Rule of Contraries, the like power to the Church again≈øt the Magi≈øtrate offending.

No, let each keep their place, and if the Magi≈øtrate will amend the Church, let it be by Preaching, not fighting; let them come that will upon his call, let him per≈øwade the other, not enforce actually (politickly he may) no not though all that come agree with him.
But I am confident, Take away the intere≈øt of Power and Revenue, and the Spring of all the≈øe controver≈øies will be dried up; for the matter is clear in it ≈øelf, and by mo≈øt ≈øo agreed.
I could enlarge much in this, and all the heads that I have treated on.

I could have multiplied Quaeries to delight the Ear, and make the Book more Merchantable in this Age; I could have ≈øcattered witty varieties, Recorded old Hi≈øtories, and enterwoven new Stories, to have delighted a foeminine fancy; I could have ≈øo poli≈øhed my phra≈øe, and trimmed my di≈øcour≈øe, that it ≈øhould have ≈øtoln away the heart of a light youngling, and like a Romance fettered him in a clew of delights, till he had come to the end of the Book and been never the wi≈øer.

But as the fir≈øt thing moved me to this Work, was the ≈øerious apprehen≈øion of the bitter Cup the Lord had put into the hand of the Inhabitants of this Nation to drink, and what God had done in Germany; when my ≈øoul con≈øidered the deadly defiances among men ≈øo called Chri≈øtians; not onely Nation again≈øt Nation, but they of the ≈øame Nation one again≈øt the other:

When I eyed the Threats and Promi≈øes of the Word of the Eternal God, Revolved his Acts of old, and at pre≈øent done among≈øt us; comparing the Profe≈ø≈øions and Practi≈øes of Chri≈øtians; and that though we had light above others, yet our ≈øins were more grievous then others; but mo≈øt of all was my ≈øpirit affected with the many engagements which lay upon the Nation; For this light drew from us on all ≈øides, Royal, and Parliamentary, and that under what notion, or name, or opinion ≈øoever you will rank them, Promi≈øes and Vows of ≈øetling Truth and Righteou≈øne≈øs; King, Parliament, and People, all ≈øeeing the Errors in Church and State; a bare name, no face, if a foot≈øtep of pure Chri≈øtianity. This in the fir≈øt place put me upon a more ≈øerious way of Writing; and in the ≈øecond place, the multitude of my occa≈øions would not permit the idle time to clip, and pare, and file, when I was forced to ≈øteal time, to ca≈øt and mould the matter of this Di≈øcour≈øe by a quarter of the hour to day, and as
much the next, ≈øeldom an hour together, and then happily not of a week, two, or three, ≈øometimes not of a moneth after; This will render me to a wi≈øe man over zealous, and over-confident, to ru≈øh ≈øo unadvi≈øedly into ≈øuch a great undertaking as it doth attempt the holding forth, though but in E≈ø≈øay, the frame of a Civil Chri≈øtian Government; and they that know me will ≈øay,

Have ≈øo many Ages pa≈ø≈øed? Are ≈øo many wi≈øe men at pre≈øent? And none to undertake it, but one ≈øo young, a man not able for time to have dige≈øted in any part the voluminous Tracts, which he that but offers at ≈øuch an E≈ø≈øay ought to have gone through; and to do all this raptim, and that by ≈ønatches, which required the mo≈øt ≈øerious thoughts.

La≈øtly, A man that practi≈øed the Law of England ≈øo ≈øhort a while, that he could not comprehend the Ambages of it; and for eminency of parts, a man of no Renown, the world hath not taken notice of him.

I know this, as to others, will be the whi≈øpers and ≈øpeakings concerning Me, and this Work; It is not pre≈øumption of my Abilities, nor to gain applau≈øe that I adventure upon this Work; my heart was fired within me, when after ≈øo many reiterated undertakings for Righteou≈øne≈øs, Ju≈øtice, &c. I ≈øaw the VVork ≈øo far off from perfection, that it was wor≈øe then before.

I waited, attended, hoped, prayed, and all, yea incited men able, and skilled in the Laws of the Land, by long ≈øtudy, and approved parts: They agreed Error in the whole, a nece≈ø≈øity of Reformation, and that even by a Tran≈øub≈øtantiation not Con≈øub≈øtantiation; for they agreed the whole Law was, as it is, devolved into Form and Practi≈øe; the pure ≈øtreams of Ju≈øtice, were as they fell from the fountain of Divine and Moral Rea≈øon, drawn by Art into private Ci≈øterns of Profit and Honour.
But they dur≈øt not undertake the VVork.

I de≈øired then, con≈øidering my many occa≈øions, That they would but impart ≈øomething to me, to help me in my ≈øo great attempt; I talked with ≈øome Attorneys to the ≈øame purpo≈øe; and from two men I received two Papers, ≈øhewing the abu≈øe of dammage clear and ≈øuing out the Cap. utlagats, the mo≈øt ordinary matters.

I then addre≈ø≈øed my ≈øelf to ≈øome men eminent in Honor, and places of Tru≈øt; di≈øcovered my minde; we argued; I ≈øaw they were convinced of the truth of the thing, and were re≈øolved, were the Law altered, they ≈øhould ≈øubmit, yea even to what I then and here propounded.

But they would have no hand in it; they had no time, they had ≈øpent their Studies in the pre≈øent Law, and to change was a new work; Some advi≈øed me to leave off the≈øe thoughts, and fall to Practi≈øe, they would warrant me I ≈øhould get as much as any of them; After long delayes, con≈øulting my own ≈øtrength, and ≈øeeing Judges, Serjeants, Councellors, Attorneys, Solicitors, and All, confe≈ø≈øed Alteration nece≈ø≈øary, delayes evident, Ju≈øtice incertain, Equity more ruining then undoing Common Law.

I did partly out of the ≈øence of the unju≈øtne≈øs and wickedne≈øs of the Law, but principally that I might be out of the la≈øh of a credit Ruining frown, leave all Practi≈øe what≈øoever, as I had formerly left the mo≈øt, and did con≈øult which way to take to open in the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian way, the Evils of the Apo≈øtate State, and Commonwealth; and how to offer an expedient ≈øutable to the condition of the people wedded to Laws and Cu≈øtoms called their own.

This is that which the Lord put me upon; I have avoided to my utmo≈øt all bitterne≈øs, and ju≈øt occa≈øion of offence to any, either Powers, or per≈øons: And to any man ≈øhall require a further account of the hope that is in me concerning matter of Con≈øcience, or of the matter of Law, and the Rea≈øons herein offered, ≈øo it be with Chri≈øtian meekne≈øs and zeal for the Truth, according to my knowledge, I ≈øhall freely di≈øcover my ≈øelf, and yield I hope, a ≈øatisfactory an≈øwer.

For I a≈ø≈øert, there is nothing here laid down in any kind, as to the civil Regiment, not warranted by the pre≈øent (≈øo called) Law-books of England; I re≈øtrain not my ≈øelf to the ≈øo called Year-Books.

For the ≈øcantne≈øs of my time, I could have wi≈øhed more, and more abilities, and that both natural and experimental; but you mu≈øt take it as it is; onely an E≈ø≈øay for a
Settlement of a Chri≈øtian Commonwealth, I leave the Work to ≈øuch as Providence ≈øhall cull out of the many pre≈øent Worthies of Englands Labourers.

Me thinks, England labours like a woman in ≈øore pangs of Travel, crying out to be delivered; I pray God none of the Midwives Juno like ≈øet cro≈øs-legg'd in the Temple of honor, profit, power, or the like. O that every one could bani≈øh all intere≈øts, and all Relatious for Chri≈øts ≈øake.

I know abundance that will allow this project of Re≈øolving this Nation into County Juri≈ødictions, their ≈øpirits will be immediatly fancying places to them≈øelves, friends, kindred, &c. for the moddle holds forth a due ≈øatisfaction, even to carnal Intere≈øts.
The oppo≈øition will ari≈øe from the great intere≈øt of the City of London, and the Supream Judicatures; but it is clear, their intere≈øt may thus be continued to a ju≈øt proportion.

Now they ruine Government within them≈øelves, and de≈øtroy the whole Nation be≈øides; let them live, but let not England peri≈øh; for the Lords ≈øake, you that are our Phy≈øitians, remember your promi≈øes when you undertook the Cure.
Then you ≈øtroaked the wound gently, you asked nothing till the cure were perfected; but our wound is open ≈øtill, more wayes to di≈øcourage the poor impoveri≈øhed ≈øubject then ever.

Take but the many fruitle≈øs Acts for poor pri≈øoners into con≈øideration, and the forceing an Affidavit of the Engagement, notwith≈øtanding a Certificate of the Commi≈ø≈øioners; can we not ea≈øily determine the Rea≈øon? it cannot be zeal for Ju≈øtice, but the Clerks Fee upon the Oath; our hearts are hot in pur≈øuit after the world, while our lips breath forth expre≈ø≈øions of the new birth.

You that are in Authority, like valiant Chieftains, mu≈øt not onely ≈øpeak couragiou≈øly, but Act rigorou≈øly; you and your ju≈øt Acts and Ordinances are ≈ølighted, and contemned; Fir≈øt, by your ≈øelves, our Tru≈øtees, they are not duly tran≈ømitted to the Counties; then by our ≈øelves, your Tru≈øtees, they, or ≈øome of them deal with them as they li≈øt, each one interprets as his intere≈øt leads.

Nay, come up to London, waite and attend till you be weary; the ju≈øtne≈øs of your Cau≈øe gives not the quicker di≈øpatch; yea, I have heard, that ≈øome ≈øpoken to, to ha≈øten matters agreed on, have been told their ha≈øte ≈øhould cau≈øe their tarriance, or words to that effect.

The≈øe are ≈øad Symptoms, to ≈øuch Melancholy ≈øpirits as mine, of renewed Judgements; I ≈øhall ≈øay no more, But leaving the whole Work to the Lord, addre≈øs my ≈øelf to ≈øeek his face, and pray unto
THe Lord our God, the God of Abraham, I≈øaac, and Jacob, and of all the faithful, the Almighty Jehovah, the Father of our Lord Ie≈øus, and in him both of Jew and Gentile.
That he will plea≈øe to open the eyes of all called Chri≈øtians, and give them hearts to under≈øtand his wayes, that they may ≈øee and perceive the evil of their doings; that the preci≈øe≈øt profe≈ø≈øors may ≈øee, that from their evil walkings the Enemy takes advantage, and cau≈øes many Profe≈ø≈øors to fall off, vainely thinking all are wholly hypocritical, becau≈øe of ≈øome mens failings; Let tho≈øe, O Lord, who have ≈øome beginnings of re≈øenting their duty to ≈øeek thy face, not give any occa≈øion to thy Enemies (the profane-hearted yet among thy people) to tran≈øgre≈øs with more boldne≈øs becau≈øe of their Liberties.
Yea give the loo≈øe Profe≈ø≈øors to con≈øider, that their evident unchri≈øtian walkings cau≈øe the open Enemies of our ble≈ø≈øed Saviour to bla≈øpheme, even Jew and Gentile; for what people walk ≈øo contrary to their profe≈øsion, as the ≈øo called Chri≈øtian?
Father, I pray di≈øcover to them that claim to be called thy Clergy, as at lea≈øt (indeed) ≈øet apart for more excellent and eminent ≈øervices, in Word and Doctrine, that their lives mu≈øt be the be≈øt Interpreter of their words, their conver≈øations of their Exhortations and Per≈øwa≈øions. O let them all ≈øee, even from the highe≈øt to the lowe≈øt; that its Error evident hath cau≈øed Truth to be di≈øtru≈øted, and their words contemned; Righteou≈øne≈øs and Truth carry a Maje≈øty which Satan fears: Convince them therefore, that as they have lo≈øt the glory of Pa≈øtors, by preaching Chri≈øt, and pretending for Chri≈øt, and following the world, and ≈øeeking Self, ≈øo they mu≈øt redeem their ancient honor by ≈øignal ≈øervices.

Lord, di≈øpel from their minds the rudiments of the world; the ≈øuper≈øtitious rea≈øonings of the fle≈øh, and all carnal Ordinances, and give them the Evidence of thy Spirit, that by thy Power they may be instrumental in this our day of high expectation to draw much people to the Lord.
Holy Father, give us Magi≈øtrates as of old, men full of wi≈ødom, and of the fear of the Lord, men of courage, and de≈øpi≈øing riches: let them make Thee their ≈øtrength, not tru≈øting to their knowledge, knowing that in ca≈øe of a Kingdom appointed to ruine by God, wi≈øe Councels and fair occa≈øions avail not, but are by a ≈øecret over-ruling Providence wholly inverted: nor to their courage riches or power for the ≈øame rea≈øons.

thy Glory, re≈øerved for thy Call of thine own people: Lord ha≈øten that time, ≈øhorten the evil dayes for thine Elects ≈øake, and ≈øtir up all hearts in their re≈øpective places, ≈øo to act, as the vigor of all Chri≈øtian vertues may be ≈øo apparent, that all eyes may ≈øee the brightne≈øs of thy glory, the perfect image of the Father ≈øhining forth in the conver≈øations of the children.
